venue.about: Annual music festival celebrating the vital creative community of downtown Ithaca, NY, with musicians performing on porches around Fall Creek & Northside.
venue.name: Porchfest!

name: Porchfest 2014

description:
Porchfest, the annual music festival in Ithaca's Fall Creek neighborhood, will return for its seventh year on Sunday, September 15. Local performers ranging from rock bands and folk singers to Suzuki violin ensembles and jazz combos and beyond will take to the porches of Fall Creek for an afternoon celebrating Ithaca's wealth of local musical talent. Each year's Porchfest has been larger than the last, and 2013 will be no exception, with 139 performers signed up. See reverse for a list of artists confirmed for this year; the performance schedule will be announced soon.

Porchfest will run from 1:00 PM to 5:00 PM, with a picnic and open jam in Thompson Park (on Cayuga Street between Cascadilla and Marshall streets) to follow at 5:30 PM.

The number of Porchfest bands has increased steadily by about 20 performers per year since the first event in 2007. Organizers expect that there will be more than 150 bands signed up to play next year; in 2020 there will be 266 bands, and Porchfest will have exceeded 1000 bands in the year 2059. (The current committee is planning to retire before then.)

As in past years, local painter Nina Widger has created an original work for Porchfest 2013, which will be featured on Porchfest posters, t-shirts and other materials. This year's painting can be viewed on Porchfest's Facebook page, facebook.com/porchfest (direct link to photo: http://on.fb.me/1c73ZzL).

Since the first Porchfest in 2007, the concept has spread widely, with at least 10 similar events launching from Belleville, Ontario, to Tucson, Arizona.

Porchfest 2013 is sponsored by Ithaca Neighborhood Housing Services (ithacanhs.org), a non-profit, community development corporation whose mission is to revitalize Ithaca’s neighborhoods, encouraging stability and diversity, and to help people of modest incomes obtain affordable housing on a long-term basis. Additional support for printed Porchfest maps comes from the Museum of the Earth, whose Dino Jam concert is scheduled for November 10 (www.museumoftheearth.org).

# # #

description:
Erica Siegel Henning is a Vice President of Lionstone Investments, a Houston-based real estate investment firm that specializes in conceptualizing, researching and executing national investment strategies on behalf of institutional investors and high net worth individuals. 

As Portfolio Manager for the firm’s two opportunistic funds, she is responsible for portfolio management, strategy, and investment performance. 

Erica received an MBA degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, as well as undergraduate and graduate degrees from Cornell University.

Join us for the 20th Anniversary of the Cornell-Southside Community Center Healthy Pet Clinic! Founded in 1996 at the Southside Community Center (a nonprofit organization dedicated to celebrating African American culture), the Southside Healthy Pet Clinic is a walk-in clinic open twice a month that is run by veterinary students from the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine who are closely supervised by faculty and local veterinarians.

Fundraiser:  Tuesday, November 15th 
Doors Open: 5:30pm Showtime: 6pm  

Performers:
*  Stand-up comedian and veterinarian – Dr. Kevin Fitzgerald (https://youtu.be/ssWLXdkluxw)

Buy your tickets today on the State Theater of Ithaca website: http://www.stateofithaca.com/20th-anniversary-cornell-southside-community-ctr-healthy-pet-clinic

description:
Cornell Veterinary students will be coming to Troy to offer low cost preventative care to members of the Troy community who require financial assistance. The cost is $30 per pet which includes a physical exam, vaccinations, screening for certain common diseases (Dogs - heartworm and 3 common tick-related illnesses including Lyme Disease; Cats - Feline Leukemia Virus and Feline Immunodeficiency Virus), and flea/tick/heartworm prevention. Microchips will also be avilable for an additional $10 per pet.

These services are available to those requiring financial assistance. Each family may bring up to 2 pets.

Please bring one of the following documents to provide proof of eligibility: Medicare Card, Social Security Income Card, EBT Card, VA Disability Card, W-2 from 2015, pay stub from the last 6 months, or other proof of public assistance

The schedule an appointment email cuhealthypetclinic@gmail.com (preferred) or call 347-620-4738

description:
DOORS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FROM 10:00AM - 4:00PM
http://www.vet.cornell.edu/openhouse/

The students, faculty, and staff of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine invite you, your family and friends to our 50th annual Open House! 

Come celebrate 50 years of us sharing our passion of the profession with the community! Veterinary students and members of the faculty and staff host this annual event that provides a chance for those interested to get a closer look at veterinary medicine. We invite you to tour our college and learn more about our facilities, our equipment, and what we do everyday.

Students, faculty members, and staff will be on hand to answer your questions about a career as a veterinarian, a veterinary technician, or an animal care specialist. Careers in veterinary medicine have traditionally involved working with dogs, cats, cows, horses, sheep, and pigs. However, this rapidly growing field also provides opportunities to work in the animal health industry, government, armed forces and with many other species in zoos, wildlife refuges, and developing countries.

PLEASE NOTE:  PERSONAL PETS ARE NOT ALLOWED AT OPEN HOUSE

description: Are you struggling with parrot behavior problems? Are you wondering how to train your parrot to be more fun and interactive? Or do you just want to find ways to create the best life possible for your feathered companion? Then join us for an informative day of Force Free Animal Training (FFAT). FFAT is the term Barbara Heidenreich uses to describe her style of animal training. Force free means the use of coercion and aversives to get desired behavior are not an option. Instead Barbara focuses on using positive reinforcement, empowering animals to choose to participate and building a relationship based on trust. This results in a well behaved, interactive and entertaining companion parrot.

description:
How are animal, human, environmental and economic health connected? What do canine cancer and human cancers have in common? How does nutrition relate to the economy and wildlife preservation? Join this interdisciplinary panel of Cornellians as we examine some of the dimensions of the comprehensive field of One Health.

Don't live in Ithaca? Can't make it in person? The event will be live-streamed! http://www.alumni.cornell.edu/livestream/onehealth

description:
Join us for a glamorous evening at the vet school while supporting your favorite veterinarians-to-be at the same time! The SCAVMA Auction is a part of White Coat Weekend, in which we celebrate the third year students moving on to clinics.

All proceeds from the Auction support veterinary students attending SAVMA Symposium 2015 at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. This conference enriches students' educational experiences by providing access to material not taught in schools as well as excellent networking opportunities.

There are countless amazing items up for grabs for every walk of life, and you can check them out at cornellscavma.com/Auction. Come ready to bid! You might score a stethoscope for your favorite vet student, some flea and tick preventative for your dog, gourmet treats for your cat, some new equipment for your vet clinic, a painting for your home, a hunting trip for your husband, or a CTB gift card for yourself! We are receiving new donations every day, so make sure you come to see all we have to offer.

The night starts at 5:00 pm with the Silent Auction and cocktails, with musical entertainment provided by our multitalented veterinary students. The Live Auction kicks off at 7:00 pm with a join performance by the vet college's very own Dance Collective and Ultrasound a capella group.

Tickets are $10 in advance or $15 at the door.

See you there!

description:
2014 Pedal for Pets
Ride with us ... Register 

April 26, 2014

Registration: 9AM (Centennial Room)

Ride starts: 10AM (B Parking Lot)

Early bird registration open through April 13!      

Every year, thousands of clients choose to bring their animals to the Cornell University Hospital for Animals (CUHA). Our faculty, students, and staff strive to provide quality medical care and education for our clients and their animal companions.

In the changing economic times, many of CUHA’s clients have found it difficult to afford quality medical care for their animal companions, both large and small. These clients are forced to forgo necessary diagnostic procedures and life saving treatments for their animals. To assist clients and patients in need, CUHA has created the Patient Assistance Fund. The Patient Assistance Fund benefits our clients with economic need to help cover medical and surgical costs for their animal companions. We, the Student Chapter of the American Veterinary Medical Association (SCAVMA), have chosen to support the Patient Assistance Fund at CUHA with this year’s Pedal for Pets bike-a-thon.

We invite you to join us! You can join our bikers on a 30- or 50-mile bike ride throughout Ithaca and the neighboring communities, sponsor a rider, donate a prize at the finish line for our riders, or help us to sponsor the event. All proceeds will benefit the Patient Assistance Fund. Please help us to make the veterinary care at CUHA more accessible to all.
Sincerely,

The Student Chapter of the American Veterinary Medical Association

Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine

http://www.vet.cornell.edu/events/pedal/

description:
More: http://bit.ly/1swl3Za

SATURDAY, APRIL 12, 2014
10:00AM- 4:00PM 
DOORS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FROM 10:00AM - 4:00PM

The students, faculty, and staff of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine invite you, your family and friends to our 48th annual Open House.

Open House is our opportunity to share the joys of our profession with the community. Veterinary students and members of the faculty and staff host this annual event that provides a chance for those interested to get a closer look at veterinary medicine. We invite you to tour our college and learn more about our facilities, our equipment, and what we do everyday.

Students, faculty members, and staff will be on hand to answer your questions about a career as a veterinarian, a veterinary technician, or an animal care specialist. Careers in veterinary medicine have traditionally involved working with dogs, cats, cows, horses, sheep, and pigs. However, this rapidly growing field also provides opportunities to work in the animal health industry, government, armed forces and with many other species in zoos, wildlife refuges, and developing countries.

PLEASE NOTE:   	PERSONAL PETS ARE NOT ALLOWED AT OPEN HOUSE

SCHEDULE OF ACTIVITIES

Events, Demos, and Tours (Times to be announced) 
Camelids (Alpacas and Camel) 
Virtual Hospital Tours and Admissions Presentations: (James Law Auditorium) 
Ultrasound demos throughout the day 
Equine Treadmill 
Canine Agility 
Animal Pathology (Learn gross anatomy)
Tour the Animal Health Diagnostic Center
Tour the New Teaching Dairy Barn (you will need to provide your own transportation to the dairy-maps available in Large Animal breezeway)

Exhibits (Exhibits will be open from 10am-4pm)
We will have a wide range of exhibits for you to enjoy, many back by popular demand!

Visit the petting zoo and play with baby farm animals. 
Explore exhibits with exotic pets and wildlife. 
Learn how to milk a cow. 
Discover more about the anatomy of your pets. 
Watch students perform an ultrasound on a dogs. 
Dress up in surgical scrubs and have your photo taken as a veterinary surgeon. 
Visit Teddy Bear ER, where we will surgically repair your wounded stuffed animals* with TLC. 
See a demonstration of our state of the art performance treadmill used to study orthopedic and cardiovascular diseases of horses. 
Watch as our expert farrier fabricate horse shoes throughout the day. 
There is much, much more, so please stop by and join the fun!

*PLEASE BRING YOUR OWN INJURED STUFFED ANIMAL FOR TEDDY BEAR ER. WE ARE UNABLE TO PROVIDE YOU WITH STUFFED ANIMALS FOR SURGERY

2014 Lecture Schedule- Lectures are family friendly and last 20-30 minutes

11:00am  Dr. Morrisey  "Choosing the Right Exotic Pet for You"

1:00pm Dr. Schoeffler "Pet First Aid-What to Do When You Can't Reach a Vet"

2:00pm  Dr. Barr and Dr. MacQueen " Lyme Disease-Human and Dog Concerns"

3:00pm Dr. Parks "Raptor Talk" 
2014 Open House Demonstration Schedule
K9 Police Demos:11:00am, 12:00pm and 1:30pm 
K9 Agility Demos: 10:30am, 11:30am, 2:00pm and 3:00pm 
Wildlife Center Wing Taping
Acupuncture: 10:30am, 11:30pm, 1:30pm, 2:30pm 
Animal Health Diagnositc Center( AHDC) Tours:10:15am,	11:00am, 1:00pm, 1:45pm (Tours will meet in the Atrium.  Please note that AHDC tours will be limited to 15 people per tour. Children under 15 will not be allowed to participate in AHDC tours for safety reasons
Farrier Shop Demos: 11:00am, 12:00pm , and 1:30pm 
Horse Treadmill : 10:30am, 11:30am, 2:00pm, 3:00pm 
Teaching Dairy Barn Tour (you will need to provide your own transportation to the dairy-maps available in Large Animal breezeway)

Admissions Information and Veterinary Career Sessions

For those interested in applying to the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, as well as for those who just want to know more about veterinary education and careers in veterinary medicine, there will be admissions and veterinary career information sessions throughout the day at the following times:

Admission Presentations and Student Panels
11:00 am, 1:30pm
Virtual Hospital Tours 
10:15am, 12:15pm, 2:15pm
Location: James Law Auditorium
Friends and Family are welcome

DIRECTIONS
Our doors will open at 10:00 am. Open House lasts until 4:00 pm. Parking and admission are free. Donations are accepted.

The Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine is at the intersection of Route 366 and Tower Road in Ithaca, New York. Open House visitors should park in the large "O" parking lot just off Tower Road and enter the college through the Veterinary Education Center doors under the open house banner.

From the north: take Route 34 South to Route 13 South to Ithaca; turn onto Buffalo Street; turn right onto Albany Street, turn left onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the northeast: take Route 13 South towards Ithaca; turn left onto Route 366 (by NYSEG); turn right onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the south: take Route 13 North to Ithaca; turn right onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the east: take Route 79 West to Ithaca, turn right onto Pine Tree Road; continue until 4-way stop sign; turn right onto Route 366; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the west: take Route 79 East, Route 96 South, or Route 89 South to Ithaca; after you cross the inlet bridge, turn right onto Fulton (one-way street); at the Route 13/Meadow Street intersection, continue straight across onto Clinton Street; turn left onto Albany Street; turn right onto Green Street; Green Street turns into State Street and continues to be Route 79 East; continue up State Street; bear left onto Mitchell Street; bear left onto Ithaca Street; turn right onto Route 366; turn left onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

For more information:
Contact Cindy Ryan in the Office of Student and Academic Services
Phone: 607-253-3700 Email: cr227@cornell.edu

description:
Love animals? Love music? Like both?
Come to our annual DeeDee Arrison Holistic & Integrative Wellness Seminar Series! All are welcome.

Saturday, October 19, 2013

9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
Complimentary Admission for All 
Veterinary Education Center 
College of Veterinary Medicine
Cornell University 


Seminars begin at 9am in the Murray Lecture Hall. Concert begins at 1:30 in the Atrium; well-behaved pets are welcome. Last talk starts at 2:30.

See the Full Schedule and the event's history: http://www.vet.cornell.edu/news/DeeDeeArrison2013.cfm



About the presenter:
Steve Marsden, DVM, ND, MSOM, Lac, DiplCH, AHG 
Steve is one of the chief educators of veterinarians worldwide in the use of complementary and alternative therapies. He regularly lectures for the International Veterinary Acupuncture Society, the American Holistic Veterinary Medical Association, and the American Veterinary Medical Association. He has been a guest speaker for veterinary courses, colleges, and associations spanning five continents, and is co-founder of the College of Integrative Veterinary Therapies, an Australia-based institution offering distance learning programs in integrative medicine. He is also a director of the National College of Natural Medicine, a fully accredited and leading educational institution in the United States offering comprehensive training in a diversity of alternative therapies for physicians. His textbook, Manual of Natural Veterinary Medicine, published by Elsevier in 2003, has been translated into multiple languages, and is a leading resource worldwide. Dr. Marsden is extensively trained in alternative medicine, receiving one of the first Master’s of Science degrees in Oriental Medicine ever to be awarded in North America, as well as board certifications in Chinese herbology, acupuncture and naturopathic medicine. When not teaching, he divides his time equally between veterinary and naturopathic medical practice in Edmonton, Alberta.

 

About the Performers
With his adventuresome spirit and vast musical gifts, violinist Tim Fain has emerged as a mesmerizing new presence on the music scene. The “charismatic young violinist with a matinee idol profile, strong musical instincts, and first rate chops” (Boston Globe) was featured as the sound of Richard Gere’s violin in Bee Season. Selected as one of Symphony magazine’s “Up-and-Coming Young Musicians of 2006,” and a StradMagazine 2007 “Pick of Up and Coming Musicians,” Fain has recently captured the Avery Fisher Career Grant and a Young Concert Artists International Award. As The Washington Post recently raved, “Fain has everything he needs for a first-rate career.”

International Violinist Yi-Jia Susanne Hou is the first ever violinist to capture 3 Gold Medals with unanimous Juries at 3 International Violin Competitions: Concours International Long-Thibaud (France, 1999), Lipizer International Violin Competition (Italy, 1999) and Sarasate International Violin Competition (Spain, 1997.) Hou has collaborated with world-renowned Directors and Artists such as Mstislav Rostropovich, Pinchas Zukerman, Alan Gilbert, Cho Liang Lin, Vladimir Spivakov, Marcello Viotti, Marek Janowski, Lan Shui, Boris Brott, Robert McDuffie, Ralph Kirschbaum, Lawrence Dutton, Joseph Kalichstein, Alain Trudel, Bernhard Gueller, Gregory Vajda, Ling Tung, and Li Xin Cao, among others.

Pianist Robert Koenig has quickly established a reputation as a much sought-after collaborative pianist and chamber musician. He performs regularly in major centers throughout the world with many of this generation’s most renowned musicians. Recent engagements have included performances at Carnegie Hall in New York, The Kennedy Center in Washington, DC, Suntory Hall in Tokyo, The Concertgebuow in Amsterdam, and the Louvre Museum in Paris. He has performed with many of today’s leading artists including Sarah Chang, Hilary Hahn, Pamela Frank, Roberto Diaz, Elmar Oliveira, and Aaron Rosand.

 

Reserve Your Seat

Please register early by contacting Tracey Friedrichsen (tjc25@cornell.edu / 607-253-3779) by October 10, 2013.

description:
Cornell veterinary students and clinical faculty will join volunteer alumni and offer their third daylong animal wellness clinic in Queens at the Cross Island YMCA at 238-10 Hillside Avenue Bellerose, NY 11426.

The Southside Healthy Pet Clinic will offer subsidized veterinary care for dogs and cats on October 13, 2012, from 12:00 PM to 5:00 PM. 

During the event, students -- under the supervision of veterinarians -- will provide the following services:

-Physical Exams
-Vaccines
-One year supply of heartworm, flea, tick, and internal parasite prevention

Owners are required to bring proof of rabies vaccination for pets over four months of age and to bring all pets on leashes or in carriers. 

The visit will cost $20, with proceeds from the event going to the Cross Island YMCA, located at 238-10 Hillside Avenue Bellerose, NY 11426. For an additional fee of $15, students will offer pet micro-chipping.

Although walk-ins will be accommodated as possible, pet owners are strongly encouraged to make appointments. Call 347-620-4738 (347-620-4PET) or send an email message to cuhealthypetclinic@gmail.com with times you are available.

-----

More info: http://www.vet.cornell.edu/services/southside.cfm

-----

This event is part of the College's Southside Well-Pet Clinic. Founded in 1996 at the Southside Community Center (a nonprofit organization dedicated to celebrating African American culture), the Southside Healthy Pet Clinic is a monthly walk-in clinic that is run by veterinary students from the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine and provides health-care for about 500 pets annually in an under-privileged section of our community. Through the collaboration of students, faculty, and veterinarians in the surrounding area, the Southside program provides routine veterinary care for pets owned by families whose income is less than twice the national poverty level. Clients pay a nominal fee for the services provided. This income is invested in the Southside Community Center’s programs – not the Healthy Pet Clinic.

description:
www.vet.cornell.edu/services/healthypetbrooklyn.cfm

Preventive veterinary care for pets can be expensive. With that in mind, students, alumni, and faculty from Cornell University's College of Veterinary Medicine invite pet owners who are struggling financially to the Cornell Healthy Pet Clinic in Brooklyn.

May 5, 2012

Visits for Large Dogs: 8 - 11 and 12 - 3

Visits for Cats / Small Dogs (beagle-size dogs): 1 - 5


Bedford-Stuyvesant YMCA
1121 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11216
www.ymcanyc.org 

http://facebook.com/ymcanyc 
 

Pet visits will cost owners $20 per pet, and all proceeds will go to the YMCA. Owners will be required to present proof of rabies vaccination for all adult dogs and cats (animals over the age of four months).


Although walk-ins will be accommodated as possible, pet owners are strongly encouraged to make appointments.  Call 347-620-4738 (347-620-4PET) or send an email message to cuhealthypetclinic@gmail.com with times you are available. Please list the widest possible window of time to increase your likelihood of getting an appointment. Your appointment will be confirmed with a return email or call. If you don't hear back within 48 hours, please contact us again.


Healthy pet visits will include the following:

-Full physical exam
-Heartworm testing (dogs)
-FeLV/FIV/heartworm testing (cats)
-Vaccinations
-1-year supply of heartworm/flea preventative, basic worming medication



Microchips will be available for an additional $15.
Referrals are available for spay/neuter services through the ASPCA.

Please note that this is a healthy pet clinic.

If your pet is suffering from an illness, we ask that you make an appointment with a local veterinarian, as we will not be able to diagnose or treat ill pets.

Join us in support of the Patient Assistance Fund to benefit pets at the Cornell University Hospital for Animals who might otherwise go without medical care due to financial considerations. 

In the changing economic times, many of CUHA’s clients have found it difficult to afford quality medical care for their animal companions, both large and small. These clients are forced to forgo necessary diagnostic procedures and life saving treatments for their animals. To assist clients and patients in need, CUHA has created the Patient Assistance Fund. The Patient Assistance Fund benefits our clients with economic need to help cover medical and surgical costs for their animal companions.

Center at the College of Veterinary Medicine on

Your registration fee gets you to the starting

Cornell University Hospital for Animals. Hosted by SCAVMA.

description:
The students, faculty, and staff of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine invite you, your family and friends to our 46th annual Open House.

Open House is our opportunity to share the joys of our profession with the community. Veterinary students and members of the faculty and staff host this annual event that provides a chance for those interested to get a closer look at veterinary medicine. We invite you to tour our college and learn more about our facilities, our equipment, and what we do everyday.

Students, faculty members, and staff will be on hand to answer your questions about a career as a veterinarian, a veterinary technician, or an animal care specialist. Careers in veterinary medicine have traditionally involved working with dogs, cats, cows, horses, sheep, and pigs. However, this rapidly growing field also provides opportunities to work in the animal health industry, government, armed forces and with many other species in zoos, wildlife refuges, and developing countries.


SCHEDULE OF ACTIVITIES
 

Events, Demos, and Tours

Camelids (Alpacas and Chewy the Camel) 
Virtual Hospital Tours and Admissions Presentations: (James Law Auditorium) 
Ultrasound demos throughout the day 
Equine Treadmill 
Canine Agility 
Police Dog demonstration 
Animal Pathology "Show-and-Tell" (Learn gross anatomy and what happens when organ systems fail)

 

EXHIBITS
We will have a wide range of exhibits for you to enjoy, many back by popular demand!

Visit the petting zoo and play with baby farm animals. 
Explore exhibits with exotic pets and wildlife. 
Learn how to milk a cow. 
Discover more about the anatomy of your pets. 
Watch students perform an ultrasound on a dog's heart. 
Dress up in surgical scrubs and have your photo taken as a veterinary surgeon. 
Visit Teddy Bear ER, where we will surgically repair your wounded stuffed animals with TLC. 
See a demonstration of our state of the art performance treadmill used to study orthopedic and cardiovascular diseases of horses. 
Watch as our expert farrier fabricate horse shoes throughout the day. 
There is much, much more, so please stop by and join the fun!
2012 Lecture Schedule
Topics will include public health issues, zoonotic diseases, pet emergencies and first-aid.



Admissions Information and Veterinary Career Sessions

For those interested in applying to the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, as well as for those who just want to know more about veterinary education and careers in veterinary medicine, there will be admissions and veterinary career information sessions throughout the day at the following times:

Admission Presentations and Student Panels

10:30am, 12:30pm, 2:30pm
Virtual Hospital Tours 
11:30am, 1:30pm, 3:30pm
Location: James Law Auditorium
Friends and Family are welcome


DIRECTIONS:

Our doors will open at 10:00 am. Open House lasts until 4:00 pm. Parking and admission are free.

The Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine is at the intersection of Route 366 and Tower Road in Ithaca, New York. Open House visitors should park in the large "O" parking lot just off Tower Road and enter the college through the Veterinary Education Center doors under the open house banner.

From the north: take Route 34 South to Route 13 South to Ithaca; turn onto Buffalo Street; turn right onto Albany Street, turn left onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the northeast: take Route 13 South towards Ithaca; turn left onto Route 366 (by NYSEG); turn right onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the south: take Route 13 North to Ithaca; turn right onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the east: take Route 79 West to Ithaca, turn right onto Pine Tree Road; continue until 4-way stop sign; turn right onto Route 366; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the west: take Route 79 East, Route 96 South, or Route 89 South to Ithaca; after you cross the inlet bridge, turn right onto Fulton (one-way street); at the Route 13/Meadow Street intersection, continue straight across onto Clinton Street; turn left onto Albany Street; turn right onto Green Street; Green Street turns into State Street and continues to be Route 79 East; continue up State Street; bear left onto Mitchell Street; bear left onto Ithaca Street; turn right onto Route 366; turn left onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

For more information:

Contact Cindy Ryan in the Office of Student and Academic Services
Phone: 607-253-3700 Email: cr227@cornell.edu

http://www.vet.cornell.edu/openhouse/

description:
Please join us at a seminar presented by the Medical Genetics Service of the College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University.

Complimentary admission, lunch and food will be provided. Attendees receive complimentary puppy packs courtesy of Merial.

The seminar will present you with cutting-edge clinical advances for inherited canine/feline diseases to improve the quality of your companion animals' lives and guide you in making informed and successful breeding decisions. 

We will feature several Cornell veterinary specialists, including Dr.s Sydney Moise and Bruce Kornreich (cardiology), Dr.s Rory Todhunter and Ursula Krotscheck (orthopedics), Dr.s Margaret McEntee and Kelly Hume (oncology), and Dr. Marta Castelhano (medical genetics) along with Dr. Margret Casal, University of Pennsylvania's specialist in pediatrics, veterinary genetics, and reproduction.

Please RSVP by January 13th at dnabank@cornell.edu.

description: What can a Black/queer analytic offer to our experiences, articulations, and speculations about the conditions of life--and of death-- in the Anthropocene? Emerging narratives about the Anthropocene mobilize ideas about the human, the person, and the body that often universalize rather than particularize, occluding the fact that, for example, in the Americas, access to these categorizations has long been shot through with histories of normative violence. In this talk I consider the ways that visible and less-than-visible violences continue to be visited upon Black bodies in this hemisphere. I ask: how might Black experience with perishment offer a rubric for thinking futurity, including reproductive futurity, in a moment of environmental collapse? Plumbing toxicities that are at once material and experiential, historical and contemporary, I propose that contemporary thinking about life and liveliness in this epoch must be fundamentally refigured by bodies that have always-already been enmeshed with commodity chains-- by the endurance of Black life in an ever-toxic world.

venue.about: FGSS studies a wide range of fields from the perspectives of feminist and LGBTQIA critical analysis in global and local contexts to promote social justice.
venue.name: Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies

name: After the End of the World: Black/Queer Life & the Anthropocene

description: Karen Jaime (Latina/o Studies & Performing and Media Arts, Cornell Univ) will deliver the 2016-17 Rabinor Lecture in American Studies. This talk examines how poet and performer Emanuel Xavier’s “Glam Slam,” an event held at the Nuyorican Poets Café then in London, brought together the competitive spoken word/slam poetry and Harlem drag ball communities. Through the “Glam Slam,” Xavier made visible socially, politically, and economically marginalized queer communities of color in New York City.

description:
Welcome to the 7th annual Winter Village Music Festival.  While at a new time, Winter Village presents the same eclectic blend of progressive acoustic music – bluegrass, old time & swing with an infusion of celtic music to celebrate the St. Patricks Day season.  

This year’s featured performers are the Jeremy Kittel Trio, The Barefoot Movement and 10 String Symphony.  They will be joined by local favorites Paris Texas (Bobby & Doug Henrie and Rick Manning), Suitcase (Judy Hyman & Jeff Claus), and downstate friends Too Blue.  Winter Village features four concerts in the La Tourelle Music Hall, a small 150 seat venue with great sightlines and sound. 

During the day there will be instrumental and singing workshops and, like any bluegrass festival, jamming throughout the day and night (yes, there is a quiet wing).  Enjoy great food and drink all weekend at the Bistro and 2 bars. 

La Tourelle is a fine place to spend a musical winter weekend – JOIN US!

description:
Join Ithaca Children’s Garden (ICG) and Title Sponsor CFCU Community Credit Union (CFCU) as they present the fifth annual Tough Turtle adventure obstacle race. Tough Turtle is Ithaca’s original  adventure obstacle course race, fostering team spirit, building community, and supporting a critical local cause: inspiring the next generation of environmental stewards. 

The 5th annual Tough Turtle celebrates the milestone anniversary with a daring 10K option and even more unique and challenging obstacles. Also new this year is a finish line festival sponsored by CTB/Ithaca Bakery and Ithaca Beer, complete with exciting raffle prizes for our top FundRACER’s, food and beverage, live entertainment, games, and more.

As always, the Tough Turtle course will be designed to challenge competitive thrill seekers, families, and participants of all ages and experience levels. Racers will climb, sprint, crawl, and slide through obstacle course along the Cayuga Waterfront and Black Diamond Trails on the south shore of Cayuga Lake.  Children not old enough to participate in the main Tough Turtle course will enjoy an equally thrilling and age-appropriate Tough Turtle Junior course, which does not require advance registration.

Thanks to our generous sponsors, every dollar raised through Tough Turtle registration and FundRACING goes directly to support ICG’s mission of inspiring environmental stewardship. In fact, critical funds raised during Tough Turtle support direct programming that reaches 8,200 children and families annually, and keeps the Garden free and open to the 69,000 visitors each year!  

To register yourself or a team, sign up to volunteer, or learn about sponsorship opportunities, visit www.toughturtleithaca.com. 

Event registration IS OPEN! Spaces are limited and this race fills up quickly. Contact Event Director Elaine Springer,  eventdirector@toughturtleithaca.com, 706-371-4034 with any questions regarding sponsorship, registration, and volunteering or to schedule an interview.

description: CTB on North Aurora St. is proud to welcome Marika Chew as our local artist. Marika is an artist based in the Ithaca area. She received a BFA in Illustration from the Maryland Institute College of Art in 2010. Her work is inspired by art nouveau motifs and world textile designs and often features animals from the local area and beyond. She works primarily in watercolor with occasional touches of gouache. Her work is for sale at local craft shows and shops and at her Etsy Store. When not making art, or catching up on sleep after a long night of making art, Marika spends any remaining free time reading as many books as possible. There will be complementary coffee and refreshments for all of Marika's guests.

description:
The College Ave Celebratory Cider Series Three fall cider tastings one great location - October 5th, 2016 4:30-7:30pm

Pucker up! 2 Cider Tastings @ CTB 4:30-6pm

Wednesday October 5th Collegetown Bagels will be hosting a Free Hard Cider Tasting From 4:30-6pm at the College Avenue Location featuring Hand-Pressed Hard Cider by McKenzie's on the Patio along with games and prize giveaways. The original cider is reminiscent of its UK predecessors, refreshing, medium body and not too dry with a crisp apple finish. 
Also look forward to refreshing Red Jacket Orchards tastings (Non-alcoholic apple juice blends) created on the north end of Seneca Lake in the heart of the Finger Lakes.

Followed by Hazlitt’s Hard Cider Tasting @ Rulloffs 6-7:30pm

This Wednesday October 5th come try samplings of Hazlitt's Cider Tree from 6:00 -7:30pm at Rulloff’s Historic Bar and Restaurant. Available on draft Cider Tree is  a crisp, pure, and even gluten-free beverage that is perfect to celebrate the start of fall! Tasting next door to the College Ave CTB at Rulloff's Bar & Restaurant.

Visit our event at http://www.ciderweekflx.com/locations/

description:
Through out the spring CTB is hosting a weekly education and tasting series featuring different brews showcased at Collegetown Bagels.  This Week head to the College Ave bar 3-5pm) to find out a little more about craft brewing from Troegs.  You can get creative with some adult coloring or just taste and learn.

Troges is famous in this area for their Nugget Nectar of the Gods! "It’s impossible to forget your first squeeze. Once a year, as the newest humulus lupulus harvest arrives at Tröegs, we blend these super-fresh hops into an Imperial Amber Ale. Excessively dry-hopped, Nugget Nectar is an explosion of pine, resin and mango."  

Learn about more tasty brews and try a few . . .Can't make it till late?  This tasting & art event moves to @Rulloff's 5-8pm

Upcoming Beer Series Tastes: https://www.facebook.com/collegetownbagels/events

description:
This year, HEC explored change: while shifts in the industry can be unexpected or uncertain, every organization has to evolve to maintain its competitive advantage, while still honoring the values that made them successful in the past. This year’s program cuts through the anxieties of change and looks at how HEC, the Hotel School, and the hospitality industry as a whole can maintain their identities—and value—as they navigate the ever-changing business environment.

description:
Get involved with the best and oldest Hotelie tradition! Attend one (or more) of our department-specific info sessions for HEC 92. Whether this is your first year with Hotel Ezra Cornell or you're an HEC veteran, be sure to attend to learn more about each department and available positions.

Feel free to attend any of the following sessions that you are interested in:

Culinary: Monday, 9/12, 4:30 PM - Statler 391
 
Human Resources: Monday, 9/12, 4:30 PM - HEC office (on the ground floor of SHA, across the bathrooms next to Macs Cafe)
 
Operations: Tuesday, 9/13, 4:30 PM - 5:30pm - Collegetown Bagels and Wednesday, 9/14 3:45 PM - 5:00pm - Macs (These are open drop-in sessions, stop by when you can!)
 
Service: Tuesday, 9/13, 4:30 PM - Statler 351 
 
Marketing, Communications & IT: Tuesday, 9/13, 5:00 PM - Statler 351

Finance & Donor Relations, Purchasing & Sustainability: Thursday, 9/15, 5:30 PM - Statler 396
 
Design: if you were unable to attend Venus's information session, feel free to email her at vt97@cornell.edu
 
Sales: Friday, 9/16, 4:30 PM - Statler 196 
 
Beverage: if you were unable to attend Allison's information session, feel free to email her at amh375@cornell.edu 
 
Rooms, Program: Friday, 9/16, 3:30 PM - Statler 398

We hope to see you there!

description:
Witness the famous Hotelie tradition!

“The new normal” is finally here, and we want you to join us as we define it during our incredible series of program events! 

Although industry fundamentals are stronger than ever, unprecedented change is coming. Our program will touch on several issues that are giving rise to this powerful phenomenon: real estate, social media, cybersecurity, diversity, ultraluxury, food & beverage, entrepreneurship, and more.

All program events are open to the public—students, faculty, staff, alumni, and other visitors. No registration required!

Learn more by visiting www.hotelezracornell.com.
Don’t forget to download the official HEC 91 mobile app and keep all the up-to-date information about events and speakers at your fingertips (just search “Hotel Ezra Cornell” on the app store).

Thursday, March 17

Starbucks Reserve Coffee Tasting
Thursday, March 17, 4:30-5:30 PM, Statler Amphitheater

Friday, March 18
The Dean’s Address
Friday, March 18, 8:45-9:00 AM, Statler Auditorium
Michael D. Johnson, The Bradley H. Stone Dean and E.M. Statler Professor, School of Hotel Administration

Cornell College of Business: An Update and Q&A with Acting President Kotlikoff
Friday, March 18, 9:00-9:30 AM, Statler Auditorium
Michael Kotlikoff, Acting President, Cornell University

Keeping Up with the New Consumer
Friday, March 18, 9:30-10:30 AM, Statler Auditorium
Hospitality companies are forming or transforming to answer the call of the evolving consumer, who is approaching travel in a whole new way.
Wrede Petersmeyer, Airbnb
Francis Davidson, Flatbook
Hari Nair, MMH ‘02, Expedia
Kevin Jacobs ‘94, Hilton Worldwide
Kit Pappas, Capella Hotel Group
Moderator: Kelly McGuire, MMH ’01, PhD ’07, Wyndham Destination Networks
 
The Evolution of Diversity
Friday, March 18, 11:00-11:45 AM, Statler Auditorium
With Millennials dominating the workforce, organizational diversity looks increasingly different from years past.
Lucida Plummer, Wyndham Worldwide
Victor Younger, School of Hotel Administration
 
Demystifying the Digital Marketplace
Friday, March 18, 1:00-1:30 PM, Statler Auditorium
With the emergence of new third-party intermediaries that help hotels find customers, the industry is searching for new ways to analyze distribution that will positively impact the bottom line.
Cindy Estis Green ‘79, Kalibri Labs
 
The New Normal of Luxury
Friday, March 18, 1:30-2:30 PM, Statler Auditorium
Ultraluxury hotels are growing as this new dimension in fine service gains traction.
Horst Schulze, Capella Hotel Group 
 
Growth in the Face of Volatility: Preparing for Disruption in Hotel Real Estate
Friday, March 18, 2:45-3:45 PM, Statler Auditorium
While the U.S. lodging industry is experiencing tremendous RevPAR growth and all-time high occupancy rates, investors around the world face challenges that are changing the investment landscape for hotel real estate.
Stephen G. Haggerty ’90, Hyatt Hotels Corporation
Tracey Gamble ’99, Apollo Global Management LLC
Michael Goodson, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority
Moderator: Arthur Adler ’78, JLL

Saturday, March 19
 
Social Media “Power Hour”
Saturday, March 19, 8:45-9:45 AM, Statler Auditorium
Social media has great influence over consumer decisions, and businesses need to leverage this tool in their favor.
The Hospitality #DATA Explosion
Marty Weintraub, aimClear Marketing Agency
Bringing the Guests Social Experience to the Big Screen (…or to the Small One)
Tim Sae Koo & Quinn Cox ‘15, TINT
 
Trends in Food & Beverage: 2016 Edition
Saturday, March 19, 10:00-11:00 AM, Statler Auditorium
Establishments adopting a few revolutionizing trends in the food & beverage industry are rising to the top and leaving others struggling at the bottom.
Drew Nieporent ’77, Myriad Restaurant Group
Jeannette Ho (via videoconference), Fairmont Raffles Hotels International
Jeff Zalaznick ’05, Major Food Group
Abby Murtagh ’92, Waldorf Astoria New York
Moderator: Damian Mogavero, Avero
 
Cybersecurity and Beyond: How to Take on the Virtual Enemy
Saturday, March 19, 11:30 AM-12:15 PM, Statler Auditorium
Cyber crime is rampant, and the industry must protect itself from this “face-less” danger.
Amitava “Chats” Chatterjee, MMH ‘00, Deloitte Digital
David Hogan, Heartland Payment Systems
Alexander Stout, Latham & Watkins LLP
Moderator: Jules Sieburgh ‘72, Jules A. Sieburgh LLC

#BayClubHappy: Developing a Formal Internship Program
Saturday, March 19, 1:30-2:00 PM, Statler Amphitheater

A 360° Look at the Hospitality Data Universe: A Hands-on Session
Saturday, March 19, 1:30-2:00 PM, Statler Binenkorb Computer Lab

Cornell Hospitality Business Plan Competition
Saturday, March 19, 2:00-4:30 PM, Statler Auditorium

Hotelies Thinking Big: Entrepreneurial Student Showcase
Saturday, March 19, 4:00-5:00 PM, Taylor/Rowe Room (Taverna Banfi)

description:
Sitting around his kitchen table nearly 30 years ago, drinking whiskey and coke with some friends, James Quest was struck with a brilliant idea. He realized that he could save himself the trouble of mixing a drink if he could make a true, distilled liquor, with the drinkability of Cola. The most ubiquitous taste in America - cola - had never been offered as a high-proof spirit. James set out on a mission to craft a perfect All-American Liqueur with the kick of a shot of whiskey and the smooth drinkability of an ice cold glass of cola.

31 years later, with the help of his grandson Aidan, James' dream has become a reality and he would love to share it with you.

Come try Colabolt with some special deals this Thursday at Loco!

$3 COLABOLT SHOTS

$4 COLABOLT LONG ISLANDS

$4 COLABOLT MIXED DRINKS

name: Bring a Friend

description:
This challenge will test your overall levels of strength. The 6 weeks will be designed to increase your strength in the bench press, pullup, front squat, and deadlift!

The first and last weeks will be test out weeks - you will have 6 weeks to work on increasing your numbers for the test out. Whoever makes the most gains will win a FREE month!

Email us at valorsandc@gmail.com or fill out the form here: www.valorsandc.com/contact

Members and Non-members are welcome.

Invite someone who you think would benefit!

description:
If you are looking to get in shape, you have to start by getting stronger. There is no way around it. Strength is the base for all other movements and is necessary to gain lean muscle, increase cardiovascular endurance, and burn fat. The goal is to develop functional strength and speed, increase lean muscle mass, and develop the fast twitch muscle fibers. EVERYONE needs to be strong.

http://www.valorsandc.com/events/6weeksofstrength

This challenge is designed for busy dads who hate to veggies all day to lose weight and don't want time to spend hours on end at the gym.

You will look and feel like a former version of yourself, we GUARNTEE it, or your money back!!

description:
Having trouble getting rid of the stubborn fat around your mid-section? Having trouble staying motivated? Going on summer vacation and want to look and feel your best?

This challenge is exactly what you need!

Members and non-members will form a team of three to compete in the 6 week challenge. The teams will consist of either two members and one non-member or one member and two non-member. The winning team will be decided based upon inches/weight lost, performance gains, AND consistency. This is open to both males and females of all ages!

Please go to http://www.valorsandc.com/6-week-summer-slimdown-team-transformation-challenge/ and sign up there. 

An email will be sent back to you with confirmation of your team and your participation. The email will also state the rules and guidelines for the challenge, as well as how the challenge will be judged.

description:

There is no fee to participate; however we are suggesting a $10 donation to The Lone Survivor Foundation. The link to donate is below. 

http://lsf2014.kintera.org/valorsandc

If you cannot attend, you are still able to make a donation by following the link. 

The workout will be held at our facility located at 478 Lower Creek Road in Ithaca NY 14850 and will start promptly at 9AM. The workout can be modified for those who do not wish to do the full Murph workout.

name: Open House

description:
All are invited to join a panel discussion on the effort in New York State to legalize physician-assisted suicide, followed by a screening of “How to Die in Oregon”, a film that explores what it truly means to die with dignity.  Currently in New York, aiding a person’s suicide attempt is a class E felony.

Location: Myron Taylor Hall, 184 524 College Avenue, 6-9PM

Panelists Include:

Dennis Vacco, Esq., former New York State Attorney General, in case of Vacco v. Quill Dennis successfully argued that Physician Assisted Suicide was not a constitutionally protected right.

Timothy E. Quill, M.D., Professor of Medicine, Psychiatry, and Medical Humanities at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry and Director of the Center for Ethics, Humanities and Palliative Care.

Professor Daryl Bem, Emeritus Professor of Psychology at Cornell University and husband of the late Sandra Bem.  Read Sandra Bem’s story here: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/17/magazine/the-last-day-of-her-life.html?_r=1

Father Daniel T. McMullin, Sacramental Minister, Associate Director of CURW at Cornell University.

Cynthia Grant Bowman, Dorothea S. Clarke Professor of Law at Cornell Law School.

Moderator: Jill Miller, Adjunct Professor of Law and Director of the Estate Planning Clinic at Cornell University, principal of Jill Miller & Associates, P.C.

venue.about: The official Facebook page for Cornell University Law School - Lawyers in the Best Sense
venue.name: Cornell Law School

name: “Death with Dignity” Legislation Discussion Plus a Screening of “How to Die in Oregon”

description: Register for an online Q&A session with Chuck Whitehead, Director, Law, Technology, and Entrepreneurship Program. He will provide insight into our one-of-a-kind Law Tech LL.M. program. Based at Cornell Tech’s innovative New York City campus, this one-year, full-time LL.M. degree is designed for practicing lawyers or recent graduates who want to be at the intersection of law, technology, and entrepreneurship. The hands-on and cross-disciplinary Law Tech curriculum will provide students with the cutting-edge lawyering skills and business acumen necessary to support and lead technology companies.

venue.about: The official Facebook page for Cornell University Law School - Lawyers in the Best Sense

description:
More than 750,000 young immigrants who arrived in the United States as children and are protected by the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy now face possible policy changes from a new presidential administration.

In an effort to clarify possible new practices, four Cornell administrators and faculty members will address the facts and uncertainty in a panel discussion, “Immigration Chaos: DACA Students and Higher Education Grapple With Upheaval,” Friday, March 17, at noon in Kennedy Hall’s David L. Call Alumni Auditorium.

The event is free and open to all.
Panelists will discuss the impact of immigration policy on DACA at the higher education, local and national levels. They are:

Barbara Knuth, senior vice provost and dean of the Graduate School, who administers undergraduate enrollment through the Undergraduate Admissions Office and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment, and serves on the University Diversity Council;  
                           
Carlos M. Gonzalez, executive director, Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives, who oversees key central academic support programs and grants, with a primary focus on academic success for underrepresented students of color, first generation, low-income and undocumented students;

Barbara Knuth, senior vice provost and dean of the Graduate School, who administers undergraduate enrollment through the Undergraduate Admissions Office and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment, and serves on the University Diversity Council;

Estelle McKee, clinical professor of law, who co-teaches Cornell Law School’s Asylum and Convention Against Torture Appellate Clinic, and has worked as an immigration attorney; and

Vijay Pendakur, the Robert W. and Elizabeth C. Staley Dean of Students.

The panel will be moderated by Rebecca Stoltzfus, vice provost for undergraduate education and professor of nutritional sciences.
President Barack Obama signed DACA in 2012 to protect undocumented children brought to the United States. Recent immigration actions by the Trump administration have created uncertainty about the future of the DACA program.

The panel discussion is presented by the Division of University Relations’ Diversity Council.

description:
This free, two-part program will explore the work of two environmentally conscious artists in anticipation of Ithaca's March for Science on Earth Day 2017.
https://www.facebook.com/events/1666981656927518/

“Bus Talk” at 4:30PM: Board the MossLab, the renovated RV parked in front of the Museum. Spearheaded by Marion Wilson of Syracuse University, the MossLab (or MLAB—Mobile Literacy Arts Bus) has traveled up and down the eastern seaboard with the aim of creating an archive of native mosses. Join Wilson to learn about artistic observation and drawing of native mosses, including those contained in the Museum’s own Morgan Garden.  

“Gallery Talk” at 5:15PM: Simon Norfolk’s "Stratographs" series of photographs visualize the receding Lewis Glacier on Mt. Kenya, the second highest mountain in Africa. Seven prints from this series are currently on view at the Museum. Learn more at this gallery talk with Cornell's Johannes Lehmann and the Johnson's Andrea Inselmann.

The Museum will be open Thursday until 7:30PM.

description:
"Rembrandt was known for making prints as well as paintings. Because multiple impressions could be made from a copper plate, his etchings were easily distributed. Unique watermarks and other details can help date the sheet of paper. But because there are so many watermark types, identifying an unknown mark can be difficult and  time-consuming. 

Students in the spring Cornell course "Watermark Identification in Rembrandt's Etchings" have created new software to quickly identify these watermarks. At this special gallery talk, they will share their research and discuss the installation they curated of Rembrandt prints and related materials.

"Recognizing Rembrandt: The Science of Art in Printmaking" will be on view from May 11 to June 12 in the Museum's study gallery, Floor 2L.

description: Prof. Alain Giami from INSERM  (Institut National de la Santé et de la Recherche Médicale in Paris, France) will share specific stories about collecting pornography to better understand culture.  The materials he is now planning to donate to Cornell’s Human Sexuality Collection, for example, will help show how the perception of condoms and of the sexuality of people with different orientations or disabilities can be changed through the use of pornography. More generally, Giami will speak about how his collection was designed and built, both as a hobby and as a means to do research; how this kind of work with pornography was often perceived as "dirty work", and how, during his career, he has combined field-work, statistical work, and archival work.

description:
Immediately preceding the first U.S. presidential election debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Donald Trump, join campus and community members for a live academic debate at 7:30 p.m. in Bailey Hall among four prominent political scientists and policy experts on two key domestic policy issues, immigration and incarceration policy, followed by questions from the audience. Gretchen Ritter ’83, the Harold Tanner Dean of the College of Arts & Sciences, will moderate.

At 9 p.m., audience members and panelists will watch the nationally-televised presidential debate on a big screen. Doors open for the event at 6:30 p.m.

Supported by a gift from Jennifer Koen-Horowitz ’93 and Mark Horowitz, the event is free and open to the public. Free tickets are required and will be available starting Sept. 12 at Willard Straight Hall, Robert Purcell Community Center, and the Ithaca Visitors Bureau.

The debaters: 

+ Marc A. Levin, director of the Center for Effective Justice at the think tank Texas Public Policy Foundation and policy director of its Right on Crime initiative;
+ Reihan Salam, executive editor of National Review and a National Review Institute Policy fellow; 
+ Karthick Ramakrishnan, professor of public policy and political science at the University of California, Riverside;
+ Vesla Mae Weaver, associate professor of African-American studies and political science at Yale University and founding director of Yale’s Institution for Social and Policy Studies Center for the Study of Inequality.

The academic debate will appear live on CornellCast at http://www.cornell.edu/video/educate-the-vote-election-2016-debate.

In order to create a safe and enjoyable experience for all guests, all bags are subject to search upon entrance into Bailey Hall. Items such as alcohol, weapons of any kind, and other hazardous or unsafe materials will be prohibited. No food or drinks are permitted in the auditorium.

Please arrive early for security screening and plan to be seated by 7:20 p.m., at which time any open seats will be offered to those without tickets.

Event sponsors include the American Studies Program, the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future, the Center for the Study of Inequality, the College of Arts & Sciences, the College of Human Ecology, the Cornell Institute for Public Affairs, the Cornell Population Center, the Department of Policy Analysis and Management, the ILR School, the Institute for the Social Sciences, the Judith Reppy Institute for Peace and Conflict Studies, the Office of the Vice Provost, the Program on Ethics and Public Life, the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, and Student and Campus Life.

The views and opinions expressed in this debate belong to the panelists and do not reflect those of Cornell University. Cornell University does not endorse political parties or candidates.

description:
The design of responsibly built environments directly impacts the safety, operation, clinical outcomes, and financial success of healthcare facilities now and into the future.  

How does the role of patient-centered design….
intersect with evidence-based design and medicine? 
improve the user experience and patient outcomes? 
improve staff proficiency and well-being? 
impact the increasing shift from volume-based to value-based care? 
impact cost-control opportunities and initiatives? 
anticipate and integrate new technology?

Perspective from the experts: Learn from Cornell faculty and alumni shaping today’s new healthcare facilities – their design, operation, and administration.

Dick Argys ‘81 Human Ecology; CAO, Boston Children’s Hospital
Wendy Gettleman ‘87 School of Hotel Administration; VP, Facilities Management & Real Estate, Dana Farber
Brooke Hollis ’78 Sloan; Executive Director, Sloan Program in Health Administration, Human Ecology

description:
In this interactive presentation, the current science underlying connections between nutrition and healthy aging will be explored based on research from Division of Nutritional Sciences. You will also get a glimpse into what it will mean for consumers as the food industry increases its presence in the health-food market. 

The rise in nutrition-related chronic disease continues, burdening national health care systems and encouraging local governments to regulate food and beverage consumption.  Paradoxically, consumer demand for health-related products including vitamins, nutritional supplements and diet foods is robust, despite limited evidence for their effectiveness.  

Join Professor Stover as he brings you into a lively discussion on this timely topic.

description:
"School-Randomized Experiments to Improve Children’s Academic and Social-Emotional Outcomes: Lessons from U.S. and Congo"
http://events.cornell.edu/event/2013_doris_lecture_lawrence_aber

School-based interventions to improve children’s academic and social-emotional outcomes have a rich history in the U.S. and are of increasing interest in other regions of the world. This talk describes the rationale, design and results of two large school-randomized trials designed to improve both sets of outcomes. The first trial tests the efficacy of the 4Rs program in primary schools serving low-income African-American and Latino children in New York City. The second trial tests the efficacy of the OPEQ initiative (Opportunity for Equal Access to Quality Basic Education) in 144 primary schools in the eastern provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Lessons learned to date and future opportunities and challenges raised by these efforts will be discussed.

Lawrence Aber is Distinguished Professor of Applied Psychology and Public Policy at the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development, New York University, where he also serves as board chair of its Institute of Human Development and Social Change. Dr. Aber earned his Ph.D. from Yale University and an A.B. from Harvard University. He previously taught at Barnard College, Columbia University and at the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University, where he also directed the National Center for Children in Poverty. He is an internationally recognized expert in child development and social policy and has co-edited "Neighborhood Poverty: Context and Consequences for Children" (1997, Russell Sage Foundation), "Assessing the Impact of September 11th 2001 on Children Youth and Parents: Lessons for Applied Developmental Science" (2004, Erlbaum) and "Child Development and Social Policy: Knowledge for Action" (2007, APA Publications). His basic research examines the influence of poverty and violence, at the family and community levels, on the social, emotional, behavioral, cognitive and academic development of children and youth.

description:
Guest speaker, Dr. Maggie Bruck, will discuss the major scientific principles that need to be presented to the court in light of details from an actual case involving allegations of child sexual abuse. She will also discuss the court's reaction to these principles. 

Maggie Bruck is professor of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Johns Hopkins University, and holds an adjunct appointment at McGill University where she was on faculty for close to 30 years. She is an active researcher in a number of fields within the rubric of developmental psychology including 
* Language acquisition 
* Autobiographical memory 
* Reliability of children's testimony 

Her collaborative work with Dr. Stephen Ceci involving the reliability of children's testimony, has produced a number of research studies, and reports or briefs to various judges or couts, as well as a number of awards and prizes, including the William James Prize for their book entitled Jeopardy in the Courtroom.

description:
In Martha Van Rensselaer Hall, G.71 LPHD presents guest speaker, Laurence Steinberg. 
http://events.cornell.edu/event/a_social_neuroscience_perspective_on_adolescent_risk_taking 

An internationally recognized expert on psychological development during adolescence, Dr. Steinberg's research has focused on a range of topics in the study of contemporary adolescence, including adolescent brain development, risk-taking and decision-making, parent-adolescent relationships, school-year employment, high school reform, and juvenile justice.

Adolescence is a period of heightened engagement in risky and reckless behavior, including: substance use, unprotected sex, reckless driving, and criminal activity. 
In this talk, Professor Steinberg presents the results of a program of research on the underpinnings of risk-taking adolescence that is informed by recent advances in developmental neuroscience.

description:
"Why Researchers and Educators Who Don’t Play Video Games Should Care About Them"
http://events.cornell.edu/event/bctr_talks_at_twelve_andrew_jefferson

Video games are becoming increasingly pervasive in modern culture, generating excitement about their potential as educational tools. However, understanding how to productively use games as a tool for education and research can be difficult for those unfamiliar with the medium. In his talk, Andrew Jefferson will highlight the properties of video games as a medium that make them suited to education and research. He will explore these properties looking at both commercial games and academic interventions, with special attention to which advances in commercial game design are useful for educational and research projects. Finally, Mr. Jefferson will discuss the limitations of using these tools and lessons learned from previous failed projects.

Andrew Jefferson is a fifth year doctoral candidate in Human Development in the College of Human Ecology. He received his MA from Cornell (2011) for work on scientific reasoning and how people change theories in response to new information, and a BS in Neuroscience from the College of William and Mary (2007). He is currently working on his dissertation project with the ASSET program (Assisting Secondary Science Education with Tetrahymena) and an interdisciplinary team to develop an educational game for high school biology students, and study its impact on reasoning, motivation, and behavior.
Lunch will be served. Metered parking is available in the Plantations lot across the road from Beebe Hall.

Join Elaine Wethington and Rachel Dunifon for a "Chats in the Stacks" talk about their new book “Research for the Public Good: Applying the Methods of Translational Research to Improve Human Health and Well-Being” 

Helping to bridge the gaps among research, policy, and practice, their book demonstrates how emerging methods of translational research can help us develop programs and policies that improve human health and well-being. This broader, more inclusive approach to translational research has gained popularity and been promoted by the National Institutes of Health, the Centers for Disease Control, medical centers, and university programs.

description:
Sexualized violence does not just affect women. It affects the men who care about them, their families, their friends, their coworkers, and their communities. Sexualized violence is epidemic. Some of the statistics: Every two minutes someone in America is raped. One in six American women are victims of sexual assault. That means someone you know, someone you care about, has been or may become the victim of sexual violence. 

Walk a Mile in Her Shoes is a men's march to stop rape, sexual assault, and gender violence. Join Alpha Chi and help raise awareness for this cause! 

Registration is $13 if you bring your own shoes, and $17 if you'd like to rent shoes at the event. 

Registration starts at 11:30 on Ho Plaza. The walk will start at 12:15.

Breakfast will be available for those who register.

FAQ: 
- Yes, girls are more than welcome to come participate in this walk! 
- Men are not required to wear heels, but it is strongly encouraged.

description:
The Center for Jewish Living is excited to welcome Dr. Jill Katz as a Scholar in Residence the weekend of November 13th-14th. Dr. Katz is a Professor of Archaeology at Yeshiva University in New York. She teaches archaeology and anthropology, with a specialty in biblical archaeology.

Here are the talks Dr. Katz will be giving over the weekend, including the time and place:

Friday afternoon (2:00-3:00 pm; White Hall 110):
“In the Footsteps of the Philistines: 20 years of Excavations at Tell es-Safi/Gath, the Hometown of Goliath”

"Not only was Goliath a giant among men, but his hometown of Gath was nearly 10 times the size of contemporary Jerusalem.  How did this Bronze Age Canaanite city become the most important Philistine city until its destruction towards the end of the 9th century BCE? What did this mean for ancient Israel and Judah?"

Friday night after Shabbat dinner (Around 8:30 pm, 104West! Dining Hall):
“Canaanite Avodah Zarah (Idol Worship)—or What Isaac saw at Gerar”

"Parshat Toldot: 
When famine strikes, Isaac (who raises animals), heads to the big city of Gerar.  We know what happened at the palace (poor Rebecca), but what happened at the temple—an    archaeological  answer to this great mystery . . .  "
  
Shabbat (Saturday) morning after Services (11:45 am, The Center for Jewish Living):
“What’s a Kohen (Priest) Supposed to Do?: Second Temple Problems”  

Here is a little more information about Dr. Katz:

Jill Katz teaches archaeology and anthropology at Yeshiva University with a specialty in biblical archaeology. Dr. Katz has excavated at several sites in Israel, including Ashkelon, Tel Haror/Gerar, and most recently Tel es-Safi/Gath where she currently serves as Area Supervisor for Area P. Her research interests focus on the nature of Israelite leadership during the time of the Judges (Iron I period) and on emergent urban life during the time of King David (Iron IIa). She has taught many courses at Yeshiva University, including Intro to Anthropology and Biblical Archaeology. Dr. Katz earned her AB from Harvard University and her PhD from the University of Pennsylvania. 

We would like to thank our co-sponsors for helping make this event possible:
Cornellians for Israel (CFI)
Near Eastern Studies Department
Jewish Studies Department
Cornell Institute of Archaeology and Material Studies (CIAMS)
Zionist Organization of America (ZOA)

description:
Co-sponsored by the CJL and JLIC.

Join Rabbi Dr. Daniel Roth from Pardes in Jerusalem for an interactive, thought-provoking and timely exploration of one of Judaism's most quoted - and most complicated - principles.

Who are the People in Your Neighborhood?
Tensions in Applying the Golden Rule
This text-based session will explore one of the most important religious pro-social principles - loving one's neighbor as one's self - and see how it has been debated and interpreted in different ways over the generations.  We will also discuss how these conflicting interpretations may impact and reflect several of the core identity conflicts currently taking place in the US and Israel, and how text study can actually help empower us to engage more constructively in these conflicts.    

There will also be some delicious hot dogs, hamburgers, and veggie burgers.

Time and Location:
The event will be taking place at 104 West (upstairs) at 9 PM. 

Some more information about Pardes and Rabbi Dr. Roth:
The Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies is an open, co-ed and non-denominational Jewish learning community, based in Jerusalem and with programs worldwide. Students encounter and grapple with classic texts and traditions of Judaism, while exploring their relevance to today’s most pressing issues. Pardes empowers students with the knowledge and tools to take ownership of their Jewish experience. Come learn more about our Summer Programs and Semester/Year Program, including a new internship add-on and international travel opportunities. Fellowships and scholarships available for student leaders.

Rabbi Dr. Daniel Roth is the director of the Pardes Center for Judaism and Conflict Resolution. He holds a Ph.D. from Bar Ilan University‘s Program for Conflict Resolution, Management and Negotiation writing on Jewish models of conflict resolution, peacemaking, and reconciliation. Daniel has been teaching advanced rabbinics, Bible, conflict resolution and other subjects at Pardes for over fifteen years. Daniel is also a lecturer at Bar Ilan’s Program for Conflict Resolution, a senior research fellow at George Mason University’s Center for World Religions, Diplomacy and Conflict Resolution and an Israeli certified court mediator. He holds a MA in Talmud from Hebrew University, a B.Ed in Jewish Philosophy and Talmud from Herzog Teachers’ College, and studied for eight years in Yeshivat Har-Etzion, during which time he received rabbinic ordination. Daniel is married with four children and lives in Jerusalem.

description:
Join Rabbi David Levin-Kruss from the Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem for a dynamic, interactive learning and discussion session:

"Irrelevant, Dull, Oppressive and Insipid"- 
Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel famously dismissed much of modern religion with these words. Many would argue that this is not the case today, but even in vibrant communities there often seems to be something missing from modern religious life. By going back to the reasons for being Jewish, this session examines what that something is.

5:30-7:00 PM: Schmooze with David over dinner at 104 West! and learn more about program opportunities at Pardes. You can also contact dlk@pardes.org.il to set up a one-on-one meeting while he is on campus.

description:
Author, police trainer, orator, and Batman aficionado Rabbi Cary Friedman will be coming to Cornell for Shabbat, October 4-5!

"A Rabbi’s Journey to Quantico: Bringing Spirituality to the FBI”- Friday night after dinner at 104West!

“Wisdom from the Batcave: Torah Lessons from Batman”- Before lunch on Saturday afternoon in The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell.

He will be available for casual discussion and questions throughout Shabbat.

Over the years, Rabbi Cary A. Friedman has been a hospital, prison, and police chaplain, the head of the JLE at Duke, a teacher, and more.  He has spoken at universities across the nation, the FBI Academy, the International Conference of Police Chaplains, and has appeared on The History Channel, among other venues.  He is the author of five books, includingSpiritual Survival for Law Enforcement,  Marital Intimacy, and Wisdom from the Batcave, which inspired the new documentary "Legends of the Knight".

description:
Join the CJL for an inspiring Shabbat with Wendy Amsellem, renowned teacher of Torah (you might know her from Drisha in NYC!).  Wendy will be speaking three times over the course of Shabbat: Friday night (after dinner with ABQ), Shabbat morning and Shabbat afternoon before mincha.  Sources in English will be available for all shiurim.  

Schedule: 
Friday night after dinner (approx. 8:30) in 104 West!
 Elisha ben Abuyah: The High Road to Heresy

Despite a promising start as a First Century Sage and Scholar, Elisha ben Abuyah leaves the path and becomes a notorious heretic. How did that happen? We will study an array of Rabbinic texts that seek to explain Elisha’s apostasy and explore the potential reasons why a believer would lose faith.

Shabbat morning (approx. 11:45) in CJL Piano Room 
Idolizing Aharon

How can we reconcile the priestly, beneficent Aharon of the rest of the Torah with the Aharon who builds the golden calf in Parshat Ki-Tissa? We will explore Aharon’s actions in Exodus 32 and the varying attempts of the midrash and of medieval exegetes to make sense of his behavior.

Shabbat afternoon 4:45 in 104 West!
Elisha and R. Meir: Tainted Torah?

Even once Elisha ben Abuyah becomes a heretic, his student R. Meir continues to learn from him. Why does Meir persist in studying with Elisha? Why does Elisha keep teaching Meir? Does this relationship taint Rabbi Meir’s Torah? We will explore their complicated relationship and examine the nature of pedagogic loyalties.




This event has been generously supported by the Institute for Jewish Ideas and Ideas, which offers a vision of Orthodox Judaism that is intellectually sound, spiritually compelling, and emotionally satisfying. Based on an unwavering commitment to the Torah tradition and to the Jewish people, it fosters an appreciation of legitimate diversity within Orthodoxy.

From Drisha's website: Wendy Amsellem  teaches in the Yesodot Program and is the Director of the July Collegiate Program for Women at Drisha. She is the former Director of the Dr. Beth Samuels High School Program and an alumna of the Drisha Scholars Circle. She is pursuing a PhD in Judaic Studies at New York University and has a BA in History and Literature from Harvard University.  Drisha Institute for Jewish Education is a leading center for the study of classical Jewish texts and has profoundly affected the lives of the thousands of students from across the United States and abroad who have taken classes and learned with its exceptional faculty. Drisha provides students of all ages and backgrounds with the opportunity to encounter texts in a serious, intellectually rigorous and inclusive manner through specialized courses, lectures and an emphasis on havruta [partner] study.

description:
Cornell Cinema partners w/Cornell CIS (Computing & Information Science) to offer a post-screening discussion following a 6:30pm* show of Hidden Figures. (*the April 13 show was previously advertised as starting at 7pm.) Professor Kim Weeden, Director of the Center for the Study of Inequality & Chair of the Department of Sociology will lead the discussion.**
Hidden Figures is the incredible untold story of Katherine Johnson (Taraji P. Henson), Dorothy Vaughan (Octavia Spencer) and Mary Jackson (Janelle Monáe)—brilliant African-American women working at NASA, who served as the brains behind one of the greatest operations in history: the launch of astronaut John Glenn into orbit, a stunning achievement that restored the nation’s confidence, turned around the Space Race, and galvanized the world. The visionary trio crossed all gender and race lines to inspire generations to dream big.
The film will be screened two more times (w/out discussion): Fri, April 14 at 7pm & Sun, April 16 at 4:30pm.
** Kim Weeden is the Jan Rock ’77 Professor of Social Sciences at Cornell University, the Chair of the Department of Sociology, and the Director of the Center for the Study of Inequality. Her research investigates income inequality, gender, social class, and education. One line of her research investigates gender in STEM fields, and she was a co-PI on Cornell’s NSF-ADVANCE grant to improve the recruitment, retention, and promotion of women in the sciences.
