description:
Sneak Preview!
American Reunion
Wednesday, April 4 9:00 WSH Free!
2012 > USA > Directed by Jon Hurwitz, Hayden Schlossberg
With Jason Biggs, Alyson Hannigan, Eugene Levy
The sexed-up crew of the American Pie films has finally grown up. All older (and theoretically wiser), it's their 10-year
high school reunion, and a chance to see if friendship – and old gags – stand the test of time. With the entire cast back
together, Reunion proves to be all that you've come to expect from the American Pie franchise. FREE Admit-2 Passes
will be available starting Monday, April 2 from the Willard Straight Ticket Desk, 10am – 5pm. More at
americanreunionmovie.com 35mm

description:
Calories are the source of health problems affecting billions of people in today's globalized world, and although they are essential to human health and survival, these units of energy are a mystery to many of us. Few people understand what they are and how they work even though we now have a population in which 64 percent of adults and one third of our children are overweight.

Join experts Marion Nestle and Malden Nesheim for a talk about their new book, “Why Calories Count: From Science to Politics” 
MANN LIBRARY: Stern Seminar Room (Rm. 160)

http://events.cornell.edu/event/book_talk_why_calories_count_from_science_to_politics

name: Book Talk: Why Calories Count

description:

At 2 pm, join us for astronomer Jim Bell's Showtime! presentation and book signing event.

At 3 pm, Cornell Space Scientists will give a guided tour of the new exhibit, which features an interactive flight over the moon using high-resolution data of the lunar surface. 

Included in admission.

description:
George Washington Carver was an African-American scientist who discovered many, many uses for peanuts. Join Sciencenter educator Miriam Musco in a celebration of Black History month by exploring the different products Dr. Carver created. Visitors will even have the opportunity to make their own peanut butter! 

NOTE: This activity is best suited for children and families with no peanut allergies.

Included with admission.

I'm excited to tell you about a new trio I'm in - it's called The Phrase-Shifters, featuring Renato Hanriot on bandoneon, Nicholas DiEugenio on violin, and myself on piano. 

This Valentine's Day at 8 PM (Monday, February 14), we'll be doing a special evening of all ballads from the great American songbook at the Carriage House Cafe Hayloft.

There will not be dinner for this event - but drinks and good vibes will be present, as always at the Hayloft. Admission is $10, $7 students and seniors.

Thank-you for your past interest, and hope you'll enjoy the music!

Sincerely,

John Stetch

description:
Prof. Bryan Danforth (Entomology) will introduce the Friday night screening of QUEEN OF THE SUN at 7:15

It also plays
Saturday, April 23 at 7:15
Tuesday, April 26 at 7:15

2010 > USA/New Zealand/France/Germany/Switzerland/Italy/UK/Australia > Directed by Taggart Siegel
With Michael Pollan, Vandana Shiva, Gunther Hauk
Around the world, the bees are dying from the mysterious and confounding Colony Collapse Disorder. Queen of the Sun examines this crisis through the eyes of biodynamic beekeepers, scientists, farmers and philosophers, and explores how recent industrial changes in beekeeping have changed our relationship to these pollinators. "A creative exploration of the global honeybee crisis replete with remarkable nature cinematography, some eccentric characters and yet another powerful argument for organic, sustainable agriculture in balance with nature." (Variety) More at queenofthesun.com Digital Projection
1 hr 23 min

description:
Set backstage at three iconic product launches and ending in 1998 with the unveiling of the iMac, STEVE JOBS takes us behind the scenes of the digital revolution to paint an intimate portrait of the brilliant man at its epicenter. 
STEVE JOBS is directed by Academy Award® winner Danny Boyle and written by Academy Award® winner Aaron Sorkin, working from Walter Isaacson’s best-selling biography of the Apple founder.  The producers are Mark Gordon, Guymon Casady, Scott Rudin, Boyle and Academy Award® winner Christian Colson.
 
Michael Fassbender plays Steve Jobs, the pioneering founder of Apple, with Academy Award®-winning actress Kate Winslet starring as Joanna Hoffman, former marketing chief of Macintosh.  Steve Wozniak, who co-founded Apple, is played by Seth Rogen, and Jeff Daniels stars as former Apple CEO John Sculley.  The film also stars Katherine Waterston as Chrisann Brennan, Jobs’ ex-girlfriend, and Michael Stuhlbarg as Andy Hertzfeld, one of the original members of the Apple Macintosh development team. 
 
Official Sight: www.stevejobsthefilm.com
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/stevejobsfilm
Twitter: https://twitter.com/SteveJobsFilm

description: A FREE screening of a silent film w/live original score in the beautiful Sage Chapel!  The Yellow Ticket (1918) is a German drama made at the end of World War I and on the eve of the Russian revolution. It stars an adolescent Pola Negri, who would later become the legendary femme fatale of the silent era, and tells the story of an innocent young Jewish woman from a Polish shtetl who is constrained by anti-Semitic restrictions to lead a double life in a brothel while attempting to study medicine in Tsarist Russia. The film includes precious footage of the former Jewish quarter of Warsaw and the people who once lived there. Alicia Svigals is a leading klezmer violinist and a founder of the Klezmatics, has written for violinist Itzhak Perlman, the Kronos Quartet, playwright Tony Kushner and singer Diane Birch, and has also collaborated with Robert Plant and Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin, poet Allen Ginsburg and many others. Lerner is a jazz pianist and improviser whose career includes deep explorations of traditional and free jazz, new music-tinged improvisation and Ashkenazic folk music. She has appeared with Tito Puente and Steve Lacy and performs with the Ugly Beauties Trio and avant-garde Henneman Sextet. The event is cosponsored with the Cornell Council for the Arts, Jewish Studies Program, CU Klezmer Ensemble, Dept of Music, Cornell Institute for European Studies, Arts Committee of Temple Beth-El, Wharton Studio Museum and Tikkun v'Or.

description:
Our annual winter party is just around the corner, and this year's tenth anniversary edition is going to be a good one!

As the closing installment of our Selections from the Hitchcock 9 series, our party will showcase a rare screening of the fun and frothy silent film, CHAMPAGNE (1928), which features some definitive Hitchcockian touches!

The evening kicks off with a reception - including a complimentary glass of bubbly, courtesy of Sparrow's Wine Legend - during which time AJ Strauss will provide some jazzy piano accompaniment. You'll get to munch on scrumptious hors d'oeuvres and desserts, as well as make full use of the cash bar on site. The reception will conclude with drawings for an array of door prizes.

After mingling, munching, and sipping, Dr. Philip Carli, one of the best silent film musicians in the world, will take the stage to provide accompaniment to the fabulously fancy CHAMPAGNE.

description: The latest edition of the touring Internet Cat Video Festival will feature 100 cat videos culled from nominations by the public in the categories of Comedy, Drama, Animated, Musical, Action, Vintage, and Documentary. Patrons of this family-friendly program will be encouraged to purr on their favorites as part of this super entertaining interactive evening that will include kitty cat trivia and prizes, an on-screen parade of patrons’ own favorite felines, and a complimentary sequined cat mask for everyone! Mistress of Ceremonies for the evening will be Asst. Prof. Leah Shafer ’94/’99/’08 (Media and Society, Hobart & William Smith College) who has written about the popularity of cat videos on the Internet (her "Cat Videos and the Aesthetics of the Superfurry" is forthcoming in Film Criticism). She will be joined by Bruce Kornreich, Associate Director for Education and Outreach at the Cornell Feline Health Center, for the pre-show activities. The Internet Cat Video Festival is produced and curated by the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

description:
Wed 9/28 @ 7:00 & Sat Oct 1 @ 7:15
"a theremin-toned time capsule from the trippier precincts of toontown and science fiction…" (Village Voice) Winner of the Grand Prix at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival. Digital Restoration!

Nothing else has ever looked or felt like director René Laloux’s animated marvel FANTASTIC PLANET, a politically minded and visually inventive work of science fiction. The film is set on a distant planet called Ygam, where enslaved humans (Oms) are the playthings of giant blue native inhabitants (Draags).  With eerie, coolly surreal cutout animation by Roland Topor featuring wondrous creatures and landscapes; and a brilliant psychedelic jazz score by Alain Goraguer.
"…it's not every stoner midnight movie that can stand a second viewing in the sober light of day." (Village Voice)

description:
Yet another absolutely fabulous, absolutely FREE Sage event.

GRASS: A NATION'S BATTLE FOR LIFE (1925) is a silent documentary which follows a branch of the Bakhtiari tribe of Persia (today Iran) as they and their herds make their seasonal journey to better pastures. It is considered one of the earliest ethnographic films ever made. 

Live accompaniment will be provided by the Cloud Chamber Orchestra (Robby Aceto, Peter Dodge & Chris White), who will reprise the core originally commissioned by FLEFF. 

Cosponsored by the Dept. of Anthropology.

description:
Organization Name: Risley Residential Collage – Cornell University
City: Ithaca
State: NY
Country: USA
Position Title: Artist in Residence
Position Type: Part-Time Temporary

Artist-in-Residence Position Description  
Risley Residential College for the Creative and Performing Arts at Cornell University is seeking working professionals from all creative fields for the position of Artist-in-Residence (AIR). The appointment is for 2016-2017 Academic Year (August 1, 2016 through May 31, 2017), with the possibility of renewal for the 2017-2018 academic year (two year maximum). 

Candidates must be open to living with college students and enthusiastic about sharing their talents and developing mentoring relationships. The AIR helps to support and expand upon creative talent and awareness of residential students in the Risley community. Responsibilities include:

1)	Programming: Create and facilitate at least (2) programs per month.  These programs should connect to the AIR’s area of artistic expertise, be open to the entire Risley community, and be educational or community-oriented in nature.  The AIR must also maintain a Bulletin Board (located outside the AIR Suite) with information about upcoming events and other AIR related news.
2)	Community Involvement: Weekly attendance at Risley’s “Kommittee” meetings is expected.  Kommittee takes place on Sunday nights at 9 PM.  It is expected that the AIR work collaboratively with Kommittee board members on a regular basis, maintaining open communication and positive ongoing interactions.  Efforts to engage in the community through programs, care of the building, and general visibility in the hall are also expected.
3)	Involvement with Staff: The AIR will be supervised by the Residence Hall Director (RHD) and will attend bi-weekly one-on-one meetings in order to receive/provide feedback and support, troubleshoot concerns, and brainstorm for programs.  The AIR will also engage with the Resident Advisor (RA) staff on a regular basis, attending at least (1) staff meeting per semester.  

About Risley Residential College
Risley Residential College for the Creative and Performing Arts is home to a tight-knit community of 197 individuals who engage in a wide variety of fine and performing arts.  On any given day at Risley, you may find students rehearsing for a play, practicing an instrument, , putting the finishing touches on an art piece, or planning one of Risley’s many annual events.  The Risley community is one that prides itself on providing students with a unique residential experience while at Cornell.  Risley is mostly self-governed, with “Kommittee” as its main governing body.  While the RHD and other staff members of the building provide structure, guidance and support, community members are highly involved in how the community functions from year to year.  Risley also has several shops that are open for student use including painting, printmaking, digital video editing, woodworking, ceramics, sewing, audio recording, jewelry making, stained glass, a general art shop, as well as an 81 seat black-box theater, a black and white darkroom, a dining hall, performance space, a library, lounge space and a dance studio.  Current and former Risleyites agree that Risley (sometimes referred to as “The Castle”) is unmatched as an on-campus living option.

Compensation 
The AIR will receive housing within the building (living room, bedroom and bathroom), use of the Risley Hall Programming Kitchen, $700 per semester meal plan, and a small stipend of $1000 per semester.  Due to the fact that this is not a full time position, benefits are not included and relocation expenses are not provided.  Please note also that personal studio space is not provided, however, the AIR is allowed to utilize the shops that are open to all Risleyites. However, Please note that space is not available for partners/family in the AIR residence nor are pets allowed (with the exception of fish in up to a 10 gallon tank).  

Qualifications
All applicants must have an undergraduate degree (preferably in an arts-related field), and be legally allowed to work in the US. Most importantly, we are seeking applicants who can work independently and thrive in a college residential environment. This position is not available to those who have served as the Risley AIR in the past.  

Application Process
Please prepare a cover letter, resume, a portfolio of your work (10 piece limit), and 3 references.  In your cover letter please comment on your experience living in a college residence hall, why you are interested in the Risley AIR position, as well as some examples of programs/workshops you have facilitated in the past. Please send your application materials to: mkr65@cornell.edu

or

AIR Search Subcommittee
c/o Meurcie Redding
Risley Residence Hall Director
129 Risley Hall    
Cornell University            
Ithaca, NY 14853


Applicants must also complete the Cornell University application which can be found here.  An offer for the Artist in Residence position is contingent upon the successful completion of a background check.


The deadline for submission is 5:00 PM May 10th, 2016.

description:
Feb 7 - THE LODGER, with live music
Feb 12 - BLACKMAIL, with live accompaniment
Feb 20 - DOWNHILL, with soundtrack
Feb 22 - CHAMPAGNE, with live accompaniment

The Hitchcock Pass: $50 general/$35 students (good for all except CHAMPAGNE)
-OR-
$12 general/$9 students (no comps, or passes allowed) per screening

Cornell Cinema is thrilled to present six silent films selected from "The Hitchcock 9," a recent tour jointly presented by the British Film Institute (BFI), Park Circus/ITV, and Rialto Pictures. The restoration of Alfred Hitchcock's nine surviving silent films has been the biggest and more complex restoration project undertaken by the BFI National Archive to date. Decades of damage and wear have been removed; the sharpness of the image improved; new shots discovered and intertitles and tinting restored. The BFI has used elements borrowed from seven international archives in the restoration process but film materials from the BFI National Archive - including a number of original negatives - have been central to the project. Hitchcock's silent films are essential to an understanding of his later work and these restoration now enable them to be seen afresh and discovered by new audiences across the world. 

Four of our selections will be accompanued live on piano by Dr. Philip Carli - one of the best silent film accompanists in the world - one of which, the fantastic CHAMPAGNE, will be presented as the featured event at this year's Elegant Winter Party on Feb 22. THE LODGER will be accompanied by a trio of seasoned silent film composers/accompanists, and DOWNHILL will be presented with its own solo piano sountdrack by John Sweeney.

description:
Two films & a reception in between! This special town-gown event is geared toward CU & IC faculty members, graduate/professional students and Ithaca community members, who are invited to socialize at a reception in between the offering of two films directed by multimedia artist Laurie Anderson. Heart of a Dog (75 mins, 2015) is a lyrical, collage-like film that centers on Anderson’s beloved rat terrier Lolabelle, who died in 2011. It’s a personal essay that weaves together childhood memories, video diaries, philosophical musings on data collection, surveillance culture and the Buddhist conception of the afterlife, and heartfelt tributes to the artists, writers, musicians and thinkers who inspire her. 

It will be followed by a reception at 8:15pm, when we’ll turn our lobby into a lounge where patrons can mingle and discuss the film while sipping a glass of complimentary beer or wine (courtesy of Sparrow’s Fine Wines) and nibbling on light hors d’oeuvres. (Non-alcoholic beverages will also be available.)

At 9:15pm, we’ll show Home of the Brave (90 mins, 1986), Anderson’s highly enjoyable performance film, “an eye-popping tapestry stitched with video, chaotic choreography, subtitles, and wild props such as dancing shirts and a so-called drum suit that turns the singer’s entire body into a percussive instrument.” (Variety) It will be shown in a rare 35mm archival print.

Advance tickets for this special event are $20 and are available now at CornellCinemaTickets.com. Door sales will be $25. Comps and passes not accepted. Please note: Heart of a Dog will also be shown on Thursday, February 18 at 9:15pm for regular ticket prices; patrons can also opt to attend the screening only (on Feb 19) of Home of the Brave at 9:15pm for $10.

description:
Cornell Cinema is proud to present, in collaboration with Pediatric Cancer Awareness Club, Colleges Against Cancer,  and Cupcakes for a Cure, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl.

In this “fresh, beautiful and heartbreaking achievement ” (Hitflix), a geeky high school senior (the astonishing Tom Mann) whose only pleasure to date has been making lo-fi film parodies with best bud Earl (a savvy Cyler) is forced by his mom to visit a girl dying of cancer (Cooke, ferociously sardonic). Among the best of a great 2015 crop of teen films.

Pediatric Cancer Awareness Club 

PCAC works to raise awareness and funds for pediatric cancer, while also participating in community service for children with cancer. We have ongoing projects in conjunction with Sunrise Day Camp, a camp for kids with cancer and their siblings located in Long Island, NY, as well as other organizations helping children with cancer. 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Pediatric-Cancer-Awareness-Club-of-Cornell/455885731216239


Colleges Against Cancer 

Colleges Against Cancer is a club that holds various cancer fundraisers and awareness events throughout the year (including breast cancer awareness week and the great American smoke-out). Our biggest event is our annual Relay for Life, an all-night cancer fundraiser where we celebrate cancer survivors, remember those we've lost, and fight back against this terrible disease. Relay is an event that includes members of our club along with the larger Cornell community. We fundraise before and during the event, which features speakers, performances, food, and activities. This past semester, we raised over $85,000 for the American Cancer Society.

http://main.acsevents.org/site/TR?pg=entry&fr_id=72916


Cupcakes for a Cure

Cupcakes for a Cure was started in 2011 at the University of Central Florida by a group of LEAD Scholars students. To date, we have donated over $20,000 to pediatric cancer patients in local communities. 

Cupcakes for a Cure at UCF donates all funds raised to BASE Camp Children's Cancer Foundation (basecamp.org) to help change the lives of children battling cancer through our cupcake sales. Not only do we donate to pediatric cancer patients, but we also form close relationships with the children by volunteering at BASE Camp events such as weekly lunch deliveries to Arnold Palmer Hospital, monthly overnight camps at hotels, and other special events such as BASE Camp's prom.

Cupcakes for a Cure started at Cornell University this past Fall. At Cornell, our sales are geared towards raising money for Sunrise Day Camp, the only dedicated full summer day camp for children with cancer. Sunrise Day Camp allows children with cancer and their siblings to attend entirely for free, alleviating the financial burden on families who have already spent extensive amounts of money on treatments. The original camp is located in Long Island, NY in 2006. Since then, Sunrise Day Camp has also been initiated in Pearl River, NY as well as in Israel. For more information, visit Sunrise Day Camp's website at http://www.sunrisedaycamp.org.

http://www.cupcakes4acure.net/about.html

description:
Filmmaker and subject of film will both be here in the flesh!

A poetic documentary portrait of New York artist Carolee Schneemann. A pioneer of performance and body art as well as avant-garde cinema, Schneemann has been breaking the frames of the art world for five decades, in a variety of mediums, challenging assumptions of feminism, gender, sexuality, and identity. The film captures Schneemann in her own words, images and reflections, at work, at home, in the studio, and interweaves extensive film excerpts from her groundbreaking film work in both super 8 and 16mm such as Fuses (1967); Kitch’s Last Meal (1973-76), with documentation of performances including Meat Joy (1964); Interior Scroll (1975) and more recent museum commissions and exhibitions. By highlighting the sheen of photographic prints, the fibres of diary pages and the gloss of wet paint, Breaking The Frame provides a textured mise-en-scene that resonates with Schneemann’s corporeal focus. The visual composition is complemented by a soundtrack featuring the music of composer James Tenney. Tenney was Schneemann’s companion and collaborator for many years, and the two remained close friends until his death in 2006.

More at breakingtheframe.com 

2012 > Canada > Directed by Marielle Nitoslawska
1 hr 40 min

with experimental filmmaker Roger Beebe!

Experimental filmmaker Roger Beebe, whose films have shown around the globe from Sundance to the Museum of Modern Art and from McMurdo Station in Antarctica to the CBS Jumbotron in Times Square, brings a program of his recent multi-projector films to Cornell Cinema. In these films Beebe explores the possibilities of using multiple projectors—running as many as 8 projectors simultaneously—not for a free-form VJ-type experience, but for the creation of discrete works of expanded cinema.

The show begins at 7:15.

description:
A film about climate change
with panel discussion

Academy Award winning documentary filmmaker Charles Ferguson (Inside Job, No End in Sight) trains his lens on both the challenges and solutions of climate change. Stunning footage and on-ground interviews span five continents, including the coal-poisoned waters of Appalachia, the dangerous coal pits of China, the glowing gas-lit night skies of Nigeria, and the vanishing forests of Indonesia. Ferguson’s advocacy leaves room for hope, as he highlights those pursuing solutions to address the global catastrophe. The screening will be followed by a panel discussion with Cornell University professors Chuck Greene (Earth & Atmospheric Sciences),
Toby Ault (Earth & Atmospheric Sciences), and
Robert Howarth (Ecology and Evolutionary Biology).

RESCHEDULED!

Korakrit Arunanondchai, born and raised in Bangkok, is an avid collaborator with a wide-ranging artistic practice, exploring themes such as history, authenticity, self-representation, and tourism as a cultural transplant. He moved to the United States to study art at the Rhode Island School of Design and the Columbia University School of the Arts, where he met and was mentored by Rirkrit Tiravanija. Korakrit was one of the collaborator's on Tiravanija's monumental print project, which is now on view at the Johnson Museum alongside new work by Arunanondchai.

The Museum is open tonight until 8:00 PM!

description:
One of the most talked-about docs of the year and a viewing experience unlike any other, ACT OF KILLING is hardly a walk in the park, but is a film that is that rare blend of education, pathos, and artistry. 

In this "dogged, inventive, profoundly upsetting and dismayingly funny documentary about the Indonesian massacres that began in 1965 and claimed, by some estimates, as many as 2.5 million lives over the next year" (NY Times), former death squad leaders reenact their real-life mass-killings in various cinematic genres. 

Profs. Brian Hanrahan (CU Dept of Performing and Media Arts) and Tom Pepinsky (CU Dept of Govt and Southeast Asia Program) will be discussants for an analysis following the film.

description:
Shown in a new digital restoration, Chimes at Midnight is the crowning achievement of Orson Welles’s later film career. This brilliantly crafted Shakespeare adaptation was the culmination of Welles’s lifelong obsession with the Bard’s ultimate rapscallion, Sir John Falstaff, the loyal, often soused childhood friend of King Henry IV’s wayward son, Prince Hal. Appearing in several plays as a comic supporting figure, Falstaff is here the main event: a robustly funny and ultimately tragic screen antihero, played by Welles with lumbering grace. Integrating elements from both Henry IV plays as well as Richard II, Henry V, and The Merry Wives of Windsor, Welles created an unorthodox Shakespeare film that is also a gritty period piece, one that he called “a lament . . . for the death of Merrie England.”

Poetic, philosophical, and visceral—with a kinetic battle sequence centerpiece as impressive as anything else Welles directed—Chimes at Midnight is as monumental as the figure at its center. “If I wanted to get into heaven on the basis of one movie, that’s the one I would offer up.”—Orson Welles

Larry Jackson ’70, producer and former industry exec, worked with Welles on his unfinished film The Other Side of the Wind as well as Filming Othello. Jackson is also a former vice president at Samuel Goldwyn Co., Orion Pictures and Miramax and the producer-director of the Welles-narrated Bugs Bunny Superstar. He will take questions and present a behind-the-scenes slide show following the screening.

More info at www.janusfilms.com/chimes

description:
Bring a warm burst of spring color into your wardrobe! Learn how to naturally dye a silk scarf using local plants with local artist Sarah Gotowka. There will be 5 different natural dye baths: marigolds* (yellow), coreopsis* (orange), hopi sunflower* (purple), indigo (blue) and cochineal (red). Participants will be able to use shibori-resist techniques in combination with over-dyeing in any of these baths to create their own individual designs!

*Plants that the artist has grown herself!!!

Please bring your own brown-bag lunch!

FEES: $45 for Johnson Museum Members / $70 for nonmembers, all materials, silk, and dyes included.

Sign up with a friend and receive 20% off the registration fee. Please call 607 255-6464 to register by Friday, March 4.

More information on the artist can be found at: www.saagoto.com

Sarah Gotowka is a visual artist currently living in Trumansburg. She is adopted Korean-Polish-Italian-American, and grew up in the suburbs of Rochester where she obsessively made mix tapes from 90’s radio airplay and built makeshift forts in the woods. (These factors alone have influenced her art practice immensely.) She received her BFA from The Cleveland Institute of Art majoring in Fiber and Material Studies in 2007, and graduated with an MFA from Concordia University’s Fiber and Material Practices in 2013.
 
Sarah helped found The Color Collective, an initiative to grow sustainable dyes in Montréal without the interference of machines or chemical fertilizers. This collaboration led to the instruction of many workshops at the Concordia University Greenhouse and Montréal Center for Contemporary Textiles, as well as exhibitions at the Textile Museum of Canada, the International Symposium & Exhibition on Natural Dyes in LaRochelle, France, and at the 13th Biennial Symposium of The Textile Society of America in Washington DC.
 
After receiving her MFA she moved back to upstate New York and began growing natural dye plants in her Trumansburg backyard. She has collaborated with Cornell, Ithaca College, the Community Arts Partnership of Ithaca, The Craftstitute, New Roots Charter School, and The Truamansburg Conservatory of Fine Arts giving various workshops on natural dye plants and textile practices.

description: CALS graduate Adepero Oduye '99, the third of seven children of Nigerian immigrants, was premed at Cornell and took her first acting class during her senior year. After that, there was no looking back. Her big break came when she was cast as the lead in the award-winning independent film Pariah (2011), playing a gay teenager struggling to come out to her family and community. She won Best Breakthrough Performance Awards from the African-American Film Critics Association, the Black Reel Awards and the Black Film Critics Circle.  She was also nominated for an Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead. Subsequently, she was cast as Eliza in the Oscar-winning Best Picture 12 Years a Slave (2013) and as Kathy Tao in The Big Short (2015), which is nominated for several Oscars, including Best Picture. She is on campus to participate in the President’s Council on Cornell Women Symposium (http://www.alumni.cornell.edu/pccw/annualmeeting2016.cfm). At Cornell Cinema she will introduce and take questions before The Big Short on Saturday, March 5 at 9:20pm in Willard Straight Theatre (this screening replaces the previously announced screening of Creed).

description:
The Kids Grow Up
with filmmaker Doug Block ’75 
Thursday, April 21, 7:15pm, Willard Straight Theatre, Free

Cornell Cinema welcomes personal documentary filmmaker and producer Doug Block ‘75, who will be the Irik Sevin Fellow on campus. Irik Sevin '69 made an endowment to Cornell to bring each year a distinguished individual in American public life to live in one of the five West Campus houses for a few days. This year the Fellow will be housed in Alice Cook House. As a Fellow, Block will interact with house residents, Cornell students in general, and with the community. Block will present his latest film, The Kids Grow Up, “a profound, and utterly relatable, contemplation of…. parenthood, aging and youth’s swift passing.” (Anthony Kaufman, indieWIRE). The film is the follow-up to his 51 Birch Street, which he will present at Cinemapolis on Friday, April 22 (see cinemapolis.org for details). In addition to his own films, Block has produced award-winning documentaries for others, including Jennifer Dworkin’s Love & Diane; Esther Robinson's A Walk Into the Sea: Danny Williams and the Warhol Factory, and Resurrect Dead, directed by Jon Foy, which won Best Documentary Film Director at the 2011 Sundance Film Festival. He is also the founder and co-host of The D-Word, a popular international online discussion forum for documentary professionals. Special thanks to House Professor-Dean Andre A. Dhondt, Alice Cook House.

description:
Cornell Cinema’s annual Elegant Winter Party has become a must-attend event on the social calendars of cinema-loving Ithacans, and this ninth anniversary edition will not disappoint! The Willard Straight Theatre will be transformed into a gambling parlor of sorts to create the perfect atmosphere for screenings of collage artist/animator Lewis Klahr’s The Pettifogger, about a year in the life of an American gambler and con man circa 1963, and The Sting, starring Paul Newman and Robert Redford as a pair of 1930s confidence men. Newman and Redford are joined by the late actor Harold Gould, who earned two graduate degrees in theater at Cornell (M.A. '48, Ph.D. '53), before going on to a successful career on Broadway and in Hollywood. The evening kicks off with a cocktail reception from 7:30 – 8:45pm, during which time The Pettifogger will be screened while local musician A.J. Strauss provides jazzy piano music. Patrons can enjoy scrumptious hors d’oeuvres and desserts, courtesy of some of Ithaca’s finest dining and catering establishments, as well as a cash bar. There will also be complimentary tastings of Meleau specialty wines, courtesy of Frédéric Bouché of Ports of New York. Between bites and sips, patrons can participate in a silent auction featuring movie memorabilia and other specialty items and services. (Check website closer to Mar 2 for details.) There will also be drawings for an array of fabulous door prizes before The Sting starts at 9pm.

Tickets for this special evening are $50 general ($90 a pair) and $30 student ($50 a pair), and are available now at CornellCinemaTickets.com, and starting Monday, February 25 from 104 Willard Straight Hall, from 9am – 5pm. For more information, call 607-255-3522.

description:
with filmmaker Penny Lane in person:
NUTS! is an animated documentary about Dr. John Romulus Brinkley, an eccentric genius who built an empire in Depression-era America with a goat-testicle impotence cure and a million watt radio station. Using animated reenactments, interviews, archival footage, and a hilariously unreliable narrator, NUTS! traces Brinkley’s rise from poverty and obscurity to the heights of celebrity, wealth and influence. Winner of a Special Jury Award for Documentary Editing at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival. Watch a trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B5rMIjd1hBc

description:
WINTER RECESS AT THE SCIENCENTER: TEACHERS' WEEK
February 17-26
Teachers and their immediate families enjoy free admission during Winter Recess. Explore the museum, embark on a journey through your watershed at the new Featured Exhibition: "Ocean Bound!", and join us for a full line-up of special activities all week.  

Showtime! Presentation: The Ocean World of Reptiles
Saturday, Feb. 18, 2 pm
Did you know some reptiles live entirely in water, not on dry land? Explore the ocean world of reptiles. Learn how the ocean serves as a source of food and travel for many reptile species. Meet, touch and photograph reptiles presented by Diana Sleiertin, MaxMan Reptile Rescue.    

Special Hands-On Activities
Monday, Feb. 20, through Friday, Feb. 24, 11 am and 2 pm
Enjoy hands-on activities to learn all about water and where it goes.

Teachers' Mini-Workshops
Monday, Feb. 20, through Friday, Feb. 24, 2 pm
Teachers, join Sciencenter educators for a special workshop highlighting water and the water cycle in our classroom. Take-home a CD-ROM filled with materials to use in your own classroom. Free.

Open Holiday Mondays
Monday, February 20, 10 am – 5 pm
The Sciencenter is open for Presidents’ Day on Monday, Feb. 20.

Curiosity Corner Program for Our Youngest Visitors
Animal Time: Big Tracks, Little Tracks
Tuesday, Feb. 21, 10:30 am
Toddlers and preschoolers are invited to hear the story “Big Tracks, Little Tracks” by Millicent E. Selsam and make their own tracks out of paint and clay.

Special Showtime! Presentation: Animal Adaptations for Winter
Wednesday, Feb. 22, 1 pm
Have you ever wondered how animals survive in winter? Join Emma Brofsky of Cornell's Naturalist Outreach Program to explore animal adaptations for winter and learn how biology helps animals cope with cold weather, food shortages, and limited habitats. Touch animal pelts and do a hands-on activity on animal insulation. 

Showtime! Presentation: Robotic Mini Submarines
Saturday, Feb. 25, 2 pm
Ever wondered about the world beneath the sea? See how a new underwater vehicle, built by Cornell's Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Team, can be used to explore underwater. Hear about the vehicle's development and watch a demonstration of this fascinating technology. 

Touch live marine animals at Connect to the Ocean -- open Tuesday and Thursday from 2 to 4 pm, and Saturday and Sunday from noon to 4 pm.

Doors open at 8, while the film will begin at 8:30. 

Tickets are $10/$8 students and are available online NOW at http://cornellcinematickets.com while any extras will be available at the door. 

Get your tickets early, though, as every one of our outdoor screenings sold out this summer!

description:
Cornell Cinema presents the Ithaca Premiere of one of the most visually dazzling films of this century. Weird, wild, and way out there, ENTER THE VOID plays Thursday (9:15), Saturday (9:15), and Sunday (7:15).

Directed by Gaspar Noe
With Nathaniel Brown, Paz de la Huerta, Cyril Roy
The film world's reigning nihilist returns with the mind-altering tale of Oscar and Linda, two siblings caught in the web of Tokyo's dazzlingly neon-lit underground drug scene. After Oscar is ostensibly killed in a drug bust, he reappears as a ghost to watch over his stripper sister.  "An exceptional work.... What largely distinguishes it, beyond the stunning cinematography, is that this is the work of an artist who's trying to show us something we haven't seen before." (NY Times) This recently released unedited version includes 18 minutes of footage not included in the initial theatrical release. In Japanese and English. Viewer warning: there is a graphic scene of an abortion near the end of the film. Subtitled. More at ifcfilms.com/films/enter-the-void 35mm 'Scope
2009 > France > 2 hrs 41 min

description:
Visit us Thursday December 17th 5-7pm to meet the current exhibiting artist Michelle Kizer.  As she presents a new show Titled: Thoughts in Color.

Description: By using simplistic body language and nuancing this with varied painting styles and color schemes, this series challenges you to look beyond your first perceptions of the figures and titles. This is particularly important when connecting with women of color, whose emotions and standards of beauty continue to be policed by mainstream culture. Ask yourself, what is the story behind each woman, and how do “acceptable” emotional responses and standards of beauty preclude us from valuing them. Enjoy!

Artist Statement: Art has always been an integral part of my expression and healing process. As an artist from Brooklyn, New York, I have experienced and seen the heartbreaking struggles of ordinary people. My most powerful works encourage others to embrace the pain in their lives and transform it into something beautiful. 

******This event is free and open to the public and refreshments will be served.

For more information & to see other works, visit michellekizer.carbonmade.com

description: "Dearly Beloved, we are gathered here today to get through this thing called ‘Life!’” In celebration of Prince’s enormous impact on music, fashion, and the movies, we’re doing a FREE (or nearly free - we're still working out details) screening of Prince’s 1984 smash sensation PURPLE RAIN! Prince stars in a thinly-veiled role as "The Kid," a musical genius who falls in love with his singer Apollonia. Soon, The Kid’s self-destructive habits drive a wedge in their love, and The Kid must learn a lesson about love, through music. And what music! The film features a catalogue of Prince's hits, including I Would Die 4 U, When Doves Cry, Let's Go Crazy, and of course, Purple Rain. Often imitated, never duplicated - Prince, you will be missed! (ps: the film's fantastic cinematography will be shown off in the DCP we'll be showing!)

description:
Starting at 7:15 PM at WSH. Tickets are $12 or $9 for students or seniors. 

1929 > USSR > Directed by Dziga Vertov
This film is not only Vertov's masterpiece and final film of the silent era, it is a work which notably exemplifies the montage aesthetic of the Soviet avant-garde of the twenties. A city symphony filmed in Moscow and Odessa, the film is a continually shifting kaleidoscope of breathtaking imagery that captures the spirit of Russian life at that time. New 35mm print from the Moscow Film Archive. Advance tickets available at CornellCinemaTickets.com, from the Ithaca Guitar Works starting Saturday, October 29, and from the Cornell Cinema Office, 104 Willard Straight Hall (9am-5pm) starting Monday, October 31. 35mm
1 hr 7 min

description: Troublemakers unearths the history of land art in the late 1960s and early 1970s when a cadre of renegade artists sought to transcend the limitations of painting and sculpture by producing earthworks on a monumental scale in the desolate desert spaces of the American southwest. Featuring Robert Smithson (Spiral Jetty), Walter De Maria (Lightning Field) and Michael Heizer (Double Negative). With archival footage and dizzying helicopter cinematography! "The film's generous views of spectacular works are best seen on the largest screen available." (Glenn Kenny, The New York Times) The film also includes some great footage of the famous 1969 Earth Art exhibition curated by Willoughby Sharp at the Andrew Dickson White Museum of Art (pre-Johnson Museum) at Cornell.  Repeat show on Sunday, April 24 at 4:30pm. The film is just 1 hr 12 minutes! More at troublemakersthefilm.com

description:
CU Mathematics Professor Steven Strogatz will introduce The Man Who Knew Infinity & lead a discussion afterwards. The film tells the true story of the incredible life of Srinivasa Ramanujan (Dev Patel), a self-taught mathematics genius who traveled from the slums of India to Cambridge University in the early 20th century. Spurred on by his mentor G. H. Hardy (Jeremy Irons), Ramanujan fought against racism and the rigidity of academia to reveal his mathematic genius to the world.  More at ifcfilms.com/films/the-man-who-knew-infinity 
1 hr 48 min

description:
Cornell alum Kathryn Schubert has been working as an editor on independent films for several years, including acclaimed indies Beasts of the Southern Wild (first asst. editor) and Only Lovers Left Alive (assoc. editor). Her first feature film as editor, Experimenter, premiered at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival and was a selection of the prestigious New York Film Festival. “Michael Almereyda’s brilliant portrait of Stanley Milgram, the social scientist whose 1961, Yale-based “obedience study” reflected back on the Holocaust and anticipated Abu Ghraib and other atrocities carried out by ordinary people who were just following orders, places its subject in an appropriately experimental cinema framework. The proverbial elephant in the room materializes on screen; Milgram (Peter Sarsgaard) sometimes addresses the camera directly as if to implicate us in his studies and the unpleasant truths they reveal. Remarkably, the film evokes great compassion for this uncompromising, difficult man, in part because we often see him through the eyes of his wife (Winona Ryder, in a wonderfully grounded performance), who fully believed in his work and its profoundly moral purpose. Almereyda creates the bohemian-tinged academic world of the 1960s through the 1980s with an economy that Stanley Kubrick might have envied.” (New York Film Festival, 2015) Read more about the film at: 
http://www.filmcomment.com/article/stanley-milgram-experimenter-michael-almereyda/ or experimentermovie.com

* Skilled carpenters needed! *

Register for one or both shifts on either day: 8 am – 12 pm and 1 pm – 5 pm. We’ll provide the lunch!

To register as a volunteer, please email Judy Ammack at jammack@sciencenter.org OR call 607-272-0600 ext. 110 today.

description:
In conjunction with LBQ, part of Haven: LGBTQ Student Union, and in honor of Gaypril, Cornell Cinema presents a three-film mini-series, International Women Loving Women. The series begins in Italy with PURPLE SEA, a Sicilian-set, 19th Century tale based on true events in which a woman agrees to live like a man to be with her female lover. It then heads to Sweden for Lukas Moodysson’s feature film debut and lesbian and arthouse hit, the acidly charming SHOW ME LOVE. It concludes in Israel with THE SECRETS, a recent Israeli film about the daughter of an ultra orthodox rabbi who develops an intense attraction to her fellow student at a women’s religious seminary. “One of the best Israeli films of recent years, The Secrets is an emotionally overpowering drama that will move audiences wherever it plays. The film’s mix of sensuality and spirituality is arresting.” 

PURPLE SEA:
Friday, April 1, 7:15, WSH
Sunday, April 3, 7:15, WSH

SHOW ME LOVE:

Monday, April 18, 9:00, WSH

Online advance tickets for all shows available as of June 15 at 
CornellCinemaTickets.com. Tickets purchased online will be held at the “will-call” table for pick-up the night of the show. Tickets can be purchased in person (with cash or check) the Monday before each screening (June 18, June 25, July 9, July 23 respectively) from the Cinema office, 104 Willard Straight Hall, from 9am – 5pm. Previous terrace shows have sold-out, so buy your tickets early!

Chico & Rita		
Wednesday, June 20	
2011 > Spain/UK > Directed by Fernando Trueba and Javier Mariscal
With the voices of Emar Xor Ona and Limara Meneses
"A dazzling and delightful work of modernist animation, a classic movie romance and a hip-swinging, finger-popping tale of musical revolution" (Salon.com), Chico & Rita was this year's surprise nominee for Best Animated Feature. Scored by Cuban pianist Bebo Valdés and featuring songs by Dizzy Gillespie and Charlie Parker, "the film rockets from the glitzy cabarets and sweaty dive bars of Havana, 1948, to bebop’s heyday in New York City and Paris jazz joints to the studio soundstages of Hollywood’s Golden Age." (Austin Chronicle) Sexy, sultry and sweet, this Spanish language animation is not for young kids! More at lumafilms.com
1 hr 33 mins

description:
In celebration of the 50th anniversary of the beloved musical, Cornell Cinema is hosting two screenings of the wildly popular  Sing-a-Long version on Saturday, Nov 14: 2pm & 7:30pm! So pull out your Lederhosen, polish up the glockenspiel and brush up on your yodeling! This hit interactive musical phenomenon has sold out audiences singing in their seats, booing Nazis, hissing the Baroness, and cheering Julie up and down the Alps from Oslo to L.A. That’s right, subtitles have been added to the film so that audience members can sing their hearts out to all the wonderful songs from this classic musical. Dressing up in costume is not compulsory but is strongly encouraged! There will be a costume contest, prizes, and a fun-pack of props for each audience member. The host for the festivities—local author, celeb and Trampoline founder, Bob Proehl—will lead the audience through a vocal warm up, judge the costume competition and award prizes, and demonstrate how to use the interactive fun-pack.

When all is song and done, including pre-show activities, movie and intermission, this fun-packed event will last about 3 1/2 hours and no doubt provide a lasting memory for all those who attend. The last time Cornell Cinema presented it, we sold-out both shows, so patrons are encouraged to buy their tickets in advance! Ticket prices are $15 general/$12 students & seniors/$10 kids 12 & under, and are available online at CornellCinemaTickets.com

Don't miss out!!

description:
India Association and Cornell Cinema will be co-hosting the screening of the movie, *Court*. 

Court is India's official entry into the Oscars and winner of top prizes at the Venice and Mumbai film festivals

Showing at Cornell Cinema Thursday, 12 November at 7:00 pm.
Samosa and chai at 6:30 pm (Co-sponsored by the South Asia Program). Ticket prices can be found here http://cinema.cornell.edu/info/tickets.html

Also showing Sunday, 15 November at 4:30 pm. Tickets are $5.50 for all for this showing.

Synopsis - An elderly folk singer and grassroots organizer, dubbed the “people’s poet,” is arrested on a trumped-up charge of inciting a sewage worker to commit suicide. His trial is a ridiculous and harrowing display of institutional incompetence, with endless procedural delays, coached witnesses for the prosecution, and obsessive privileging of arcane colonial law over reason and mercy.

‘Critics Pick! The wheels of justice grind slowly and mercilessly in “Court,” Chaitanya Tamhane’s quiet, devastating critique of the antiquated Indian legal system.’
— Stephen Holden, New York Times

description: American identical twins working in London, stop motion animators Stephen and Timothy Quay find their inspiration in Eastern European literature and classical music and art, their work distinguished by its dark humor and an uncanny feeling for color and texture. Masters of miniaturization, they turn their tiny sets into unforgettable worlds suggestive of long-repressed childhood dreams. Three Quay masterworks (In Absentia, The Comb, and Street of Crocodiles), curated by Christopher Nolan, will be shown with Quay, a new short film by Nolan revealing the inner workings of the Brothers' studio. All in new 35mm film prints! Cosponsored with the College of AAP. More at zeitgeistfilms.com/film/thequaysin35m  (A scene from The Comb is pictured.) This will be a rare & extraordinary show!

The Hitchcock Pass: $50 general/$35 students (good for all except CHAMPAGNE)
-OR-
$12 general/$9 students (no comps, or passes allowed) per screening

Cornell Cinema is thrilled to present six silent films selected from "The Hitchcock 9," a recent tour jointly presented by the British Film Institute (BFI), Park Circus/ITV, and Rialto Pictures. The restoration of Alfred Hitchcock's nine surviving silent films has been the biggest and more complex restoration project undertaken by the BFI National Archive to date. Decades of damage and wear have been removed; the sharpness of the image improved; new shots discovered and intertitles and tinting restored. The BFI has used elements borrowed from seven international archives in the restoration process but film materials from the BFI National Archive - including a number of original negatives - have been central to the project. Hitchcock's silent films are essential to an understanding of his later work and these restoration now enable them to be seen afresh and discovered by new audiences across the world. 

Four of our selections will be accompanued live on piano by Dr. Philip Carli - one of the best silent film accompanists in the world - one of which, the fantastic CHAMPAGNE, will be presented as the featured event at this year's Elegant Winter Party on Feb 22. THE LODGER will be accompanied by a trio of seasoned silent film composers/accompanists, and DOWNHILL will be presented with its own solo piano sountdrack by John Sweeney.

The highlight of this program of shorts is Mack singing live with 'Dusty Stacks of Mom' (2013, 41 mins), an animated rock opera paying affectionate tribute to her mother's ailing poster business. 

"Through exquisite layering and Mack's trademark cut 'n' paste stroboscopic animation techniques, it's impossible not to be reminded of our collective adolescent bedrooms or student kitchens. The film is eulogy to now near-defunct forms of cultural production and exchange, including analogue filmmaking, which have been all but extinguished by digital technology. " (BFI London Film Festival) Shown as part of last year's Views from the Avant Garde at the New York Film Festival. 

Check out more of her fabulous shorts at jodiemack.com 

1 hr 15 min

description:
Cornell veterinary students and clinical faculty will join volunteer alumni and offer their first daylong animal wellness clinic in the Bronx at its YMCA on Oct. 8. 

The clinic, at 2 Castle Hill Ave., will see cats from 8 a.m. to noon and dogs from 2-6 p.m. 

Pet owners are asked to enter the building through the side entrance fence. Pet visits will cost owners a modest fee, and all proceeds will go to the YMCA.

The program is modeled after a veterinary program that’s been running at Ithaca’s Southside Community Center since 1996. Organized by Cornell parasitologist Dwight Bowman and veterinarians Daniel Fletcher and William Hornbuckle, groups of first- and second-year veterinary students run low-cost clinics twice a month for pets in downtown Ithaca for owners who may not otherwise have access to well visit care.

In the spring, organizers plan to hold the clinic in another New York City borough and hope it will become a regular event.

---

Inquire for more information, or visit:
http://www.vet.cornell.edu/news/bronx.cfm

description:
Meet the star of the PBS kids show “Sid the Science Kid” at the Sciencenter on Saturday, December 10, 10 am – 1 pm. Enjoy special hands-on activities, explore interactive museum exhibits, and watch Sid episodes in a fun-filled day of science. All Sid the Science Kid activities are included with museum admission.

Sid’s special appearance celebrates health and children’s natural curiosity about science in everyday life. Kids can investigate health, the human body and over 250 hands-on exhibits throughout the museum, and record their observations in their own customized Sid the Science Kid Journal.

Explore how your body moves and make a skeleton puppet with articulating arms and legs. Learn how you breathe and create a model of the respiratory system at the Lung Power interactive activity station. Investigate the food you eat and make a food plate craft. Watch health-related Sid the Science Kid TV episodes that celebrate children’s natural curiosity about science in everyday life in the Sciencenter Amphitheater.

Learn about health, the human body, and our amazing ability to heal at our featured exhibition, The Healer Within. Become a virtual white blood cell on a mission through the body to hunt for and destroy pathogens. Play doctor and test how your heart responds to electrical circuits by taking your own EKG. Create music and feel music’s healing effects on the human body and mind. Learn about biofeedback loops in the body as you become a skateboard star, or explore blood pressure as you "pump it up."

Sid's visit to the Sciencenter is made possible by support from the WSKG Education Department. For more information, visit www.wskg.com, click “teach and learn.”

(Snow date: Sunday, December 11, noon - 3 pm)

description:
Cornell is participating in the 2016 Art + Feminism Wikipedia edit-a-thon, designed to improve coverage of women and the arts on Wikipedia. The Wikimedia Foundation says that only around 10 percent of its editors are female – this project aims to empower women to edit Wikipedia and ensure its content accurately represents the important arts contributions of women from all cultures. 
Join us Saturday, March 5 at several campus locations, including the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art, Olin Library and the Fine Arts Library, to participate in updating and adding entries on art and feminism at this free, fun drop-in event. Cornell University Library will offer Wikipedia editing workshops before the event, as well as same-day training. All gender identities and expressions are welcomed to contribute.
Already a Wikipedian? Register to attend here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/Ithaca/ArtAndFeminism_2016
For more info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/ArtAndFeminism

The BFI has used elements borrowed from seven international archives in the restoration process but film materials from the BFI National Archive - including a number of original negatives - have been central to the project. Hitchcock's silent films are essential to an understanding of his later work and these restoration now enable them to be seen afresh and discovered by new audiences across the world. 

Four of our selections will be accompanued live on piano by Dr. Philip Carli - one of the best silent film accompanists in the world - one of which, the fantastic CHAMPAGNE, will be presented as the featured event at this year's Elegant Winter Party on Feb 22. THE LODGER will be accompanied by a trio of seasoned silent film composers/accompanists, and DOWNHILL will be presented with its own solo piano sountdrack by John Sweeney.

description:
Free only with ticket in advance from the Willard Straight Resource Center,  starting Mon Sept 19 at 10am

The Aesthetics and Style of Race, Gender and Politics: Beyoncé’s Lemonade

Join us for a free screening of Beyoncé’s hour-long visual album, LEMONADE, followed by a panel of featuring four Cornell faculty women of color:  Oneka LaBennett, Noliwe Rooks, Samantha Sheppard and Dehanza Rogers.

LEMONADE is a rapturous tour-de-force of the personal and the political with directorial work from Jonas Åkerlund, Kahlil Joseph, Melina Matsoukas, Dikayl Rimmasch, Mark Romanek, Todd Tourso, and Beyoncé herself, work that has drawn comparisons to Julie Dash’s 1991 masterpiece DAUGHTERS OF THE DUST as well as artist Pipilotti Rist’s installation Ever is Over All, among others.

The presentation is cosponsored with the Africana Studies & Research Center, the Feminist, Gender & Sexuality Studies Program and the American Studies Program.

description:
One could call Stephane Wrembel a Gypsy, a World Traveler, for the music he plays and his lifestyle are expressive of the Gypsy way of life.  Born in Paris, and raised in Fontainbleu  (home of Impressionism and the music of Django Reinhardt), Stephane began classical training at the age of four.  His life took a decisive turn in his late teens when he first discovered Django’s music and the Gypsies. He spent the next ten years of his life learning, playing and expanding this tradition.  This intense work gave him his technique, but the time he spent playing around campfires and trailers gave him his soul.

After graduating Summa Cum Laude from Berklee College of Music with studies in Contemporary Jazz, Indian, African and Middle Eastern music, his life took another turn when he moved to New York City. Like New York, Stephane is aways in motion- always searching and never stopping in his quest to create a new sound.

THE DJANGO EXPERIMENT

Stephane tours in quartet format with two guitars, bass and percussion.

HIGHLIGHTS

Recorded third album with the legendary DAVID GRISMAN
Opened for and Sat-In with Rock and Roll Hall of Famer PATTI SMITH 
Headlined Lincoln Center
Coached MARIAH CAREY for her role as a singer/guitar player in “Tenessee”
Composed soundtrack music for WOODY ALLEN’s “Vicky Cristina Barcelona”
Wrote full soundtrack for “GOODBYE BABY” -Santa Cruz film festival winner 2008
Wrote several scores for National TV and RADIO commercials including ARBY’S, CHASE, CHEERIOS, and FRITO LAYS

Performed at many major music festivals including…. Discover Jazz in Burlington, The International Rochester Jazz Festival, Djangofest San Francisco, Djangofest Los Angeles, Djangofest Seattle, Djangofest New Mexico, High Sierra Music Festival, The Berkshire Mountain Music Festival, Northbeach Jazz Festival, Jalopi Django Festival and Whistler International Music Festival
name: Stephane Wrembel: Live Gypsy Jazz

description:
Oscar-nominated animator Bill Plympton will conduct a master class on Wednesday, February 16 from 6pm - 7:30pm in the Schwartz Center for Performing Arts Film Forum in Collegetown. He will discuss the artistic (design, layouts, storyboards, writing, editing, etc.) and business (budgets, funding, festivals, etc.) sides of animation, present a live drawing demonstration, show a selection of his recent shorts and give each student a free drawing! Seating is limited, so please email Christopher Riley at cjr20@cornell.edu to register for the class in advance. Preference given to students, but if there's enough space, all are welcome. Bill Plympton's visit is cosponsored with the Cornell Council for the Arts and the Dept. of Cinema, Photography, and Media Arts at Ithaca College.

When a selfish, mean-spirited, average joe wakes up with a pair of angel's wings sprouting out of his back, his life is transformed against his will. Try though he may to reject the wings and the unwanted attention they garner, he finds himself undeniably and irrevocably changed, and acting as defender of the wings and the goodness they represent. With a soundtrack featuring Tom Waits and Pink Martini, the otherwise wordless film is a darkly comedic, veritably monochromatic cartoon that mines the dregs of humanity for illumination. From the man responsible for I Married a Strange Person, animator Bill Plympton's Idiots and Angels effectively "suggests Toulouse-Lautrec by way of Charles Bukowski." (NY Times) more at idiotsandangels.com 35mm
2008, color, 1 hour 18 minutes, USA

description: An intimate, inspirational portrait of Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Malala Yousafzai, who was targeted by the Taliban and severely wounded by gunshot when returning home in Pakistan's Swat Valley. The then 15-year-old was singled out, along with her father, for advocating girls' education, and her attack sparked a global outcry. Building on her activism in Pakistan, Yousafzai has since emerged as a leading global campaigner for the educational rights of girls worldwide.  The film gives a glimpse into this extraordinary young girl's life - from her everyday life with her parents and brothers, to her impassioned speeches at the UN. Sponsored by the Office of the Vice Provost for International Affairs. More at henamedmemalalamovie.com and malala.org

description:
Join us for this special FREE event in Sage Chapel - Beyond Enchantment: Recent Work by Animator Lawrence Jordan:
Influenced by the collage novels of Max Ernst and the work of Joseph Cornell, with whom he worked, Jordan is known for experimental animations made from collaged cut outs of Victorian engravings which evoke the world of Alice in Wonderland and other surrealist works. Tonight's program, in honor of the 150th anniversary of Lewis Carroll’s classic novel, features five recent films including Blue Skies Beyond the Looking Glass, which invites viewers to trip the light fantastic with an array of silent film stars including Buster Keaton and Lillian Gish; Beyond Enchantment, wherein Victorian women encounter science and natural phenomena; and Cosmic Alchemy, where magnificently colored ancient star maps take the viewer into a world of cosmic imagination. Soundtracks accompany all of the films and range from classical to mambo to avant-garde.  Cosponsored with the Cornell Council for the Arts.  More at http://lawrencecjordan.com/

description:
Composers Michael Gordon & Julia Wolfe:
Collaborations w/Filmmaker Bill Morrison

Composers Julia Wolfe (2015 Pulitzer Prize) and Michael Gordon, co-founders of the renowned NYC-based group, Bang on a Can, will join us for a program of 8 short films by archival filmmaker Bill Morrison (DECASIA), for which they composed the soundtracks, including Light Is Calling, a meditation on the nature of random collisions, as seen through the roiling emulsion of an ancient film; music by Michael Gordon; and Porch, in which home movie footage harkens back to when afternoons & evenings were spent on the porch; music by Julia Wolfe and libretto by Deborah Artman.  Visit cinema.cornell.edu for complete program line-up. Cosponsored with the Jewish Studies Program.

description:
Cornell veterinary students and clinical faculty will join volunteer veterinary alumni to offer their first daylong animal wellness clinic in the Bronx at its YMCA on Oct. 8. 

The clinic, at 2 Castle Hill Ave., will see cats from 8 a.m. to noon and dogs from 2-6 p.m. 

Pet owners are asked to enter the building through the back. Pet visits will cost owners a modest fee. 

The program is modeled after a veterinary program that’s been running at Ithaca’s Southside Community Center since 1996. Organized by Cornell parasitologist Dwight Bowman and veterinarians Daniel Fletcher and William Hornbuckle, the clinic allows first- and second-year veterinary students to hone skills that are used during typical wellness visits. 

During the clinic, students will perform wellness visits on pets that may not otherwise have access to veterinary care. Pets diagnosed with any clinical condition are referred to local veterinary practices for further diagnostics and follow-up.   

In the spring, organizers plan to hold the clinic in another New York City borough and hope it will become a regular event.

Inquire for more information, or visit: 

http://www.vet.cornell.edu/services/healthypetbronx.cfm

description: Winner of multiple honors at the Jerusalem Film Festival and the Ophir Awards (Israeli Oscars), including Best Actress and Best Film, The Wedding Doll will screen Wed, Sept 21 & Sun, Sept 25 at 7:15pm The film tells the story of Hagit, a beautiful young woman with a sunny disposition and a mild mental deficiency, who works at a toilet paper factory and lives with her weary mother, a divorcee who struggles to reign in her daughter’s desire for independence while trying to carve out a life for herself. Hagit dreams of her wedding day, adorning her bedroom with magazine pictures of wedding dresses and wedding dolls she makes out of toilet paper. When she thinks that her dream of getting married may finally come true, her life unravels in this bittersweet tale. Learn more at weddingdollthemovie.com where you can watch a trailer!

description:
PLEASE ATTEND the Student Assembly (SA) meeting on Thurs, Oct 8 and show your support for an increase in Cornell Cinema’s (CC) activity fee allocation! We have not received an increase in NINE YEARS (!!) and CANNOT CONTINUE OUR CURRENT LEVEL OF PROGRAMMING WITHOUT ONE. The SA will be voting on their Appropriations Committee’s recommendation (see below) to hold our funding at its current level of $10.60/student and we NEED YOUR HELP to overturn this recommendation, and instead, increase our allocation to $12/student.

PLEASE CONTACT your SA representative before Thursday’s meeting to express your support for this increase. A list of voting members can be found at: http://assembly.cornell.edu/SA/Members

CC has ALREADY MADE SIGNIFICANT CUTS to the operation to accommodate the lack of additional funding from the SA over the past nine years, cope with increases in costs to run the program (inevitable over 9 years), and weather reductions in funding from both external & internal sources due to economic strains at the State & University levels. 

We have also had to deplete our general reserve account to cover the cost of the necessary upgrade to digital cinema, something that benefits all of our viewers and makes it possible for us to do advance screenings of films like STEVE JOBS. 

Nevertheless, the SA Appropriations Committee has recommended level funding for the next two years. THEY ALSO RECOMMEND THAT WE FURTHER CUT THE PROGRAM TO GET BY. In essence, they are proposing that we REDUCE the DIVERSITY of our offerings. 

And all of this even though last year there were close to 11,000 undergraduate admissions to our events, an increase of 1,300 from the year before.

PLEASE HELP US MAINTAIN ONE OF THE MOST PRECIOUS RESOURCES ON THE CORNELL UNIVERSITY CAMPUS!

JOIN US ON THURSDAY! THANKS!!

Rationale of the Appropriations Committee:
“The Appropriations Committee recommends funding Cornell Cinema at $10.60 for the 2016-2018 By-Line Funding Cycle. Although the Committee believes that Cornell Cinema provides some value to students, they do not believe that an increase was justified given current attendance numbers relative to the amount students spent on tickets and the activity fee. Despite significant cost increases, the Committee does not believe it is the Fee’s responsibility to continually and consistently cover the rising cost of doing business within the cinema industry. Moving forward, the Committee suggests that Cornell Cinema determine ways to reduce costs by either more selectively showing screenings, reducing the number of days that Cornell Cinema is open, or find alternative mechanisms to reduce their costs. The Committee appreciates the importance of the cinematic experience to Cornell students, but they question whether or not the current model is sustainable given historical trends to request increases from the activity fee and raise ticket prices.”

For perspective, consider this: the SA currently allocates $18/student to the Slope Day Programming Committee to present a one-day event that costs $350,000. The activity fee allocation covers 70% of this budget. 

Cornell Cinema presents 180 programs/year offered in close to 300 screenings that are presented 5 nights/week during the academic year. CC’s annual operating budget is $485,000, which includes the cost of the infrastructure (staffing, space rental, equipment, etc) needed to run a weekly film program. Our current allocation from the activity fee covers 30% of our budget. If we were to receive the increase we’ve requested ($12/student), the coverage would go up to 33%.

description: Art Majors get in for free to this afternoon's screening! A colorful character who was not only ahead of her time but helped to define it, Peggy Guggenheim was an heiress to her family fortune who became a central figure in the modern art movement. As she moved through the cultural upheaval of the 20th century, she collected not only art, but artists. Her colorful personal history included such figures as Samuel Beckett, Max Ernst, Jackson Pollock, Alexander Calder, Marcel Duchamp as well as countless others. While fighting through personal tragedy, she maintained her vision to build one of the most important collections of modern art, now enshrined in her Venetian palazzo. From the director of the acclaimed documentary Diana Vreeland: The Eye has to Travel. “A sleek, entertaining portrait of the collector and gallerist who assembled one of the great troves of Modern art.” (NY Times) More at peggyguggenheimfilm.com

The new Late Spring calendar begins tonight with a screening of GASLAND at 9:00, being shown in conjunction with the Environmental Law Society Energy Conference: Gas Drilling, Sustainability & Energy Policy: Searching for Common Ground (www.lawschool.cornell.edu/research/els) 

More about the film
2010 > USA > Directed by Josh Fox
Gasland explores the dangers of the natural gas drilling technology of hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," around the country, in our own backyard across the border in Dimmock, PA, and in our future, as we sit upon the massive gas-rich Marcellus Shale. "[T]here's only one conclusion to draw here: No fracking way." (Village Voice)  Nominated for the Best Documentary Academy Award. Cosponsored with the CU Sustainability Hub. Shown in conjunction with the Environmental Law Society Energy Conference: Gas Drilling, Sustainability & Energy Policy: Searching for Common Ground (www.lawschool.cornell.edu/research/ELS/index.cfm). More at gaslandmovie.com Digital Projection
1 hr 47 min

Watch a trailer at:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZe1AeH0Qz8

description:
Visit the Sciencenter—in costume—for this annual free community event. Explore tricked-out exhibits and experience a full line-up of special presentations, demonstrations and activities.

Special Presentations and Demonstrations:

-Creepy Crawly Critters: Meet snakes, spiders and other live, creepy creatures of the night (and day) with Dan the Snakeman.
-Hair-raising Electrical Demon-strations: Zap! These demonstrations will raise the hair on the back of your neck!
-Chemistry Show: Are you prepared for weird science? Local chemists will share tricks and treats of chemistry.
-Grand Finale: Join us outside for a thrilling surprise ending! 

Activities:

-Shaking Skeleton: The leg bone's connected to the hip bone. Piece together a shaking skeleton puppet.
-Bleeding Paper: Use chemistry to make golden paper "bleed" red.
-Screaming Cups and Balloons: Listen to the disembodied screams coming from these crafts.
-Mystery Sand: Discover the mysterious properties of Nano Sand.
-Gummy Worms: Make gooey slimy gummy worms.
-Ghostly Hydrogel: Mix up a surprising concoction and discover its eerie behavior.
- Lung Power:  build a model of your respiratory system and make it breathe on its own power

PLEASE NOTE: The museum will close at 4 pm on Friday, October 28, in preparation for Spooky Science and will reopen from 6 pm to 8:30 pm for the free Halloween community event.

Spooky Science is made possible with the generous support of Kionix

description:
Artist Kiki Smith will speak about her work in printmaking, on view in the current exhibition "Imprint / In Print." This event is supported in part by a grant from the Cornell Council for the Arts.

Kiki Smith is known for her multidisciplinary practice relating to the human condition and the natural world. She uses a broad variety of materials to continuously expand and evolve a body of work that includes sculpture, printmaking, photography, drawing, and textile.

The talk will be followed by a screening of "All About Prints" (54 min.), a documentary produced by the National Gallery of Art that explores the collaborative nature of printmaking, from 19th century masters to contemporary artists.  

The Museum will be tonight until 8:00 p.m.!

2010 > USA > Directed by Lena Dunham
With Lena Dunham, Laurie Simmons, Alex Karpovsky
With a film theory degree, 357 hits on her Youtube page, a boyfriend who's left her to find himself at Burning Man, Aura (played by writer/director Lena Dunham) is at loose ends, having just graduated from Oberlin and moved back home to live with her mom and sister in their Tribeca loft. A familiar situation, and yet Dunham makes it strange, fraught with as much meaning and emptiness as the lives of most recent college graduates. "The movie is full, assured and extremely wry." (Chicago Tribune) More at tinyfurniture.com 35mm 'Scope
1 hr 38 min

description:
What: Two Wheels to Freedom: Ithaca’s First Annual Juried Bike Art Show
When: May 1st to May 31st, 2014 daily 6:30am-8pm
Opening Reception:  Friday May 2nd 5pm-8pm
Cost: Free
Where: Collegetown Bagels, 203 N. Aurora Street, Ithaca NY
Web: http://streetsaliveithaca.com/bike-art-show
 
Contact:  
Victoria Armstrong, 273-8686 varmstrong AT hsctc.org
Katherine Banko, 607-273-0982 
katherine AT collegetownbagels.com

Two Wheels to Freedom, an art show that celebrates the art of the bicycle and the bicycle in art
 
Ithaca, NY (April 16, 2014) – Not so very long ago, John F. Kennedy said “Nothing compares to the simple pleasure of riding a bicycle.”  How true for many people.  And to a surprising number of visual artists, bicycles bring not only pleasure but also creative inspiration. 
 
For the month of May, you can see the output of that inspiration at Two Wheels to Freedom: Ithaca’s First Annual Juried Bike Art Show, showing at Collegetown Bagels downtown on Aurora Street.  The works of eighteen Ithaca-based or Ithaca-connected artists are brought together in a vibrant collection of bicycle themed photographs, prints, and paintings.  You’ll see images of bicycles from around Ithaca and around the world; images of cyclists who go fast, and cyclists who take their time; three tributes to cyclists lost to tragic events; an abstract impression of learning to ride; and numerous celebrations of the feeling of freedom one often gets when out on a bicycle ride.  Included in the show are artists Susan Keough, Robert Grant, Taliah Lempert, Jon Reis, Laura Glenn, Sara Gaechter, Margaret Corbit, Jeanne Leccese, Karen James, Leslie Sandman, Gwen Elizabeth Bullock, Susan Larkin, Rebecca Godin, Jane grace Taylor, Katherine Banko, Molly Bargar, Annamiek Haralson, and Susan Verberg. The opening reception is 5-8pm on Friday May 2nd, as part of Downtown Ithaca’s gallery night.  The show runs from May 1st to May 31st and is open daily from 6:30am to 8pm.
 
Two Wheels to Freedom has a selection committee of five local artists and art organizers, and is coordinated by the Creating Healthy Places Project, which has a mission to help people get more daily activity in their lives.   Just as every participating artist brings their own personal intention to their work, the coordinators bring an intention to the overall show; they hope the art will inspire viewers to enjoy the beauty that can be found in bicycles and be inspired to add more bicycling to their daily lives.
 
This first annual bicycle art show is also one of a number of local events celebrating National Bike Month, including Streets Alive! Ithaca on Sunday May 4th and Bike to Work and School Day on Friday May 16. 
These events are part of the community wide effort to improve conditions and awareness of bicycling as a viable means of transportation:  a green, clean, healthy and beautiful way to get around. 
 
 
INFO: Victoria Armstrong, Creating Healthy Places Project, Human Services Coalition of Tompkins County, 
607-273-8686 or see http://streetsaliveithaca.com/bike-art-show
Also http://collegetownbagels.com/events.php
Also http://gallerynightithaca.wordpress.com/
 
Other Bike Month events:
www.streetsaliveithaca.com
http://ccetompkins.org/calendar

description: The only Studio Ghibli film to never receive a North American release, Only Yesterday is finally screening in celebration of the film’s 25th anniversary! Realizing that she is at a crossroads in her life, bored twenty-something Taeko heads for the countryside. The trip dredges up forgotten childhood memories which unfold in flashback to younger years: the first immature stirrings of romance, the onset of puberty, and the frustrations of math and boys. In lyrical switches between the present and the past, Taeko wonders if she has been true to the dreams of her childhood self. Directed by Isao Takahata (The Tale of the Princess Kaguya) and produced by Hayao Miyazaki, Only Yesterday is a double period piece that beautifully evokes both the 1960s and 1980s, and the quintessential drama of Japanese school-day nostalgia. “Like [Takahata’s] Princess Kaguya, it functions as a highly sensitive and empathetic consideration of the situation of women in Japanese society—but it’s also a breathtaking work of art on its own.” (RogerEbert.com) Shown in original Japanese language with subtitles. 1 hr 58 mins. The film will be repeated on Sunday, March 13 at 4:30pm.
