description:
Are you a senior who’s been accepted to Cornell? Are you a junior considering Cornell, or just want to learn what Shabbat in college is really like? 

If so, we at the Cornell Center for Jewish Living, a student-run organization, invite you to attend our High School Shabbaton from Friday, April 8th to Sunday, April 10th. The Shabbaton itself is completely free—you only need pay for your transportation to Cornell. 

Interested in attending or have any questions whatsoever?
Please email Rachel Blady '13 at vpcomm@cornellcjl.com
If you are reserving a spot for the Shabbaton, please include your name, address, phone number, high school and year. After making reservations, you will be contacted to confirm your attendance and to provide more details about the Shabbaton. 


Why should I visit?
As a Jewish student, Shabbat will play a large an important role in your college experience. No matter what your level of observance, Shabbat is a time to relax, hang out with friends, and just have fun. Because of this, Shabbat is a great time to get a sense of the Jewish community and of the overall university culture—you’ll learn far more about Cornell on this shabbaton then you will by doing online research, etc. In addition, this is a chance to meet potential future classmates and upperclassmen, so you’ll know people and already have friends if you come in August. (Or next August, as it’s not uncommon for students to spend a year in Israel)	

Where will I stay?
Students will have the option of staying in the Center for Jewish Living, which is a privately owned house where many Jewish students live, or to be hosted by first-year students in the freshman dorms. 
 
What will I do? 
Attend services of your choice, join over a hundred students at Shabbat dinner, ask current students any questions on your mind, eat some good food and have a great time! Planned optional activities include a nature walk through Cornell’s amazing waterfalls, Q&A panel with students from different majors, and bowling and a midnight BBQ after Shabbat. 

How do I get there?
For those living in the New York area, driving is the best option. Ithaca is about four hours from New York City. There are also regular buses from New York City, North Jersey, and Long Island—check out shortlinebus.com. For those living a bit farther away, the Ithaca airport is about ten minutes from campus. If you fly in, we’ll be glad to pick you up from the airport. 


Please forward this event to seniors and juniors who are considering universities with vibrant Jewish life. For more information, please feel free to contact us at vpcomm@cornellcjl.com

**Please keep in mind that clicking "attend" on this event does not count as registration. E-mail vpcomm@cornellcjl.com to register.**

description:
Come to this week's Thursday Night Mishmar to hear a special guest speaker, Rabbi Yaakov Yisroel Wenglin, and enjoy what will surely be an entertaining and inspiring evening. Chulent will be provided as usual.

The topic is: The Earnestness of Being Important


Rabbi Yaakov Yisroel Wenglin graduated with a B.A. cum laude in History and Literature from Harvard University and with a JD from the UCLA School of Law, where he was a member of the Law Review and a lead performer in the law school musical all three years. After law school, Rabbi Wenglin joined the Manhattan law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison as a corporate associate, working in their mergers and acquisitions subgroup. The potential of Rabbi Wenglin’s growth towards becoming a partner was tangible, but he ventured to put on hold that success in order to learn more about his Jewish roots. After some years of hard work and growth at Aish, Rabbi Wenglin became a part-time student/part-time staff member of a new yeshiva called Lev Yisrael. Soon thereafter, he became a full-time member of the teaching staff and he was named Director of Education. After filling that role for a year, he was promoted to be Executive Director of the organization, a position that he held for over three years until he determined that the time was right to hit the road and bring his package of talents and experiences to audiences in North America, where he is currently an in-demand guest speaker for college-campus and community-based outreach programs.

This event is partially funded by Cornell SAFC.

description:
A Magical Méliès Evening!

Georges Méliès is the historical figure at the center of Martin Scorsese’s new film, Hugo. The French magician-turned-fantasy-filmmaker made hundreds of magical films at the turn of the century, most notably, Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon) in 1902.

Party plans: 

7:30 pm - 8:45 pm
Scrumptious hors d’oeuvres and desserts, courtesy of some of Ithaca’s finest dining & catering establishments. Complimentary tastings of Meleau specialty wines, courtesy of Frédéric Bouché of Ports of New York   

Cash bar &    Live music

Méliès films screening while guests eat, drink and mingle

Photo ops with a scene from a Méliès film as backdrop! Photographer provided!

Silent Auction:
2 DVD box sets of Georges Méliès: First Wizard of Cinema
4 copies of “The Hugo Movie Companion” autographed    by director Martin Scorsese & editor Thelma Schoonmaker ‘61

8:45 – 9 pm
Drawings for an array of door prizes, including gift certificates from restaurants, wine, tickets for live music & theatre, and two CDs of Le Voyage Dans La Lune, the latest from French electronica duo, AIR    

9 - 9:30 pm
A Trip to the Moon (black & white version) 
With live music by The Electric Golem (Trevor Pinch & James Spitznagel)

A screening of Journey to the Moon, artist/animator William Kentridge’s homage to Méliès

9:30 – 9:45 pm
The Ithaca premiere of the recently restored hand-painted color version of A Trip to the Moon, which was unveiled at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival, with soundtrack by the French electronica duo, AIR. Winner! 2011 National Society of Film Critics: Best Film Restoration!

9:45 – 10:45 pm
The Ithaca premiere of The Extraordinary Voyage (2011), a documentary made by preservationist Serge Bromberg and Eric Lange, charting the film’s voyage across the century and into the next millennium, from the fantastical Méliès production in 1902 to the astonishing rediscovery of a nitrate print in color in 1993 to the premiere of the new restoration at Cannes. Film includes the fascinating and gorgeous history of hand-painted films!

Tickets:
$50 general ($90 a pair)
$30 student ($50 a pair)

Available now at http://cornellcinematickets.com 
Starting Monday, February 27, from 9am – 5pm, 104 Willard Straight Hall

description:
Get in tha Halloween mood vith DRACULA (part of Survey of American Film Series)

Cornell Cinema bids you welcome… Bela Lugosi’s iconic performance as Count Dracula, the culmination of several years' refinement on the theatrical stage, remains a joy to behold on the big screen. With this film, Tod Browning—who would go on to direct the cult classic Freaks (1932)—and his crew set the bar by which all vampire films before or since have come to be measured. The story of Renfield’s naive downward spiral and Dracula’s consequent descent onto London is a familiar one, yet rarely has it been so vividly brought to life (or death, as it were) as in this Universal Pictures gem. With the sole possible exception of F. W. Murnau’s silent Nosferatu (1922), Browning’s masterpiece is without equal in the annals of blood-thirsty cinema. The shadowy cinematography, courtesy of Karl Freund, makes it a quintessential experience that no film lover should miss. Often imitated yet inimitable, parodied yet irresistible, this is where it all began. “It’s almost impossible not to love Dracula, a horror milestone that is the most important and influential vampire movie ever made.” (IMDB) 


SHOWINGS:
Monday, October 3, 7:00, WSH
Tuesday, October 4, 9:15, WSH

description:
EXPLORE "NANO": THE NEW MINI-EXHIBITION
Opens Tuesday, March 6, 10 am-5 pm
Discover a world you can't see and learn about real applications of nanotechnology. Consider the societal and ethical implications of advances in this emerging field. Explore "Nano" at the Sciencenter.

CELEBRATE NANODAYS: THE BIGGEST EVENT FOR THE SMALLEST SCIENCE

NANODAYS AT THE SCIENCENTER
Saturday, March 31, noon-4 pm
Explore the amazing world of nanoscale science and technology at NanoDays 2012 through our NEW interactive Nano Exhibit, 20+ special hands-on activities, and two special presentations including "Horton Hears a Who" (1 pm) and  3D images (2 pm). Admission to the Sciencenter is FREE from 10 am- 5pm for NanoDays! 

Special presentations include:

*  Super Small Storytime: Horton Hears a Who!, in the Curiosity Corner at 1 pm - Listen to Dr. Seuss's story Horton Hears a Who!, make a pair of elephant ears, and experiment with identifying different smells.
*  Showtime Presentation: 3D Images, in the Amphitheater at 2 pm - Find out how we are able to see flat images in 3D and how scientists can use 3D techniques to look at things on the micro and nanoscale.

Hands-on activities include:

* I Spy Nano! - play I Spy to learn about nano in the world around us
* DNA Necklaces - experiment with nano materials that self-assemble as you learn how some things behave differently at the nano-scale
* Iridescent Art & Butterfly - make a butterfly change color
* Graphene - explore how the world's thinnest material can be used as a semi-conductor

For more information visit www.sciencenter.org or call (607) 272.0600.

NANODAYS AT CORNELL UNIVERSITY, DUFFIELD HALL
Sunday, April 1, noon – 4 pm
Ever wonder what a nanoscientist does? Join Cornell University and the Sciencenter for a free public event about nanoscience and technology on campus. Family-friendly activities include: lectures, hands-on programs, learning labs, and limited tours of the Cornell Nanoscience & Technology Facility. Parking available in the Hoy Road Parking Garage (free). Limited handicap parking in front of Phillip Hall. Cornell University, Duffield Hall, Campus Rd & Hoy Rd, Ithaca NY 14850. For more information visit www.ccmr.cornell.edu/education/ or call (607) 255-1486.

NATIONAL COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS AT THE SCIENCENTER
The Sciencenter is part of a nation-wide effort dedicated to developing programs, activities and exhibits that promote awareness of cutting edge science. Our work through the National Collaboratives Department brings the best ideas in museum programming back to our local community. Currently we're focused on Nano, the science of the really, really small. To find out more about nano, visit nano.org.

During February break, the Sciencenter will welcome teachers and their families to explore the museum for free. As part of the city-wide initiative to honor teachers, the Sciencenter invites you to a special presentation and hands-on activities:

Sciencenter Winter Recess Activities
Monday, February 21, through Friday, February 25, at 11 am and 2 pm
Join us for special activities related to our winter exhibition - Fun, 2, 3, 4: all about a number of things! Make a kaleidoscope, play a Native American stick game, explore volume by experimenting with water, food coloring and containers of different shapes and sizes, transform yourself into a giant puzzle, and recreate different 3D shapes using just an index card. 

Sciencenter Showtime! Presentation: "Red Rover, Red Rover-A Mars Update from the Rover Imaging Team" Saturday, February 19, 2 p.m.
Visit the Sciencenter for a behind-the-scenes look at the images, science and human creativity that have made the Mars Exploration Rovers Mission such a success. Using the remarkable photos taken by the Spirit and Opportunity rovers, Melissa Rice from Cornell University will share the inside story of the project—you will be amazed at how much we have learned about Mars from these hard-working robotic explorers!

For more information on how to register for your VIT (Very Important Teacher) pass, visit http://www.ithacalovesteachers.com or contact the Tompkins County Convention and Visitors Bureau, 607.272.1313.

description:
Youth in grades 9 - 12 are invited to explore veterinary medicine through this six-week mini-course for those with a sincere interest in biology, medicine, and animals.  Each session is taught by a different team of Cornell veterinary students, and lessons will incorporate guest presentations by veterinary professors and utilize the vast teaching resources of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine.

Individual classes will focus on a different species group of animals, including cats and dogs, horses, ruminants, exotics and wildlife.  Hands-on activities will include practicing a physical exam, discovering the inner workings of the rumen, handling a wide variety of animals, learning about different anatomy, and getting messy with dissection.

This course will meet on Friday evenings, April 1, 8, 15, 22, 29 & May 6, 6:00-8:00 pm.  

Registration fee of $50 is due by March 18 - space is limited so register early!

More info:
http://ccetompkins.org/calendar/11/02/23/animals-medicine-program

To register:
http://ccetompkins.org/4h/activities-events-0/animals-and-medicine

description:
The students, faculty, and staff of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine invite you, your family and friends to our 45th annual Open House.

Open House is our opportunity to share the joys of our profession with the community. Veterinary students and members of the faculty and staff host this annual event that provides a chance for those interested to get a closer look at veterinary medicine. We invite you to tour our college and learn more about our facilities, our equipment, and what we do everyday.

Students, faculty members, and staff will be on hand to answer your questions about a career as a veterinarian, a veterinary technician, or an animal care specialist. Careers in veterinary medicine have traditionally involved working with dogs, cats, cows, horses, sheep, and pigs. However, this rapidly growing field also provides opportunities to work in the animal health industry, government, armed forces and with many other species in zoos, wildlife refuges, developing countries, and even in everyday practice at your local veterinarian.


SCHEDULE OF ACTIVITIES

Events, Demos, and Tours

Camelids (Alpacas and Chewy the Camel)
Virtual Hospital Tours and Admissions Presentations: (James Law Auditorium)
Ultrasound demos throughout the day
Equine Treadmill
Canine Agility
Police Dog demonstration
Animal Pathology "Show-and-Tell" (Learn gross anatomy and what happens when organ systems fail)

 

Exhibits

We will have a wide range of exhibits for you to enjoy, many back by popular demand!

Visit the petting zoo and play with baby farm animals.
Explore exhibits with exotic pets and wildlife.
Learn how to milk a cow.
Discover more about the anatomy of your pets.
Watch students perform an ultrasound on a dog's heart.
Dress up in surgical scrubs and have your photo taken as a veterinary surgeon.
Visit Teddy Bear ER, where we will surgically repair your wounded stuffed animals with TLC.
See a demonstration of our state of the art performance treadmill used to study orthopedic and cardiovascular diseases of horses.
Watch as our expert farrier fabricate horse shoes throughout the day.
There is much, much more, so please stop by and join the fun!


Lectures

Topics will include public health issues, zoonotic diseases, pet emergencies and first-aid.


STAY TUNED FOR LECTURE TITLES AND TIMES!

 

Admissions Information and Veterinary Career Sessions

For those interested in applying to the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, as well as for those who just want to know more about veterinary education and careers in veterinary medicine, there will be admissions and veterinary career information sessions throughout the day at the following times:

Admission Presentations and Student Panels
10:30am, 12:30pm, 2:30pm
Virtual Hospital Tours
11:30am, 1:30pm, 3:30pm
Location: James Law Auditorium
Friends and Family are welcome


DIRECTIONS


Our doors will open at 10:00 am. Open House lasts until 4:00 pm. Parking and admission are free.

The Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine is at the intersection of Route 366 and Tower Road in Ithaca, New York. Open House visitors should park in the large "O" parking lot just off Tower Road and enter the college through the Veterinary Education Center doors under the open house banner.

From the north: take Route 34 South to Route 13 South to Ithaca; turn onto Buffalo Street; turn right onto Albany Street, turn left onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the northeast: take Route 13 South towards Ithaca; turn left onto Route 366 (by NYSEG); turn right onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the south: take Route 13 North to Ithaca; turn right onto Green Street; turn left onto Route 366; at the Y intersection, bear right; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the east: take Route 79 West to Ithaca, turn right onto Pine Tree Road; continue until 4-way stop sign; turn right onto Route 366; turn left on to Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

From the west: take Route 79 East, Route 96 South, or Route 89 South to Ithaca; after you cross the inlet bridge, turn right onto Fulton (one-way street); at the Route 13/Meadow Street intersection, continue straight across onto Clinton Street; turn left onto Albany Street; turn right onto Green Street; Green Street turns into State Street and continues to be Route 79 East; continue up State Street; bear left onto Mitchell Street; bear left onto Ithaca Street; turn right onto Route 366; turn left onto Tower Road across from Cornell Orchards.

For more information:
Contact Cindy Ryan in the Office of Student and Academic Services
Phone: 607-253-3369 Email: cr227@cornell.edu

http://www.vet.cornell.edu/openhouse/

description:
As most people now know, Seidler was inspired to write the story of King George VI and his stutter because he, himself, was a stutterer as a child and grew up listening to the King give his inspiring speeches on the radio during WWII. In addition, during his research on the project, Seidler discovered that his own uncle, also a stutterer, was treated by speech therapist Lionel Logue. Seidler will be at Cornell Cinema to introduce The King’s Speech and take questions afterwards on April 12th.

Nominated for 12 Academy Awards, the film took home Oscars for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor and Best Original Screenplay, written by Cornell alum David Seidler '59. More at kingsspeech.com 35mm

description:
Amy McNair, professor of Chinese art at the University of Kansas, will discuss “Empress of Fire: The Extravagant Constructions of Empress Hu.” This annual lecture on Asian art is funded by a generous gift from Judith Stoikov ’63.

Professor McNair has focused her extensive study of the Buddhist caves at Longmen, in central China, on the patrons and matrons whose commissions from the fifth through eighth centuries created this great monument. Her talk examines the life and impact on Longmen of Empress Hu (ca. 493-528), one of the most powerful imperial characters of the Northern Wei dynasty, who dedicated a grotto at Longmen that is now known as Huoshao, “the grotto destroyed by fire.”

The Museum is open tonight until 8:00 p.m. Admission to the Museum and this lecture is free!

description:
with filmmaker Jim Mickle, and post-screening discussion facilitated by Hugues Barbier, programmer of the Strasbourg Fantastic Festival in France.

Set in a post-apocalyptic world after a vampire epidemic has ravaged the country, the film follows a recently-orphaned boy (Paolo) who is taken in by a grizzled vampire hunter known only as Mister (co-writer Nick Damici). Together they navigate the deserted towns of northeastern America, trying to make their way to rumored safe havens in Canada,  taking in a nun (played by Kelly McGillis) and two other young survivors along the way. But the path towards possible safety is fraught with not only vampires, but a cadre of well-armed religious fanatics determined to rule the earth in the new era.  From emerging horror auteur Jim Mickle, Stake Land is an entertaining low-budget horror flick with laughs (and fangs) around every corner. "Highly cinematic, pitch-perfect yarn should take a sizable bite out of the genre box office during its 2011 release....." (Variety) Winner of the Midnight Madness Award at the recent Toronto Film Festival. more at scareflix.net/stakesite.html Digital Projection
2010, color, 1 hour 36 minutes, USA

Mickle studied film production at NYU, writing and directing three award winner short films. He has worked professionally as a storyboard artist, a lighting technician, a 3D animator, and film editor, gathering over forty credits to his name. He first toured the festival circuit with The Underdogs, where he worked with actor Nick Damici. A few years later, Mickle and Damici wrote Mulberry Street, Mickle’s feature directorial debut that earned critical acclaim in festivals and among horror aficionados all over the world. It screened in 25 major interntaional festivals including Tribeca and South by Southwest, and in 2007 took home a coveted Audience Award at Fantasia. It later won Best Film as the opening night gala film at the Toronto After Dark Film Festival. Stake Land, which was co-written by and stars Damici, continues the duo's exploration of the darker aspects of American culture by reimagining traditional elements of horror.

description: Cornell Cinema welcomes filmmaker Deborah Stratman on Friday at 7:15 with her unconventional documentary O'ER THE LAND, a meditation on national identity, gun culture, wilderness, consumption, patriotism and the possibility of personal transcendence. Woven throughout the film is the story of Col. William Rankin, who in 1959 was forced to eject from his F8U fighter jet at 48,000 feet without a pressure suit, only to get trapped for 45 minutes in the up and down drafts of a massive thunderstorm, and survive. The film had its world premiere at the Sundance Film Festival, 2009, and its European premiere at the Rotterdam International Film Festival, 2009. Shown with Ray’s Birds (2010, 7 minutes), an homage to Ray Lowden, who keeps seventy-two large birds of prey, five deer and some wallabies at his place in Northumberland, England. Deborah Stratman is a Chicago-based artist and filmmaker interested in landscapes and systems. Her films, rather than telling stories, pose a series of problems - and through their at times ambiguous nature, allow for a complicated reading of the questions being asked. Most recently, they have questioned elemental historical narratives about freedom, expansion, security, and the regulation of space. She is the recipient of Fulbright and Guggenheim fellowships and she currently teaches at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

Patrons are also welcome to bring picnic dinners. Doors will open at 8:15pm and the film will start at 9:30pm, after dark. These tickets will be held at the “will call” table for pickup the night of the show. Any tickets unclaimed by 9:15pm may be resold. Credit cards cannot be used at the door. Terrace shows typically sell-out in advance, so patrons are encouraged to plan accordingly! Added enticement: drawings for three pairs of Cornell Cinema guest passes will be held at the show. description:
A dazzling abstract play of sights and sounds created by two 35 millimeter film projectors!

“Though the live-cinema piece takes place within a stable set of parameters, it will never be the same twice; it will always be a re-presentation rather than a repetition….” (Erika Balsom, Art Forum)

Tickets are $10 general, and $8 students and the performance will be followed by a Q & A with the artists.

Sandra Gibson & Luis Recoder have collaborated on various expanded cinema projects since 2000. Their performances and installations have taken place at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Sundance, Serralves Foundation in Porto, Oberhausen Film Festival, and Viennale in Vienna. Their work was recently referenced in the Art Forum article Live and Direct: Erika Balsom on Cinema as a Performing Art (September 2014).
 
The program at Cornell Cinema will be a live collaborative cinematic work that reflects and refracts the role of projectionist-as-performer in the standard theatrical projection of the 35mm changeover system. Two projectionists perform within the cinema theater to critically unmask the otherwise masked cinematic apparatus in a dazzling abstract play of sights and sounds. The dual-projection changeover system in which two identical 35mm projectors alternate back-and-forth in their restorative reassembly of feature-length films provides the theatrical platform and oblique precursor to historical movements in the field of Expanded Cinema.
 
Cosponsored with the Cornell Council for the Arts

description: Mary Lorson, a musician, composer and dramatist, grew up in the 60s and 70s in Westchester County, NY, land of corporate plenty... and plenty of dysfunction. For her performance memoir Signals, she sets some of her family anecdotes to contemporary music, and takes turns narrating and singing these tales, backed up by an eight-piece jazz/rock band. Lorson (vocals, guitar, piano, percussion) began her career over twenty years ago as the lead singer of Madder Rose, and since then has fronted the jazzy artrock group Saint Low and the trio the Soubrettes, scored several films with Billy Cote, and collaborated on other dramatic and musical projects. A visual backdrop will accompany the show.

description:
Part of Fantastic Film Friday!

There is a love story at the heart of Bellflower, but the flesh and bone around it is made up of the apocalypse—or the desire for it. The two guys in the movie spend all their time, when they are not chasing girls, preparing for the end of the world: constructing flame throwers, custom cars, and other oddities. “[Glodell] also custom built the camera he used to shoot the movie along with many of the film’s weird gadgets and weapons. Like any mad scientist worth his salt, Glodell occasionally loses control of his creation. But that’s what we like to see mad scientists do: invent something truly crazy and brilliant and watch it crash and burn, in this case, by a flamethrowing muscle car called The Medusa. Glodell built that thing too.” (IFC.com) more at bellflower-themovie

Check out the trailer here! http://www.bellflower-themovie.com/trailer/

description: The latest film by experimental maker Bill Morrison (Decasia) is a meditation on contemporary art, technology, and other themes through the lens of the Frankenstein story. Working with new, archival, and distressed footage, Morrison developed the film in collaboration with two-time Grammy-nominated jazz musician Dave Douglas while the two were in residence at Stanford University. Douglas's original score will be performed by his electric band Keystone (a sextet with trumpet, tenor/soprano sax, rhodes, electric bass, drums, and turntables), which was created to work with films. The result is a stunning multimedia piece evoking the complexity and detail of the story's intertwining narratives, which unfolds with a score that is at times bucolic and others explosive. Cosponsored with the Cornell Council for the Arts and the Atkinson Forum in American Studies. Advance tickets available at dansmallspresents.com and CornellCinemaTickets.com and starting Saturday, January 29 downtown at Ithaca Guitar Works and starting Monday, January 31 from the Cornell Cinema Office, 104 Willard Straight Hall, from 9am-5pm. More at imnworld.com/davedouglas

description: Yakov Protazanov’s Aelita: Queen of Mars (1924) is a classic Soviet sci-fi silent film that will be shown with an original score performed live by local musicians Anna Coogan and Tzar (Michael Stark & Brian Wilson), who recently delivered a knock-out score/performance with Jean Epstein’s The Fall of the House of Usher (1928) as part of the Ithaca International Fantastic Film Festival. Wrought with subtle erotic tensions and national predilections of the moment, the Martian adventure is known for its incredible leaps of fantasy running parallel to documentary-style depictions of 1920s Moscow. Love crosses light years in this popular Russian classic featuring fantastic constructivist set designs! Advance tickets are $11 general/$9 students & seniors, and door prices will be $15 general/$13 students & seniors. 2010 > Thailand > Directed by Apichatpong Weerasethakul
With Thanapat Saisaymar, Sakda Kaewbuadee, Matthieu Ly
This haunting and achingly beautiful film from acclaimed Thai director Weerasethakul traces the past, present, and future lives of its titular protagonist as he faces terminal illness. Winner of the coveted Palme d'Or at Cannes, the film paints a beautiful palette of Buddhist realities, blending the tangible and intangible, the animal and the human. Subtitled. description:
Save the date and come out to explore the amazing world of nanoscience and nanotechnology through hands-on activities, family-friendly presentations, and special exhibits. 

Sciencenter admission is FREE all day on Saturday, April 2, from 10 am to 5 pm, with the NanoDays celebration running from 12-4 pm. NanoDays will continue at the Wilson Lab at Cornell University on Sunday, April 3, 12-4 pm.

Join us to celebrate NanoDays and investigate super-thin, flexible solar cells, encounter forces stronger than gravity, make a butterfly change color with the touch of a button, and play with sand that doesn't get wet, even under water! Other activities include using your nose as a nanodetector and trying out the special clothing real nanoscientists wear when they study and make tiny things. 

NanoDays is cosponsored by the Sciencenter and Cornell University.

For more complete event information visit: http://www.sciencenter.org/programs/nanoday.asp

description:
The year 1761 marks the creation of veterinary education and the veterinarian profession, and 2011 has been declared the " World Veterinary Year ".

The world's first veterinary school was founded in Lyon, France, in 1761, shortly followed by the Alfort Veterinary School, near Paris, in 1764, both of them at the initiative of Claude Bourgelat.

In the context of the World Veterinary Year, Alfort Veterinary School has the honour to organise the official Opening Ceremony, the 24th of January 2011.

We have chosen Versailles, the place where the king Louis the 15th has approved the creation of the two first Veterinary Schools. 

The Official Opening Ceremony of the World Veterinary Year will take place in the "Palais des Congrés" of Versailles, France, Monday, the 24th of January 2011. The President of the World Veterinary Association, the General Directors of the World Animal Health Organisation, the World Health Organisation, the Food and Agriculture Organisation and IUCN - International Union for Conservation of Nature will attend this ceremony.


Fore more information and to register:
http://resa.netbba.com/enva/index_GB.php

description:
We are excited to start the new year with our first ever combined SEEN and Green Drinks event at the Carriage House Cafe in Ithaca, NY.  We will be gathering in the beautifully restored second floor known affectionately as The Hayloft.  This warm rustic space now has a fireplace with comfortable seating.  You will find local beers and wines at the newly restored bar.

Green Drinks
As with all Green Drinks events, this event is free and open to the public.  There will be a cash bar.  Stop by anytime between 7 and 10pm.  Please pass this invite out to sustainability-minded friends, family, and colleagues.

The SEEN
You will also have a chance to see and give feedback on the newly developed website for the SEEN.  In the back, this beta site will be displayed on a few laptops.  Bob Rossi and other SEEN leaders will be there to answer questions and take suggestions.  

 
National Day of Service
In 1994, congress passed the King Holiday & Service Act designating MLK Day as a national holiday for MLK volunteer service.   This holiday saw a boost in volunteerism two years ago when President Obama took office.  We commend anyone who has observed this day of service today, but we also want to remind everyone that there's still time!  In fact, there's always time.  Service is not an annual event. Perhaps the best service you can do today is to consider how to serve your community every day. One Kingly approach would be to consider the injustices around you, and then to address them in at least some small way throughout the year.  If you have ideas or want ideas, come to Green Drinks next Tuesday and let's spark some conversation around this topic.

We look forward to seeing you next Tuesday!

The Green Resource Hub

Green Resource Hub is a non-profit organization that aims to expand the marketplace for sustainable living in the Finger Lakes region. The SEEN is one of many programs that we offer in pursuit of this mission.
name: SEEN and Green Drinks

description:
Stop in and see the work by our current exhibiting artist Michelle Kizer.  As she presents a new show Titled: Thoughts in Color until the end of February.

Description: By using simplistic body language and nuancing this with varied painting styles and color schemes, this series challenges you to look beyond your first perceptions of the figures and titles. This is particularly important when connecting with women of color, whose emotions and standards of beauty continue to be policed by mainstream culture. Ask yourself, what is the story behind each woman, and how do “acceptable” emotional responses and standards of beauty preclude us from valuing them. Enjoy!

Artist Statement: Art has always been an integral part of my expression and healing process. As an artist from Brooklyn, New York, I have experienced and seen the heartbreaking struggles of ordinary people. My most powerful works encourage others to embrace the pain in their lives and transform it into something beautiful. 

For more information & to see other works, visit michellekizer.carbonmade.com

Imagine exploring a watershed by diving into your backyard creek and taking an underwater journey all the way to the ocean. Embark on a journey through watersheds to see how everyone's actions affect the health of our ocean at "Ocean Bound!", the New Exhibition at the Sciencenter. Enjoy interacting with 3-D watershed models, piloting a full-size submersible from mountain stream to ocean, guiding water safely through a hazardous maze, diverting pollutants as they travel through storm-water drains, playing with early education exhibits inside a clubhouse, and many more engaging interactive exhibits.

"Ocean Bound!" is made possible with the generous support of M&T Bank.

Friday, May 6, 7:30

Directed by Quentin Dupieux
With Stephen Spinella, Jack Plotnick, Wings Hauser
Robert is an abandoned tire (yes, tire, as in Goodyear) who suddenly and mysteriously comes to life in the desert.  After learning he possesses a strange telepathic power that allows him to destroy anything he thinks about, he begins preying on small desert creatures and other discarded items.  But he soon sets his sights on a desert town, specifically a beautiful and mysterious woman with whom he's obsessed, leaving a wake of destruction across the desert in his pursuit. .  "A film brimming with comic brilliance and manic originality." (Cinematical) In English. More at rubberfilm.com Digital Projection

Celebrate health, the human body, and our amazing ability to heal at "The Healer Within," the new fall exhibition at the Sciencenter. Become a virtual white blood cell on a mission through the body to hunt for and destroy pathogens. Play doctor and test how your heart responds to electrical circuits by taking your own EKG. Create music and feel music’s healing effects on the human body and mind. Learn about biofeedback loops in the body as you become a skateboard star, or explore blood pressure as you "pump it up." Included with admission.

For more information visit: http://www.sciencenter.org/exhibits/featuredexhibition.asp

description:
"Cinema Under the Stars" - four classic films outdoors on the Willard Straight Terrace, all with a cash bar, complimentary snacks and a great view! The series continues with Wes Anderson’s MOONRISE KINGDOM. Patrons are also welcome to bring picnic dinners. Doors will open at 8:15pm and films will start at 9:30pm, after dark. In the event of rain, screenings will be held in Willard Straight Theatre. Tickets are $13 general/$11 students & seniors and can be purchased in advance at CornellCinemaTickets.com. These tickets will be held at the “will call” table for pickup the night of the show. Any tickets unclaimed by 9:15pm may be resold. Credit cards cannot be used at the door. Terrace shows typically sell-out in advance, so patrons are encouraged to plan accordingly! Added enticement: drawings for three pairs of Cornell Cinema guest passes will be held at each show (see remaining line-up below). For more information call (607) 255-3522.

Wednesday, June 29
Moonrise Kingdom (2012)
Directed by Wes Anderson
Set on an island off the coast of New England in the 1960’s, Moonrise is a romantic fantasia of young love, both funny and bittersweet, capturing the dreams of youth and the disappointments of age. “Gorgeously shot, ingeniously crafted, [an] über-Andersonian bonbon.” (Slate)
1 hr 34 mins

Wednesday, July 13 
Strangers on a Train (1951)
Directed by Alfred Hitchcock
Considered by some to be the best of Hitchcock’s American films, Strangers on a Train, adapted from a Patricia Highsmith novel, is a chilling comedy.
1 hr 41 mins

Wednesday, July 27 
Top Hat (1935)
Directed by Mark Sandrich
Perhaps one of Fred Astaire’s & Ginger Roger's best, most well-coordinated and tastefully executed films; Top Hat is a film filled with mixed-up identities and madcap high-jinks, featuring fantastic Art Deco sets and a wonderful Irving Berlin score. 
1 hr 48 mins

description:
Join the CJL, the Japan-US Association (JUSA), the A Capella Advisory Council, and Cornell Hillel for a special dinner to help the victims of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan. Come hear about the experiences of Japanese students and faculty and listen to music from some of Cornell's premier A Capella groups.

For every person who attends Shabbat dinner, over $12.00 will be donated to the American Red Cross, which will help support Japanese relief efforts. If you are interested in pledging money for the cause, please visit our page at www.cornellcjl.com/charityshabbat.

CHECK-IN: 6:30PM
DINNER: 7:15PM
RESERVATION: www.campuslife.cornell.edu/campuslife/dining/104west

===================================
===================================

Center for Jewish Living (CJL)
http://www.cornellcjl.com/
(607)-272-5810
	
The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University is an independent, student-run organization catering to the needs of Cornell's Jewish community. It serves as a residence hall and community center for Cornell's Jewish students.

===================================
===================================

Japan - United States Association (JUSA)
http://rso.cornell.edu/jusa/
cu.jusa@gmail.com
	
The purpose of JUSA is to provide a venue for recognition and celebration of the Japanese culture and of the Japan-United States relations. In order to attain these goals, JUSA strives to:

-- provide information regarding the Japanese culture and Japan-United States relations to the general populace
-- promote interaction amongst Cornell students of all background through the promotion of the aforementioned topics
-- offer support and resources for the Japanese, Japanese-American and Japanese interest community at Cornell University.

===================================
===================================

A Cappella Advisory Council (ACAC)
http://www.rso.cornell.edu/acac/events.html
lcs78@cornell.edu

The fundamental goals of the A Cappella Advisory Council are to establish a more convenient and formalized means by which a cappella groups may communicate in order to eliminate conflicts, share resources, and coordinate events and to foster a sense of community and amiability among the University's a cappella organizations without compromising the individual identity of each group. 

===================================
===================================

Cornell Hillel
http://cornell.hillel.org/
hillel@cornell.edu

Hillel's mission is to enrich the lives of Jewish undergraduate and graduate students so that they may enrich the Jewish people and the world. Cornell Hillel embraces this mission by seeking to provide positive and purposeful Jewish experiences that are relevant to the lives of students. At the foundation of Cornell Hillel is a commitment to excellence, innovation, accountability and results.

description:
Thinking of places to live next year?

The CJL is having its annual housing lottery on Sunday, Nov. 13!!

Participants in the housing lottery will get preference in room selection. In addition, preference is given to those who are CJL members, current/former house residents, or CJL board members according to a point system.

What are some of the benefits of living in the CJL? 
*Friendly, welcoming environment with your current and soon-to-be friends
*Convenient location right outside of Campus and C-Town and adjacent to 104 West! Dining Hall
*Great amenities, including Cable TV in every room, free laundry (2 sets of machines), and HDTV big screen
*Cheaper than Cornell Dorms (and most C-town apartments)!
*Large rooms

In addition, there will be an open house taking place at 106 West (in the House) on Sunday November 6. Feel free to stop by anytime between 12:00PM - 4:00PM to check out the house, the rooms, the people, and whatever else you may have questions about. 

If you would like to participate in the housing lottery, or would like any more information about pricing, the point system, or anything else, please contact Victor Haas, CJL House Manager (housing@cornellcjl.com).

description:
Remember when you were a freshman and just getting a handle on the Cornell Jewish community?  Maybe you were at Freshman Fest, talking to all sorts of people you didn't know about Jewish camps they all attended without you, and maybe you had absolutely no idea what the heck the Center for Jewish Living was, or what awesome people it contained.  Then, all of a sudden, a group of hungry CJL-ers ready to eat Hillel's BBQ food and be friendly showed up at the Freshman Fest ropes course and maybe you got into a conversation about Cornell or about you, maybe you found some things in common, and maybe you got just a little bit more comfortable with the whirlwind of Jewish life that is the CJL!  

And even if you never had this experience, come make it happen for incoming freshmen at Hillel's Freshman Fest!  We will show up en masse, eat dinner, get a little Mincha-Maariv, and start building connections with the newest Jews at Cornell!  They're cool people!  We will meet them!  Also, free Hillel food!  

If you can drive to this, please tell a programmer (pmf46 or maa245)!

description:
“In addition to being a funny, invigorating and inspirational ode to being the cleverest kid in the room, it’s a remarkable testament to the suspension of disbelief.” (The Guardian) In A Space Program, acclaimed artist Tom Sachs takes us on an intricately handmade journey to the red planet, providing audiences with an intimate, first person look into his studio and methods. The film is both a piece of art in its own right and a recording of Sachs’ incredible installation/performance, Space Program 2.0: MARS, which opened at New York’s Park Avenue Armory in 2012. For Space Program 2.0: MARS, Tom and his team built an entire space program guided by the philosophy of bricolage: something constructed or created from a diverse range of available things. They ultimately sent two female astronauts to Mars in search of the answer to humankind’s ultimate question… are we alone? “The result is something like the best science-fair project ever, an inviting performance piece that tasks viewers with the pleasurable, imaginative engagement that more seamless special effects deny.” (Village Voice) More at aspaceprogram.com

Come at 6:30pm for a retro space food reception sponsored by the Art Majors Organization, followed by the 7pm screening. In addition, the first 30 art majors get in for free courtesy of the Dept. of Art!!

description:
On Saturday October 29, Cornell Cinema offers one of the greatest of all horror films as well as a recent spoof on the genre. Arrive in costume to the theatre and only pay $2!

Tucker & Dale vs. Evil - 7:15 WSH
2011 > USA > Directed by Eli Craig
With Tyler Labine, Alan Tudyk, Katrina Bowden
Tucker and Dale want nothing more than to enjoy their vacation in the woods. Unfortunately, a gaggle of preppy coeds have mistaken them for crazed killers and will stop at nothing to confirm their suspicions - even if it means unwittingly paring down their numbers in the process. Shaun of the Dead meets Joe Dirt. What more could you want? More at magnetreleasing.com/tuckeranddalevsevil 35mm 'Scope

The Shining - 9:15 WSH
1980 > USA > Directed by Stanley Kubrick
With Jack Nicholson, Shelley Duvall
The consummate contemporary horror flick about a guy who moves his family to a big creepy hotel in the middle of winter, types the same thing over and over on his typewriter and then goes totally, utterly, and completely nutso. Digital Projection
2 hrs 22 min

description: A colorful character who was not only ahead of her time but helped to define it, Peggy Guggenheim was an heiress to her family fortune who became a central figure in the modern art movement. As she moved through the cultural upheaval of the 20th century, she collected not only art, but artists. Her colorful personal history included such figures as Samuel Beckett, Max Ernst, Jackson Pollock, Alexander Calder, Marcel Duchamp as well as countless others. The first 40 art students get in for free to the 7pm screening of the documentary on March 3rd, courtesy of the Department of Art and the Art Majors Organization. All patrons are invited to come at 6:30pm to enjoy complimentary tea & cookies before the show. The documentary will be repeated on Sunday, March 6 at 4:30pm. Ticket info at cinema.cornell.edu. More about the film at peggyguggenheimfilm.com

description:
The good news:  You're done with finals!!  
The bad news: You can't get home before the sun goes down!  

It's not actually bad news.  We are going to miss you like crazy over the summer (forever for some of you, let's be honest), so won't you give us one more chance to see your smiling face for just one more weekend?  

Stranded Shabbat- a little messy, a little sleepy, a little crazy...a lot of fun!  

So we're going to organize meals and stuff.  Who's here, who wants to feed people?  We're thinking to get Friday night together centrally at the house and then doing a light lunch and then farming people out to those folks who love cooking for 3rd meals.  

But that all depends on who's here.  If you're awesome and want to show up for all or part of the Shabbat, or want to feed us, or some of us, come on down!  Don't be shy!  It's Stranded Shabbat.  There is no fear in Stranded.

description: No, Hitchcock and Truffaut won't be joining us in person, BUT, co-producer & editor Rachel Reichman will, along with director Kent Jones (via Skype) for a post-screening Q & A that will be moderated by Andrew Utterson, Asst. Prof of Screen Studies at Ithaca College. The documentary recounts a series of interviews that Truffaut wrangled with the master of suspense in 1962. The result changed the perception of Hitch from genius hack to brilliant auteur. Jones mixes the original tapes with clips from the films and interviews of contemporary directors, including Wes Anderson, David Fincher and Martin Scorsese. “Smart, thoughtful and elegantly done, …a love letter to film itself, to the value and lure of the cinematic experience.” (LA Times) Kent Jones is also the Director of the New York Film Festival. The film will screen a second time, without guests, on Thursday, March 17 at 9:15pm.

description:
From an immersive laser-light environment by Matthew Schreiber to restored WPA murals from Roosevelt Island …

From the East Asian cultural sphere to interactions across Thai generations by Rirkrit Tiravanija and Korakrit Arunanondchai, plus a survey of work by Cornell’s art faculty ... don’t miss our five new exhibitions!  

As part of the opening reception, join us at 5:15 PM for artist Matthew Schreiber in conversation with Johnson Museum curator Andrea Inselmann.  

The Museum will be open tonight until 8:00 PM, and every Thursday night through May 5. Admission to the Museum and this event is free.

description:
Come join us this First Friday of October for the opening celebration of Tommy Beers's exhibit of paintings from rural upstate New York.  Accompanied by musical guests Harry Aceto & Friends.

Artist's Statement:

I have lived in Ithaca since 1988. I helped raise a family and now have some of said family as well as grandchildren living here. I’ve been drawing and painting for over 40 years but recently have had the opportunity to do so in a more concentrated manner. Some of the results of this work are now on display. 

What you can expect is simply an appreciation and documentation of the mostly rural world around us, albeit from a working class point of view. All paintings are done within the February to September period of time this year. A majority of the pieces are from the Finger Lakes area; I visited a North Carolina beach in June so there's a few paintings from that trip as well.

I’m very interested in where the sky meets the earth as it reminds me that we are spiritual beings in a material world. I stay close to the ground on a bicycle. All of the work comes from sightings or paintings done from this intimate rolling contact with our surroundings.

Thanks for viewing,
tommy

description:
Take a breath before study week begins with a number of films at Cornell Cinema. Featured films are The Debt, Friends with Benefits and The Future. 

The Debt, playing at 7:00 PM at Uris Hall. 
2011, color, 1 hour 54 minutes, USA
In this remake of the 2007 Israeli film of the same name, director Madden (Shakespeare in Love) jumps between the present and the past, circa 1965, to tell the story of three Mossad agents who were tasked to capture a Nazi war criminal: a doctor who performed brutal experimental surgery on prisoners in the concentration camps. Mirren and Chastain play the elder and younger Rachel, the most compelling of the Mossad agents. And indeed much of the film's drama depends on the considerable acting talents of these two women, and upon the interplay between the younger and older characters. "The younger actors are more idealistic, more sexually alive, more charged with the shifting dynamics of their missions. The older cast are more dour and tightly wound, carrying the weight of history and high positions atop a foundation of lies, doubt, fear and regret. And whichever trio of actors worked first, you get the sense that all six performances are knit into a single fabric; it's impossible, in effect, to see the three young agents and not see the shadows of the older characters, and vice versa." (Portland Oregonian) The result is a complex series of character studies wrapped up within a thriller of surprising moral weight.

Friends with Benefits, playing at 9:30 PM at Uris Hall. 
2011, color, 1 hour 49 minutes, USA
In the newest film from Cornell alum and Easy A director Will Gluck '93, Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis star as Dylan and Jamie, two friends who, despite the attraction they feel for one another, aren't ready for a new relationship. Instead, they decide it's best to keep things purely physical, a plan which turns out to be much easier said than done. "Friends with Benefits is fast, allusive, urban, glamorous—clearly the Zeitgeist winner of the summer." (The New Yorker)

The Future, playing at 9:45 PM at Willard Straight Hall. 
2011, color, 1 hour 31 minutes, Germany/USA
A couple, comprised of two misfits, adopts a stray, maligning cat in order to spice up their lackluster lives. As the cat convalesces, the two of them seize the opportunity to do all the things they thought they didn't have time for before they got the wounded cat. July (of Me, You, and Everyone We Know fame) launches her characters - including the cat - into a dizzyingly cute period of introspection and reflection which changes their perspectives, their ways of life, and the trajectory of time itself. If it sounds funny and far-fetched, that's because it is. As The Onion cryptically put it, "The Future is elliptical, but never shaggy."

description: Photographer and filmmaker Don Freeman explores the handmade homes created and lived in by eleven distinguished American artists, shedding light on a unique architectural typology characterized by a D.I.Y. aesthetic, the appropriation of building techniques from art practice, and a fierce spirit of individual expression that deserves deeper examination in this age of architectural standardization. The film reveals the inventiveness derived from the dialogue between each artist's practice and the construction of their handmade homes. The results range from the romantic (Hudson River School painter Frederic Church's Olana, framing views of the Catskills to echo his paintings), to the futuristic (Urbanist Paolo Soleri's silt-casted structure Cosanti growing out of experiments in bell making in the Arizona desert). Commentary from cultural critic Alastair Gordon and an original score by Jamie Rudolph help to evoke the spiritual dimension of the locations and argue the case that the intuitive vision of artists can create great architecture. Featuring the hand-built homes of George Nakashima, Henry Chapman Mercer, Wharton Esherick, Paolo Soleri, Byrdclife Arts Colony, Frederic Church, Henry Varnum Poor, Russel Wright, Raoul Hague and Eliphante. More at arthousethefilm.com

“Truly one of the most beautiful Technicolor films ever made!” according to Martin Scorsese, and clearly a film that influenced Darren Aronofsky’s Black Swan, this spectacularly restored print of The Red Shoes is a must see for older fans as well as new viewers who have never before experienced Powell and Pressburger’s masterpiece on the big screen. Based on Hans Christian Andersen’s tale of shoes that dance the wearer to death, the film features real-life ballerina Moira Shearer in a legendary (and original) 17-minute ballet of the title story. “The UCLA restoration does full justice to what has to be one of the most exquisite color films ever made, filled with the kinds of deep, vivid hues that will leave viewers literally gasping.” (Kenneth Turan, LA Times) Restored by UCLA Film & Television Archive in Association with the BFI, The Film Foundation, ITV Global Entertainment Ltd., and Janus Films.

With Ernst Deutsch, Erna Morena, Roma Bahn
Fresh from screenings at the Telluride and New York Film Festivals, the Alloy Orchestra performs yet another astonishing original score to a recently rediscovered and restored silent German Expressionist film that rivals The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari with its wild expressionist sets and bizarre acting. Based on a play of the same name, the film tells the story of a bank cashier in a small German town who falls prey to the allure of money after his encounter with a rich Italian women. He embezzles 60,000 Marks and heads to the capital city, where he attempts to find escape from the monotony of his bourgeois life. Advance tickets available at CornellCinemaTickets.com, from the Ithaca Guitar Works starting Saturday, October 29, and from the Cornell Cinema Office, 104 Willard Straight Hall (9am-5pm) starting Monday, October 31. description:
Starting at 9:00 PM at WSH. Tickets are $12, or $9 for students or seniors. 

A program of ten landmark early shorts – some favorites, others unfamiliar – produced between 1902 and 1927. Following Edwin S. Porter's curtain-raiser, Dream of the Rarebit Fiend from 1906, the program proceeds in chronological order with many of the shorts separated by vintage hand-painted slides created for use in movie theaters a century ago. The selections include Red Spectre, The Acrobatic Fly, The Thieving Hand, Princess Nicotine, Artheme Swallows His Clarinet, The Cameraman's Revenge, The Pet, Filmstudie, and The Life and Death of 9413, a Hollywood Extra. All accompanied by the wild, weird and wonderful Alloy Orchestra! Advance tickets available at CornellCinemaTickets.com, from the Ithaca Guitar Works starting Saturday, October 29, and from the Cornell Cinema Office, 104 Willard Straight Hall (9am-5pm) starting Monday, October 31. description:
This event is free and open to all. From dusk to dawn El Velador accompanies Martin, the guardian angel whom, night after night, watches over the extravagant mausoleums of some of Mexico's most notorious Drug Lords. In the labyrinth of the cemetery, this film about violence without violence reminds us how, in the turmoil of Mexico's bloodiest conflict since the Revolution, ordinary life persists and quietly defies the dead. 
 
"The Mexican drug cartels have inspired countless films, but never one as final as Natalia Almada's documentary EL VELADOR. After this experience, everything else seems trivial." —Roger Ebert, Chicago Sun Times

Cosponsored with the Latin American Studies Program, the Dept. of Performing & Media Arts and Cornell Cinema

More at icarusfilms.com

description:
Oktoberfest celebrates the harvest season with a great outdoor tasting market of all things Bavarian! TICKETS ON SALE NOW (Limited Number Sold)

Downtown Ithaca Alliance and Kilpatrick’s Pub host samplings of Finger Lakes wines and beers as well as tasty morsels from local restaurants and food vendors at the Third Annual Ithaca Oktoberfest – October 25 – 12-5pm in Downtown Ithaca on the 200 block of North Aurora Street. The Ithaca Oktoberfest is a celebration of a rich harvest season complete with live music, sampling from regional breweries, wineries and farmers, as well as local food vendors. Come celebrate the fall season in style at this ticketed tasting event in Downtown Ithaca.

To Purchase Tickets:
Advance purchase tickets may be purchased with cash or credit card at the Downtown Ithaca Alliance office or over the phone by calling 607-277-8679 (starting October 1st). Tickets will be available for pick up on October 25 in the express line upon presentation of identification (over 21). Tickets can be purchased the day of as well.  Tickets are $15 for 10 drink samples and 5 food samples. Larger food portions will be available for purchase.

Local favorite microbreweries will be competing in the Oktoberfest championship for best beer. The first Champion of the “Oktobercup” was Cortland Beer Company in 2012 followed by Hopshire Farm Brewery in 2013. Back to defend the title of best brew Hopshire will be featuring its 100% New York State produced brew BeeHave Honey Blond Ale.  Other great featured Beverages will be . . . Bandwagon Brewpub – German Style Marzenbier/Oktoberfest, Bacchus brewing - Harvest Ale Brewed with Local Cascade and Chinook Hops, Hopshire Farm Brewery - BeeHave, Daddy-O  (malt forward English pale ale) , (Scottish ale) and Near Varna  (IPA), Ithaca Beer Company – New Seasonal Embrr Rye Porter & Flower Power IPA, Six Mile Creek – Variety of local wines & spirits , Teeter Farms – Apple Cider , and Wagner Valley Brewing Co. - Coffee Porter using Ithaca Coffee Co Red Rooster Espresso.  

Great German foods such as  Center Café’s Beer Basted Bratwurst and Sauerkraut, Ithaca Ale House’s Pumpkin Soup, Red’s Place’s German Yummies, Kilpatrick’s Pub’s Turkey Drums, Schokocreme torte(Bavarian Chocolate Pie), Pumpkin Funnel Cake and so much more.

Come celebrate in festive garb or with your signature Oktoberfest drinking boot or authentic lederhosen or dirndl skirt.For more information, to participate as a vendor or volunteer, contact Patty Clark at (607) 277-8679 or ithacaoktoberfest@gmail.com

description:
The time to head to Collegetown is now! This Wednesday visit Rulloff’s to enjoy the fine musical talent of NBR (No Blood Relation) is two fathers-in-law (Jim and Charlie) and their respective sons-in-law (Matt and Trevor) who play songs influensed by traditional and contemporary folk-rock artists. The band includes guitars and mandolin, with the occasional banjo on a song or two. Admission is free.  
The kitchen at Rulloff’s is open until 10pm during the show serving a wide selections of salads, burgers, fresh appetizers and tasty warm entrees to cure the winter chill.  The great selection of craft beers on draft will keep you near the tap and pleasantly surprised.

description:
The 2016 Summer Concert Series presented by CFCU Community Credit Union kicks off on the Bernie Milton Pavilion stage in the Ithaca Commons on Thursday, June 23! The Summer Concert Series is a free outdoor concert series open to the public held every Thursday evening from June 23 - September 15 (with the exception of Grassroots week- the show will be on Wednesday, July 20 not Thursday). Local and national acts perform music in genres including jazz, blues, reggae, folk, hip hop, country, bluegrass, rock, and more! 

Enjoy a beer and wine garden open for the duration of each concert. Seating is not provided but participants are encouraged to bring a chair and stay a while! The Downtown Ithaca Summer Concert Series has become a weekly summer tradition in the local community; Ithacans and tourists alike enjoy happening upon a vibrant downtown on a weekday evening. 


The CFCU Community Credit Union (CFCU) returns as title sponsor of the award-winning CFCU Summer Concert Series and will be continuing their support of the United Way of Tompkins County through a fundraiser with exciting prizes. Concertgoers can buy a reusable cup, with 100 percent of the proceeds going to the United Way, and be entered to win a private performance by the Gunpoets and other cool perks. This year, the series is also supported by Seneca Beverage Corporation, Ithaca Marriott Downtown on the Commons, Green Street Pharmacy, Six Mile Creek Vineyard, GreenStar Natural Foods Market, The Ithaca Journal, Legacy Foundation of Tompkins County, and the J. M. McDonald Foundation. 
 
For more information about the CFCU Summer Concert Series and other summer events in downtown Ithaca, please visit www.downtownithaca.com.

description:
THE BRACKET IS IN!!!!

1st Game-10am start (Field B5)
             Team Last Minute vs. 2nd Floor
2nd Game-10am start (Field B4)
             Silky Jones vs. Kilpatrick's 1
3rd Game-11-11:15am start (Field B5)
             Moonies vs. Diane's Downtown AutoGoddesses
4th Game- 11-11:15am start (Field B4)
             Whatever Happened to Automatic Seatbelts vs. Kilpatrick's 2


Event Goodies:
-10 cases of Poland Springs water donated from John Ryan Distributing
-1 case of assorted NutriGrain bars donated from Maines Food
-3 cases of assorted Sun Chips donated from Maines Food
-5 cases of Saratoga Water donated from Maines Food
-2 cases of assorted Snapple from Hilton Garden Inn Ithaca


Some of the rules:

1.  Games will be 7 innings each with a 60 minute time limit.  A new inning will not begin after the time limit.  The home team will always receive their "last licks" even if the time limit is reached.  In the event of a tie game, the "international tie breaker" will be used.  The "international tie breaker" consistsof each team getting 3 outs, but a runner starting the inning on second base.  A 10-run mercy rule will be in effect in the fifth inning.
2.  The umpire will call strikes.  All pitching must be slow pitch.  Modified, slingshot, windmill, and high arc are prohibited.  
3.  No stealing, leading, or bunting.  There is no sliding allowed.  Anyone who slides into a base will be automatically called out.  A player is not allowed to dive into a base to avoid a tag.
4.  Teams will play with nine or ten men in the field.  A team may bat as many different batters as they like.  Free substitutions are allowed throughout the game.  The batting order may not change with the substitutions.  For example, if a player comes late, he must be placed at the end of the batting order, not interrupting the already established lineup.  No pinch runners are allowed.
5.   Every player must play at least 1 full inning (hitting and fielding)
6.   Every team must have at least two men and two women
7.   A team can play upto 10 positions, but can use 9 if needed:
      -pitcher, catcher
      -4 infielders
      -4 outfielders (3 if using 9 people)



Join Kilpatrick's and take part in a life changing event!! On August 21st we will raise money for Mira's Movement, Supporting Kids with Cancer. We are seeking up to 8 teams with 9-15 players each. For a small donation of $15 per person you will be entered into the tournament. The entry donation includes at least 2 games, free snacks and beverages, a free appetizer at Kilpatrick's, and your chance to win a Kilpatrick's mug!!

Help us find enough sponsors and volunteers so we can donate ALL proceeds to our great charity and exceed our goal of $2000. 

Snacks and beverages will be provided by Kilpatrick's and local donors. In addition, there will be softball tournament shirts for sale, proceeds will be donated to Mira's Movement.

Call or email to reserve your teams by August 19th! Space is limited!! Players in the tournament have a chance to win a spot on the Kilpatrick's Slainte Tap displayed on Kilpatrick's Publick House. DON'T MISS YOUR CHANCE AT PUB BRAGGING RIGHTS!!

To register a team, join a team, donate, sponsor or volunteer for this tournament contact 607-277-8900 ext. 1161, or email tim.gammons@hilton.com

description:
This Free Live Music at Rulloff's is as original as you get!

You can meet the man the myth the legend BADHAND was rumored to have been born somewhere in the dusty hills of Danby NY, Some say with a can of spray paint and a stencil in his hands, others say he wielded a set of tile nippers, an MK700 diamond wetsaw and a bucket of mortar. The truth however is that he came out with a shiny red guitar and full drum set which he proceeded to beat on mercilessly. His life was pretty average really. He spent his early years painting birds but soon realized they couldn’t fly very well with paint in their feathers, so he tried fish but couldn’t seem to make the paint stick. When he was about 11 years old he picked up that shiny red guitar and drumset for the first time since his birth and invented 4 different new styles of post progressive, alt country,neo-folk-hop, Dada music. After a few bad reviews he retreated into the wilderness where he developed an abnormal affinity for rocks. In fact some would say he became one with the rocks. Several years later once he returned from the dank wilderness of Danby’s hills he began working on the most ambitious endeavor he had ever faced: finding a job.
name: Free Live Music with: BadHand ( One Man Band of Awesomeness)

description:
Ithaca's premier event of the Fall, Apple Harvest Festival presented by the Tompkins Trust Company, is a three day celebration of food, fun, and apples!

Three fun-filled days of apples, local produce, fresh baked goods, family entertainment, games, rides, prizes and live performances on two stages. Apple Harvest Festival is a great introduction to the farms and artists in Ithaca and its surrounding farming communities  

First time visitors can witness a variety of wonderful local entertainment while strolling Ithaca's recently remodeled outdoor pedestrian shopping mall, The Ithaca Commons.  The pedestrian mall is the epicenter of the festival and the gateway to a nostalgic journey of harvest season fun.

Over 100 vendors will be selling unique apple varieties, hot apple cider donuts, kettle corn, local farm fresh baked goods and a multitude of around the world specialties. Local farmers are on site selling everything from tasty apple beverages to local pumpkins and of course, apples, apples and more apples. Wineries and cideries have regional beverages available for tasting and purchase.  Kids can visit with the goats and learn how fiber is made with Laughing Goat Fiber Farm.  Looking for quality goods, visit 50 different handcrafting artisans along Cayuga Street at the fall craft show which includes jewelry, ceramics, home decor, body care, specialty gifts, unique sculpture, clothing and so much more.

Pledge to Buy Local by liking this page. 

WHY SHOP LOCAL? 
Small Business Saturday was started by American Express four years ago so that small business could have its day. Big retailers have Black Friday and online retailers have Cyber Monday, so Small Business Saturday is a way to educate consumers about shopping locally and to have an impact on the small business bottom line, kick starting the holiday season.  (from Shopsmall.com) 

Downtown Ithaca has over 100 independent, locally owned stores and businesses to choose from. By shopping or dining locally on Saturday, November 29th and for the holidays, patrons can show their support for local businesses and for our community. 

When money is spent at independent locally owned business the money stays here. Local businesses donate more, and the owners and managers live and pay taxes here, strengthening the economic base of where we live. Plus the one-of-a-kind businesses contribute to the character of our community with unique shopping and dining options. 

For more information visit shopsmall.com or www.downtownithaca.com

description:
PRIMATE FIASCO from Northhampton, MA midway through their three month New England blowout tour will be gracing The Range's stage on Thursday April 6....

"To a deaf person, they look like a New Orleans dixieland street band. To a blind person, they sound like a rave DJ mashing-up house beats with 60′s folk lyrics. To the police, it’s a busy day on the sidewalk.

The Primate Fiasco uses instruments that are loud without electricity, giving them the opportunity to attack at any moment, in any location, with or without permission. No one is safe, not even an elevator or city bus. If The Primate Fiasco sees a dull moment somewhere, they will pop out of the nearest sewer drain or trash can to lead an irresistible dance party.

On stage, the sound is different. This band has pioneered what is possible with mind-bending Accordion, funky pockets of a hyperactive Sousaphone player, and banjo that thinks it’s a Fender Strat. Add lyrics that grab hold of even the most inattentive audience and beats that channel surf like a remote that’s been sat on. The music is always high energy and extremely imaginative. Most importantly, this is fun. People smile from the first beat to the last smoldering ash of what was previously a dance floor.

Following a Grammy-nominated kids album, several conquered jam and electronica fests and stolen hearts at prestigious folk festivals, the Primate Fiasco audience demographic is as diverse as a New York City street. No one is safe from the Fiasco. You will smile."

THE ITHACA BOTTOM BOYS have been turning heads in the local and regional scene recently due to several undeniably stellar shows at last years Grassroots Music Festival in Trumansburg, and at The Blind Spots welcome home show at The Haunt this past Saint Patricks Day. 

Delightfully disorienting in their designated "genre" the Bottom Boys do their best to keep their audiences engaged, loose, and wanting more. 

It was only this past Saturday that the IBB came home from their first shows out of NYS. The week was packed with unforgettably formative experiences, where they were given new opportunities to refine their sound and stage show to new calibers.

DOORS at 9PM, SHOW at 9:30
COVER $5

description:
The Range welcomes Gratefully Yours Friday March 31st. Come celeabrate with one of the best Grateful Dead cover bands around! Break out your colorful tie-dyes and spend the evening listening to cultural music that has withstood the test of time.

Band Bio:

Gratefully Yours has quickly established itself as one of the Northeast’s premiere Grateful Dead cover bands; with a truly all-star lineup and often performing “dream” set lists submitted by their fans. The band was founded in 2012 by Alex Mazur, (founding member and keyboardist of The Deadbeats… one of the, if not the longest running Grateful Dead cover bands in existence).  Along with a core lineup that includes, Adam Czolowski (Sonic Garden), Tom Pirozzi (Ominous Seapods), Jeff Martinson (Shakedown) and Rob Schiff (Nailed Shutt), other honored members include Vinnie Amico (moe.), Rob Eaton (Dark Star Orchestra), Russ Lawton (Trey Anastasio Band), Bill Carbone (Max Creek) and Zach Nugent (Cats Under The Stars).
The Dead were a truly unique band and had a unique bond with their audience:  Magic is what they did. Music was how they did it. Ultimately, it is that magic that Gratefully Yours aims to “cover” and pay tribute to. And taking it one step further, they also encourage their audience to participate further in the creative process by giving them the opportunity to submit their dream set lists (or vote for one) online and the band often chooses one to perform at their shows. But of course, you never know what might happen…

      St. Vith takes a modern impression on the 70's jam styles of bands such as the grateful dead. They are tuned to a intimate setting such as wineries and cafes, though they are not limited. Festivals and larger settings allow for a fuller spectrum of intensity and sound. Ever changing with guests, and environment, St. Vith provides an eclectic original and colorful experience.

description:
Downtown Ithaca introduces Day Out in Downtown

This inaugural event features walking tour, luncheon at Madeline's, and jewelry appraisal lesson at Mansour Jewelers for the older adults of our community. 

This fun-filled, mid-day event, slated for Tuesday, Nov. 1, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.

A free, short walking tour, starting at 10 a.m., will kick off the day's activities. Participants will get to explore downtown's historic State Theatre, visit the new Press Bay Alley micro-retail project and see the unique neighborhood surrounding these locations.

Following this activity, attendees will then get to unwind and socialize while they enjoy a special, all-inclusive, three-course lunch at one of Ithaca's premier restaurants on the Commons, Madeline's. The cost for this tasty activity is $24.50 ($21.30 for anyone 65 or older). A vegan option will be available among the entree choices.

After lunch, at 2 p.m., participants can walk the short distance to Mansour Jewelers where local jeweler David Abdulky will conduct a free lesson about what gives jewelry its value. Attendees are welcome to bring a piece of their own jewelry to this event to receive a complimentary cleaning and instruction on proper jewelry care.

Come for one, two, or all three of the events. A reservation is necessary if you plan to take part at the Day Out luncheon. To reserve your seat, call Madeline's at (607) 277-2253.

For more information about this special day, call the Downtown Ithaca Alliance at (607) 277-8679.

description:
Born in the woods of Connecticut and raised in the wilds of Boston, lespecial has established themselves as innovators and tastemakers on their own unique trajectory. The aggressive death-funk dance trio explodes with energetic live sets, tapping into a primitive past distorted through the lense of contemporary technology. Their debut full length album “Omnisquid”, out November 20th 2015, captures the band (at their heaviest,) interweaving dark, heavy, polyrhythmic grooves with head bobbing electronic synths and samplers augmented with fierce, precise musicianship, creating an apocalyptic backdrop for the sci-fi storyline. Preceded by their Ceremony EP (2013) and Playonbrother Sessions (2011), Jonathan Grusauskas (guitar/synth/sampler/vocals), Luke Bemand (bass/synth) and Rory Dolan (drums/sampler) ignore convention, instead amalgamating the familiar styles of Afro-Latin rhythmic traditions, Hip Hop, Funk and Metal into a singular sound that dexterously transforms during their live sets and over the course of their studio albums. As Ben Weiss of Relix Magazine puts it, “Amidst the rest of the noise, lespecial is the squeaky wheel that demands attention.”
Follow at @lespecialmusic 
http://www.lespecial.net/
http://www.lespecial.bandcamp.com/
http://www.soundcloud.com/lespecial
