description:
IT STARTS WITH YOU: Sexual Assault Awareness Week 

We are incredibly fortunate to have well-acclaimed author, Kate Harding, join us for the 2nd Annual SAAW Keynote Address!

The talk will focus on the cohorts most susceptible to sexual assault and violence, the cultural norms that perpetuate the core issues, and how we as students and humanitarians can rectify them. 

-- More about Kate Harding -- 
http://www.kateharding.info/
@KateHarding

Kate Harding is the author of Asking For It: The Alarming Rise of Rape Culture—and What We Can Do About It, a finalist for the Minnesota Book Award in general nonfiction.

Previously, she collaborated with Anna Holmes, Amanda Hess, and a cast of thousands on The Book of Jezebel, and with Marianne Kirby on Lessons from the Fat-o-Sphere. You might also remember her as the founding editor of Shapely Prose (2007-2010). 

    Kate holds an M.F.A. in fiction from Vermont College of Fine Arts and a B.A. in English from University of Toronto. She's currently at work on a Ph.D. in creative writing from Bath Spa University and was very pleased to join The Loft Literary Center as a teaching artist in fall 2015. 
___

Take Action Together: Cornell's 2nd Annual Sexual Assault Awareness Week brings together a wide range of communities to foster dialogue about the issue of sexual assault. For more information and events, visit www.cornellsaaw.com and www.fb.com/CornellSAAW.

Many thanks to the 50+ Cornell organizations committed to taking action for sexual assault prevention in our community. 

#TakeActionTogether #ItStartsWithYou #CornellSAAW

___

description:
The Emerging Markets Institute (EMI) at the Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University will be exploring:

• How emerging multinationals from Asia and Latin America have expanded aggressively on a global scale.
• Coming from regions which are/were very volatile and from countries with lower Gross Domestic Product/capita than developed countries, how have some of these companies been able to succeed internationally?
• How are they changing the competitive environment for multinationals from the developed countries?
• What can we expect from them over the next years? And how they are now innovating to move to the next phase.

*Link to Register is https://wdbcs.secure.force.com/pmtx/evt__QuickEvent?id=a3FA00000006bsI

description:
The Cornell Data Science project team would like to invite all those interested to our upcoming professor talk series:

In Hollister Hall room 110 this Thursday at 5:30 pm, Professor Carla Gomes will be giving a talk on "Challenges for Data Science in Computational Sustainability."

Computational sustainability is a new interdisciplinary research field with the overarching goal of developing computational models, methods, and tools to help manage the balance between environmental, economic, and societal needs for a sustainable future. Professor Gomes will provide an overview of computational sustainability, with examples ranging from wildlife conservation and biodiversity, to poverty mitigation, to materials discovery for renewable energy materials. She will also highlight cross-cutting computational themes and challenges for Data Science at the intersection of machine learning, optimization, citizen science, and crowd sourcing.

Carla Gomes is a Professor of Computer Science and the director of the Institute for Computational Sustainability at Cornell University. Her research area is Artificial Intelligence with a focus on large-scale constraint-based reasoning, optimization, and machine learning. Recently, she has become deeply immersed in the establishment of new field of Computational Sustainability.

If you need accommodations to participate in this event, please contact sc2356 as soon as possible.

venue.name: Cornell Data Science

name: CDS Professor Talk Series - Carla Gomes

description:
The Islamic Alliance for Justice (IAJ) invites you to

The French Burkini Ban: Secularism, Security and Politics of Gender
5:00 - 6:30 PM Tuesday September 27th, 2016
G-76 Lewis Auditorium Goldwin Smith Hall

This summer, about 30 French towns passed laws banning the 'burkini' – full-body swimwear typically worn by Muslim women – from public beaches. The rationale behind these laws ranges from upholding French laïcité to seeing burkini as symbolic of enslavement of Muslim women to concerns over national security and public order especially in the wake of recent terror attacks in France. Critics of the ban, however, have called the laws Islamophobic and misogynist, seeing it as a continuation of the French colonial ‘civilizing mission’ and highlighting the marginalization of the Muslim minority in France.

Join us to engage in an important conversation on security, gender and racism in the context of French secularism with three distinguished Cornell professors:

Panelists:

Camille Robcis is an Associate Professor in the History Department. Her research focuses on on three broad issues: the relationships among intellectuals, ideas, and politics; the historical construction of norms; and the articulation of universalism and difference in the context of modern France. She is the author of  The Law of Kinship: Anthropology, Psychoanalysis, and the Family in Twentieth-Century France (Cornell University Press, 2013) and has taught courses on modern European history, French history, intellectual history, historiography, gender and sexuality, psychoanalysis, contemporary critical theory, and European social and political thought.

Durba Ghosh is an Associate Professor in the History Department. She has written extensively on gender, culture, law, archives, and colonial governance in eighteenth- and nineteenth-century India, and is interested in the importance of history in legitimizing anti-colonial struggles. She is the author of Sex and the Family in Colonial India: the making of empire (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2006) and her current research focuses on popular and radical political movements in early and mid-twentieth century India as well as the role of political violence in popular historical narratives.

Richard Miller is a Professor in the Philosophy Department and Director of the Program on Ethics and Public Life. His main interest is social and political philosophy and he has authored several books including Globalizing Justice: The Ethics of Poverty and Power (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2010) and Moral Differences: Truth, Justice and Conscience in a World of Conflict (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1992). His writing and teaching on social justice concern the moral significance of economic inequality, the nature and implications of democratic values and the proper political role of evaluations of ways of life; he addresses these issues in a book he is currently writing The Ethics of Social Democracy.

Moderator: Satya Mohanty is a Professor in the Department of English and his work is in literary and cultural theory.  He is a co-founder of the Future of Minority Studies (FMS) Research Project, the Global South Cultural Dialogue Project and the South Asian Vernacular Culture and Alternative Modernities Project and he is the coordinator of the Minority, Indigenous and Third World Studies Research group at Cornell. He is the author of Literary Theory and the Claims of History: Postmodernism, Objectivity, Multicultural Politics among other publications and co-editor of Identity Politics Reconsidered.

Cosponsored by: MITWSrg (Minority, Indigenous & Third World Studies), Cornell University Department of History, The Cornell Program on Ethics and Public Life, Cornell Asian Pacific Islander Student Union - CAPSU, Arab Student Association at Cornell. APAA | Asian Pacific Americans for Action at Cornell University, Cornell University Pakistani Students Association, ALANA Intercultural Board, Amnesty International at Cornell University, MEChA de Cornell, [BSA] Bengali Student Association | Cornell, Cornell Organization for Labor Action, Mario Einaudi Center for International Studies at Cornell University, Cornell Students for Justice in Palestine, Cornell MECA - Muslim Educational and Cultural Association, Native American Students at Cornell (NASAC), Black Students United at Cornell University, Amnesty International group 73, Ithaca

description:
A proposed budget has reccomended the De-Funding of the Office of Violence Against Women (OVW) and elminating ALL Violence Against Women Act Grants. These grants fund victim service agencies across the country to provide crisis hotlines, safe housing and victim advocacy services to those experiencing Domestic & Sexual Violence. 

Join us  on International Women's Day as part of the Day Without Women Strike to send a message to our representatives that we MUST Protect VAWA and survivors. You can write postcards, design clothesline T-shirts and partake in a photo booth to share why VAWA matters and needs to stay funded! All paper t-shirts will be compiled and delivered to Tom Reed as a visual representation of why VAWA is important to his constituents.

name: Protect VAWA
